description:
Probably top 5 tacos I have ever had- I know.. that is a big statement to make. But the chicken super taco was so fantastic. I had to get up and get a second one because it was so flavorful and so tasty! 

They only take cash so if you are like me and never ever have cash, make sure u stop by an atm before checking this place out! 

You really cannot get a better value for the price. Tacos were cheap, tasty and each order came with chips and salsa! I was so full and happy for less than $10
author: Kiva M.

description:
Okay YUM. One of the best things I ate in SF. A cute, lively burrito joint with amazing burritos and fast service. The cashier was cracking jokes with us the whole time and was so funny. Get the carne asada super burrito if you want guac & sour cream. The meat was so well seasoned. I'm a flour tortilla snob (I'm from Texas) and I thought it was a perfect tortilla. The chips and salsa were skippable, but they're not the reason you're here anyways. Get it to go and walk over to Dolores park for a perfect place to eat your burrito. 

Btw, it's cash only but they have an ATM inside.
author: Nikki T.

description:
Best vegetarian burrito in town.  Comes with the best green salsa in town.  The rest of the menu seems pretty good although I've only tried some of the tacos and plates.  The veggie super burrito is my favorite though and repeat order.  It comes with generous slices of avocado, flavorful beans and rice, not to mention a good amount of cheese and sour cream.  Additionally, it's wrapped in a delicious flour tortilla that's either grilled or toasted.  

*It's cash only but there's an atm inside.
author: Jenn L.

description: Got a regular cabeza burrito and at first, before biting into anything, it smelled amazing. Tortilla hot, soft, not soggy, and smelled delicious. I could smell the meat coming out too! Biting into it, everything was steaming hot and was warming to the soul. However, the meat was not what I expected. It seemed more like carne asada as opposed to cabeza. The meat was still delicious, but not as soft, tender, fatty, and melty as cabeza normally would be. The rice had a lot of flavor as well and everything together was great! Wish they gave more chips though.
author: Rachelle C.

description: This place was a late night life saver! I needed to get some friends fed after a night of drinking and this place was absolutely perfect. The service was super fast, and the environment is pretty fun. The Super Burrito with chicken is what I got which was absolutely delicious and definitely worth the price (which wasn't too bad). The burrito is huge though, so maybe consider sharing with someone if you plan on getting it.
author: Nesha P.

description: Aaaamazzzing. Soooo authentic. Worth every penny. The meat-to-tortilla ratio is on point on the tacos.
author: Sandy C.

description: Ever wonder what a real burrito tastes like? You know, the quintessential California burrito that West Coasters are always harping on about, and swear you can't get anywhere else. Come here and find out. This is how you burrito. Get the super.
author: Randy H.

description:
Overall the food here is much better than farolito. The issue is they have made the burritos start at $9.50, effecively price gouging 90% of patrons who are here for a quick meal. They lose a star for that.

Pictured here is their equivalent of a wet burrito. It was between $11-12 which is fair. 

Would return. 

Cash only and atm on site. Very fast service.

Salsas were below avg.
author: Atif J.

description:
I had a the Veggie Burrito after seeing that it was the "best Veggie burrito" in town. Unfortunately, I should have probably gotten a regular meat burrito, because the veggie burrito was just like what I would expect a meat burrito to be like, except with like avocado on the inside instead of nicely grilled meat. It ended up missing that special touch of meat flavor that makes burritos good.

So I guess this is what a "Mission Burrito" tastes like, and to be honest, coming from SoCal, I think he burritos down there taste much better. They're pricier up here (but that's expected), and I don't think they taste as good. The ones in SoCal have rich flavors, and everything goes well, and the seasoning is always on point, which I couldn't quite say the same for here. Some parts felt a bit bland, others were just okay, and it didn't really come all together.

The one nice thing though, is their green salsa is good! A little on the simpler side, it still is nice and hot as I would expect from a green salsa.
author: Tyler T.

description:
when you're in doubt about a Taqueria, the safest bet for you is to order a Quesadilla.
I had doubt about this place since I've been to the one on Market st and it wasn't a good burrito experience.
why the safest bet is to order a quesadilla when you're not sure about a particular taqueria?
because even bad taquerias at least makes decent quesadillas!
it's grilled tortilla, cheese, carne asada.
it's hard to mess up.

and quesadillas are generally cheaper and less hurting emotionally if you don't like it, than burritos (San Franciscans take their burritos seriously).
and cheaper than tacos (because you don't order just one taco).

but this place can't even make a decent quesadilla for $9.50 (tax).
or at least be generous.

I had doubt and I wasn't wrong.
author: Rudy H.

description:
Delicious kinda felt as if I was in Mexico due to the surroundings and the food. Great taco de lengua, nachos especiales not so good taco de carnitas. 
Overall delicious  and they serve Mexican beer!!! Cheers!!!
author: Nathaly G.

description: This place is overrated. The salsa was a solid 3/5, chips were bad, and carnitas super burrito was just an overall 3/5. I don't understand the hype of this place.
author: Alvin D.

description:
There's something about a wet huge burrito that's deeply satisfying. Taqueria Cancun definitely delivers that sweet Mission bucketlist burrito and it's delicious to boot. Cash only with a helpful staff, I got a huge "wet" Majado with carne asada and it was delicious and filling. Impressive if you can eat a whole one and definitely a fork and knife endeavor. Free chips when you sit down -- score!

The enchiladas looked great as well, but pretty much everyone in our party had a burrito. Delightful!
author: Alex L.

description: So delicious. So happy they are open again. I think I stopped having burritos because they were closed. :)
author: Diane L.

description:
Someone told me about this taqueria and I had to try it.
It's cash only, gotta tell you that, but it was worth it. ATM is inside if you're like me and never carry cash. 
We tried the nachos w/carne asada and they were really good. They could've use a little bit more beans, but overall good flavor. 
The Super Burrito was big, it had beans, rice, avocado and I had it half and half, half asada and half pastor. The pastor wasn't from a trompo but the flavor was good.
author: Alex H.

description:
There is a reason this is one of the best Taqueria's in the city. It has officially surpassed El Faralito in my book because of:

1) size
2) quality
3) flavor
4) their super nachos with both the sour cream and the green sauce
6) Their cheese enchiladas

I will be back that is for sure! You don't need to be drunk to enjoy these tacos and burritos!
author: Morgan S.

description:
I had a few hours to kill before taking off at the airport, and I was determined to find and consume the best burrito in the mission. After much research and deliberation, I settled on Cancun.

Order: super carne asada burrito 
Cost: about $10, cash only 

Pros: 
-Steak was surprisingly tender
-Flavorful overall
-Decent size
-Colorful, cheery atmosphere with plenty of seats
-Free chips and salsa
-I got there just around 4pm and had no line or wait (burrito was ready within minutes) 

Cons:
-Poor distribution of ingredients. First few bites were full of sour cream, and then the sour cream was hardly present halfway through. 
-No discernible cheese
-Second half of the burrito was very salty, almost too salty to eat (perhaps correlated with the tapering off of the sour cream that helped temper the salt?)
-Sadly, the fresh avocado chunks added little flavor or value
-Could have used a bit more heat (or a spicier salsa)

Overall, I was a bit let down by this burrito, especially at $10. I had picked Cancun because I read specifically that their burritos were well spiced and had good ingredient distribution, but this was the opposite of what I experienced. 

The biggest redeeming factor was the tenderness of the steak (but maybe I'm just used to tough meat in my steak burritos and don't know any better?). 

I was also really disappointed that there didn't appear to be any cheese. I looked for if, many times, but if it was there I could neither taste nor see it. It also got SO salty by the end that I was having trouble finishing it.

Side note: the cook had to kick out both a pigeon (who had strolled in the door casually and hilariously) and a homeless person who came in to ask for change.
author: Jenn C.

description: Yummy breakfast burrito. I got a breakfast burrito without chorizo. They're huge, super filling, and have a good ratio of ingredients. It wasn't busy around 10:30am which was nice. They also give you your individual free chips and salsa with every order. They were also very friendly!
author: Cassandra G.

description:
No way you can't give this place five stars, favorite place to go for a burrito in the Mission. My favorite thing to get is the super burrito with al pastor. I love that they slice avocado instead of guacamole. The burritos are also huge for the price, so worth it!

One small note, they are cash only so remember to bring cash. They have an ATM machine inside though, so you have an alternative if you want.
author: Erin H.

description: Cash only. Best burritos in Mission. Like chipotle but 10x as good and big. Seriously you may want to split a burrito. Good prices good/fresh ingredients good beer. Stays busy but doesn't get too packed. Get their burrito mojado. Colorful inside, Mexican music and a bathroom which you may need afterwards.
author: Jared J.

description:
Tasty burrito / taco / meat plate spot, but not downright amazing to make me eat there all the time.

Have to get there at the right time- we went around 8pm on a Sunday evening and barely managed to grab a table (there are oh so many seats inside).  Lines can get super long and crowds the inside of the place, so not good if you are claustrophobic.  

My guy friends ordered the carne asada burritos- first thing I noticed were how massive they are!  Even they had trouble eating the whole thing (one of whom did a 3 hr bike ride just before)... I can't even imagine trying to eat one myself.  Also noticed how much salsa they dumped on their burritos, which personally means that it was either not flavorful or was dry.

I ordered the Alambres (beef, bacon, peppers, onions, rice, beans, and tortillas) and, again, the plate was massive.  The only reason I ate most of it was because I had just gone on a super long run and needed the carbs.  The meat was flavorful, but it was unfortunately rather tough and salty (probs was because of the bacon).

Super cheap- we all paid less than $10 for these massive plates of food (mine was the most expensive at $9.99).

So it's not a go-to place for me, but it's not the worst option ever in the Mission.  I can see why people might like it (cheap price for massive portions); maybe I just ordered the wrong thing.  Put it this way- if everyone in my group of friends wants to go here, I'd tag along, though I probably won't be the one to suggest it.
author: Audrey H.

description: We tried to go to Gracias Madre (i know, but it sounded interesting) and there was a 45 minute wait. Ended up here instead and I'm so glad they asked us to wait that long. Super fast service. Amazing meats (carne asada, super prawn, al pastor, carnitas) you name it. ALSO their nachos come as a huge pile of amazingness. I wish I ordered that. Next time!! Highly recommend. 10/10. The ambience is fantastic as well. They have a Virgin Mary so you know it's real.
author: Cherrilyn B.

description:
Yes. Yes. Yes. The grilled carne asada super burrito here was the best of the Cali Mex food I had on my trip to San Francisco, and I am the kind of person who does the two lunch bang-bang, so I tried a lot of food on my trip. I am literally tearing up a little knowing I can't get my hands on another Taqueria Cancun burrito in the foreseeable future. 

Every flavor and texture was perfect and they were not skimpy on the avocado or cheese. The meat was juicy and bursting with flavor. Just so good.

When I say it was the best burrito, I mean it - I also tried La Taqueria and El Farolito (and Little Chihuahua) the same day so I am not messing around.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
No tripe so that was a letdown. However, we liked that our tacos came with a side of chips and salsa -- loved the crunch of the chips and the salsa flavor! The soft tacos weren't as sizable as Farolito but we loved the extra crisp of the carnitas (my gf preferred Cancun's). I liked the lengua but it wasn't as memorable as I would have liked.

Would like to return!
author: Daryn L.

description:
I needed a Mission burrito and I needed it before I headed to the airport in the am. I had read about Taqueria Cancun and was able to make it before they closed on a Sunday night. Located on Mission Street across the street from a neighborhood watering hole called Beauty Bar. It was late and in their last hour of business, so the drunk crowd was def in effect. No comment on how the Mission has changed since I was a kid.... On to the food.

I ordered a carne asada super burrito ($8.99). It comes with rice, beans, onions, salsa, cheese, avocado & sour cream. Sin cilantro para mi. Taqueria Cancun's burritos are pretty big. They are not cylindrical like El Farolito. They are fatter and use a different kind of flour tortilla. Still good and loaded with flavors. The asada was good and the other ingredients with the meat, all went well together. It is definitely a meal unto itself. It's not cheap but you will be stuffed after you're through. 

We also ordered a couple of super tacos ($3.99). One asada and one al pastor. They are big too and really loaded. Each super taco, like the super burrito, comes with onions, cilantro, salsa, cheese, avocado and sour cream. Lots of sour cream. It's good stuff! The al pastor is pretty good. I liked it. 

We took our food back to the hotel but they still gave us the complimentary chips and salsa. Service was friendly and quick. Tip the good folks at Taqueria Cancun. They more than deserve it.
author: Chuck D.

description:
**3.5 stars** 

I totally did not check Yelp before coming here and I did not know that it was CASH ONLY. Luckily there was an ATM inside so I could withdraw some cash ($2 transaction fee). There was a line for the ATM so I'm guessing a lot of people didn't know either. I came here solely for the tacos and I ended up getting four: lengua, cabeza, carne asada, and carnitas. Total was $14, a little more expensive than I'm used to. I expect a regular taco (just onions, cilantro, and salsa) to usually be around $2.50-3 at a taqueria but it's $3.25 for one here. The tacos are pretty big though so I would say they're worth the price. 

The lengua and cabeza were very tender. Carne asada wasn't that great - a bit dry. The carnitas though, was the best carnitas I've ever had! It was perfectly fried pork that was juicy and flavorful. It was definitely my favorite out of the four. What was lacking was the salsa on top of the tacos. Although the tortilla was quite soft, I would have preferred more salsa on the tacos cause after a few bites, the tacos got kind of dry. They do give chips and salsa with your purchase, but the chips tasted like something I could get at a grocery store instead of the fresh, crispy chips I get at other taquerias. I love chips and salsa along with my Mexican food so good chips are a deal breaker for me! I ended up using the salsa that came with the chips for my tacos instead. It would be so much better if they had a salsa bar! 

Overall, tacos were good, but I've had better experiences elsewhere and it's a bit more pricey than the other taquerias I've been to.
author: Cecille W.

description:
Came heren on a Sunday around 2pm...had a super steak.. asked them to grill the burrito and totally ignored me. Didn't bother asking the to regrill. Server seems lazy. 

Had first bite of burrito thinking it was a hidden gem place bc of the good reviews on yelp..

It had to be the dryest, most tasteless burrito I ever had. And I'm a burrito mission fanboy..

Couple barely taste the carneasada, though I was sick and couldn't feel my taste buds.
author: Aj D.

description:
I've been coming to Taqueria Cancun for more than 15 years. I don't visit frequently, but I've eaten the food at least a dozen times over the years. And I've come to realize that the food tastes best when intoxicated. Other Yelpers agree on that note.

Yesterday I ordered the super burrito with 50/50 carne asada and lengua. The lengua was great but the carne asada was overcooked. It had two tiny slivers of avocado, enough cheese but almost no sour cream or salsa. I really want to enjoy the "super" part of my burrito when I order one, so Taqueria Cancun let me down.

The service is always patient and helpful, generally nice at the counter. They're so busy though that it's difficult for them to stay on top of clearing tables and there isn't a station to drop your dirty dishes. So tables are often left dirty.

On the contrary, the restroom was as clean as I had ever found it and it pleasantly smelled of bleach instead of anything that would ruin a meal. Perhaps that's because I arrived at 6:00 before the dinner rush.

In any event, the ambiance is cool and touristy. The food is so so, but the complimentary chips are nice. For me, I look forward to trying some of the other longstanding as well as the new & hip Mission District food offerings.
author: Gisele X.

description: Dearest Cancun please come back. I move to the mission and you close for remodeling just two months into my stay? I miss you so, please remodel quickly. Out of the Mexican restaurants, surely you are the best for convenience and possibly flavor as well.
author: Jackson W.

description: First experience of getting a burrito. We ordered the super burrito which included beef, rice, sour cream. I am a Chinese, but i definitely could accept and like this burrito. MY HUSBAND ordered no bean and onion for me.  I don't like Mexicon food before I been here. The burrito like my arm's big just 10 bubs so that I separated for 2 meals. Half for lunch. Half for dinner. Anyway tasty and good atmosphere restaurant! :-D
author: Yingying C.

description:
All I can say is WOW. Whenever I am craving Mexican food, I immediately crave Taqueria Cancun. Why do I have to live in nyc!?

My boyfriend and I were craving authentic Mexican food and this was definitely the spot. I ordered three tacos (one supreme chicken, one marinated pork and one beef tongue). I highly recommend getting the supreme tacos (or at least one). It was absolutely delicious. And the beef tongue was so tender. The marinated pork was just okay. They give you chips with your order that were the perfect amount (I hate when I fill up on too many chips beforehand). We split a plate of rice and beans - the beans were fantastic! My boyfriend said the best he has ever had. The rice was also good! (But we have had better ;)) my boyfriend got the supreme burrito, which he was a little disappointed that it was smothered, as he would have rather enjoyed eating with his hands than a knife and fork. 

And the price is obviously perfect! No complaints there. The one thing I wish I could have changed was how freezing I was! We sat as far away from the door as possible but I could not warm up. Next time I'm bringing a heavier coat!!
author: Maddy O.

description:
Their burrito mojado with carne asada was delicious and huge! My friend and I split the burrito with an order of super nachos (chips with jalapenos, carne asada, avocado, refried beans) and we left ultra bloated. There are cups of water near the cash register towards the bathroom. 

We went on a wednesday around 1 and it was half full and was able to get a seat immediately. Food took about 10 min to prepare.
author: Laura E.

description:
I really wanted to give this place 4 stars but i think 3.5 is where i will settle. 

The two of us shared a mojado burrito carne asada! It was wet and spicy. The salsas and sauce were the best part of it. Burrito was good but perhaps not the best meat since it was a bit tough and very tiny bits. All in all a good experience tho, or at least until i went home and got very gassed up - very unpleasant evening!

Friendly staff but the place is not very clean especially the bathroom.

Something that upset me further is the use of plastic forks and knives. This is a sit down place so it's pretty uncomfortable to try and cut your wet burrito with non environmentally friendly tools. Even if they would be recyclable, i don't see reason why a sit down place would do this. Might not return...my heart is little broken
author: Heliana M.

description: There are a ton of great burritos in the Mission and this one is definitely up there. Their vegetarian burrito is quite filling and not just filled with beans and rice, but fresh fajitas. The hot salsa is actually hot which is nice for a change. The burritos are a bit pricey and considering it is cash only, can be a pain if the people you come with are unprepared. Overall, great food in the Mission. It is a little off the beaten path with all the bars on 18th St. but if you are willing to make the walk, the food is definitely worth it!
author: Vaibhav S.

description:
One of my favorite Taqueria's in the bay area.

The burrito has chunks of fresh avocado inside and tastes great with or with out salsa. Both the carne asada and al pastor tacos are fresh and traditional. Their salsa's are made fresh every day.
author: Marco S.

description:
2 stars when I'm sober. 3 stars when I'm drunk. Okay for a quick drunchie craving if convenient. 

Food is okay. Bit greasy. Lackluster compared to other Taquerias.

There's quite a bit of seating. It's pretty dirty. The grounds uneven so don't trip if you are in heels or messed up!

I ordered a lengua burrito and it was okay.
author: Sean W.

description: Stopped by and tried the carne asada burrito mojado. We were going to get some tacos but saw a bunch of people eating this amazing looking wet burrito so we got it instead. We ordered it to go and feasted in Dolores park. Unfortunately, they had given us two knives instead of two forks but we made it work. The burrito was at least 6 inches long and maybe 4 inches in diameter. It was stuffed with rice, beans, onions, cilantro, salsa, and carne asada (small chunks and I wish there was more of it). Then, they top the burrito with green salsa, melted cheese, sour cream, and mexican salsa. Finally, its all smothered in enchilada sauce. YUM. It came with a bag of chips with both salsas on the side, as well.
author: Christine L.

description:
Incredible vegetarian burrito! I live in the mission, and this is my first time here. I can't be more happy right now. 
The tortilla is just melting, and mouth watering. The quality is well done here. My favorite taqueria in the city. Simple and authentic to grab a bite.
author: Lena A.

description:
Pros:
- Hearty portions, nothing skimpy here;
- Quick & friendly service;
- Open til 2am;
- Free chips & salsa with every order. What used to be standard is now rare cuz everyone wanna nickel & dime nowadays. 

Cons:
- Extremely limited street parking;
- Cash only. 

Classic taqueria in the heart of Mission between 19th & 18th. 

Everything is generously filled with fresh veggies and your favorite protein ensuring each bitefull is loaded with equal parts meat, cheese, beans, & rice. 

Favorites:
- tacos al pastor
- burrito mojado
- quesadilla suiza con camarones
author: Geminyna J.

description: Great food for very good price. I love the fajitas here! Not fancy atmosphere but authentic hole in the wall feeling.
author: Greta V.

description:
With so many taquerias in "The Mission", how does one know which ones are good or not?  Well, follow the crowds and you'll come upon Taqueria Cancun.  It's a small joint with limited seating, but they draw in more than their fair share of patrons.

It's the vibe, it's the quality and taste of the food, it's the more than reasonable prices...Heck it's all that and more!

We recommend going with the Burrito Mojado with carnitas.  It's huge with red sauce poured over it.  Yummy!  True the utensils are cheap but the food more than makes up for some deficiencies/cost cutting measures!
author: Gene D.

description:
I was a bit skeptical about how good this place was going to be, but I was pleasantly surprised with my experience here. The food was awesome!
 
No surprise here, but there was a bit of a wait, though the line does move fairly fast as the crew seemed to have mastered the taking of customers' orders down to an artform of sorts. I had ordered the vegetarian burrito, and honestly, it was one of the best Mission style burritos I've ever had. It was simple enough, but somehow, the flavors just came together so much better than anything I've ever had in NYC.
 
I will say, though, that the place is a bit too grungy for my tastes. The bathroom was super gross. Aside from, that the food was excellent and super cheap.
author: Cinthia K.

description:
I've been here a number time for drunchies and never fully appreciated the beauty of Taqueria Cancún until I came here sober.

I came on a Thursday night around 8:30 pm and the place was reasonably filled but not overly crowded; my friend ordered the pork quesadilla and I got the beef tongue super burrito. The pork quesadilla was seriously sooooo juicy and friggin bomb!! The beef tongue in my super burrito was incredibly tender and the burrito was great--my only qualm is I wish they put a tad bit more salsa inside because the other flavors can get really heavy without the fresh salsa to cut the grease and richness of the rest of the ingredients.

Price was reasonable and what you'd expect from a burrito shop. 

Oh!!! They have beef brain... not for the faint of heart. I tried a sample of it and it was really tender but didn't have much flavor to it. If you're feeling ballsy sample it!
author: Joy K.

description:
Lame carnitas burrito with just not tasty meat. Total let down. 

The chips offered nothing to cheer me up either.
author: Lanny B.

description: After bar hoping through the Mission (like I was in my 20's again) we topped off the night with a trip to Taqueria Cancun. We got a very large plate of nachos, lots of beers, some burritos and enjoyed a very loud last meal for the night. Despite the long lines, your food comes out fast and the tables turn over fairly quickly so you're not waiting very long for a seat. There was also a semi naked person that we shared our nachos with hanging out outside. Semi naked because at least he wore a bathrobe. Having lived in HI for the last few years, we have zero Mexican restaurants so you learn to appreciate a quality burrito and this place does not disappoint. The prices are cheap and the burrito was so damn good. I miss this place already. Someone bring me a burrito.
author: Cameron B.

description:
Had the veggie burrito eight dollars mostly rice, not good tasting. 
Nachos were a complete disaster, they put refried beans and white cheese on top of chips then microwaved NASTY! $8.00
I would never recommend and never be back. 
Decour is horrible.
author: Rod D.

description:
Please don't ask me what my favorite Mission Taqueria is.

Know that this is up there. 

It's the creamy, fatty beans.  Al-dente rice with heaps of tomato-y goodness and none of the sog.   Quick-grilled meats that were OBVIOUSLY marinated in chiles and salt and pepper and love.  

Tender corn tortillas; luscious flour ones. 

Fair prices.  And the dudes always seem to be having a good time.
author: Jolene H.

description: This review is for the al pastor super burrito with everything. It's perfect. Texas may have great tacos, but our burritos are lacking. I could seriously eat a Cancun burrito everyday. The flour tortilla was homemade, the al pastor was perfectly spiced, the chips were fresh, and the salsa was tasty. Cash only. They have beer, too.
author: Lauren A.

description:
I was so disappointed in this place. I thought that with the great reviews it had, I would be willing to eat here. I was looking for a great Mexican restaurant that is open later in the evening where I was and this was the closest. 

I ordered a carnitas plate and it was just really dry and lacked seasoning. On my plate, the only thing I ended up liking the most was the rice. I didn't bother with the beans and the lettuce and tomato on the side. Because I was still so hungry, I ended up just eating chips and the salsa at the bar. The mango salsa was the best.
author: Crystal H.

description:
After having snacks, drinks, and more drinks, my group of four decided to get tacos! We stopped by for dinner on Wednesday, November 9th around 11:30pm.

I love lengua, so I got a lengua taco. So did a girlfriend of mine. The others got carne asada and I believe maybe a carnitas taco? I can't recall, but they didn't want to be tongued like us. (No pun intended?) My taco was piled high with meat and nice and hot. The lengua was super tender and flavorful. So good! Great meal to end the night. They also gave us some chips and salsa to snack on while we waited for our tacos.

My gf had a gf from out of town, so she said she had to try some tacos while in the Mission. Glad she did as I was finally able to try Taqueria Cancun!

Delicious place to grab some after drinking munchies!
author: Elena N.

description: Even though this place wasn't very busy, I still found the service to be faster than most other places we've been to. Unfortunately for my boyfriend, they were out of tripe and sesos (beef brains). Our order came with chips and salsa which was a plus! We ordered a lengua taco as well as one of carnitas. Lengua lacked some flavor, but nothing their delicious green salsa couldn't help with. I really loved the slight crisp and flavor of the carnitas! Sizes were big enough to divide the one taco into 2 (maybe 2.5). I'm partial to the small street taco tortilla sizes, so that's one thing I wish was an option here. We would definitely come back!
author: Edith Q.

description: It's an institution.  It's fast. You need cash. It's delicious and filling.  Perfect post a big run or ride and pre a big nap.  The burritos are huge and fabulous.  I  walked out happy.
author: Rich P.

description:
A fellow chef suggested that this was the ultimate taco joint, or at least his favorite in the Mission. Arrived late at night, around midnight to find the place full of drunk 20 & 30 somethings -
 no surprises there. 20 Somethings stuffing themselves with sauce smothered burritos the size of a small baby's arm. The tortillas were served very hot, the meat was squishy and mysteriously tender (carne asada) The salsa was weak, which caused a star to be removed. The place was a dive, which was fine, I was expecting that, The al Pastor was okay, not as good as I had imagined. Another star gone. La Taqueria Rifa! This place does not even come close. Its fine after several drinks, at that point it could be unfit for dogs let alone human consumption, but a drunk Yelper is gonna pop 5 stars on it 'cause its so cool...maybe I should not judge them by mere tacos, The burritos and quesadillas looked quite good, but we must have rules, otherwise ....chaos!
author: Jonathan R.

description:
It's an authentic hole-in-a-wall Mexican, honest to its nature and delivering authentic taste. I was hoping for some more when I ordered my burrito there - after all, I was after that insane taste of California burrito from San Diego from the time when I lived there. 

Too bad for me - the burrito was decent, but the carne asada was overcooked and lacked too much taste; spicy sauces were lacking and there was way too much rice in the burrito.

Overall it's a good place for a lunch, fairly affordable, but it's not worth going there if you are looking for a great, authentic burrito.
author: Andrei K.

description:
I recently went here. I got the vegetarian burrito w/o cheese & w/o sour cream for $8.69 including tax. I got my vegetarian burrito w/ rice, beans, onions, cilantro, salsa, & avocado. The burrito was massive & filling. It came w/ complimentary pico de gallo & salsa verde. It was a nice red & green Christmas presentation. The burrito was fine yet used a fair bit of the Tapatio Salsa Picante Hot Sauce on the table as preferred more heat. 

My favorite burrito in the Mission is still Papalote due to their extensive vegan burrito options yet Taqueria Cancun might be a close second. I came at the lunch hour on a weekend & was quite crowded. The line moved fast as you place your order & wait for your number to be called. The wall to the right of the kitchen as you walk in is filled w/ numerous awards won over the years by Taqueria Cancun. I enjoyed the solid burrito & the only caveat is it is a bit noisy.
author: Shane S.

description:
This place is a diet buster.  My super taco oozed with sour cream and deliciousness.  The chicken was tender, but I'm pretty sure because it was cooked in fatty juices.  That said, it was amazing!

When we stopped by last weekend, this place was absolutely packed.  We had to share a table with a few strangers after waiting in line for a while.  I had the super taco, which was enough for me, and my husband had the carne asada burrito, which was delicious.  The chips were yummy, although the salsas were deceptively spicy.  We should have ordered a side of guacamole.

A very affordable and delicious dinner!
author: Lauren M.

description:
Grossest burrito I have ever eaten in my life. I ordered a carne asada burrito after a night dancing at Bruno's. With drunchies in mind, we saw the crowded line and decided to snag a burrito to end our night. 

First off, this place is extremely dirty. There is no trash system so people leave food on the table and workers rarely came out to bus. 

Secondly, the burrito was nasty. I seriously have no idea why anyone would give this place a positive review. For one, it's tiny. It's not a filled burrito by any means, so you aren't getting your dollars worth. Plus I maybe had5 chunks of carne asada. Half way through I almost convinced myself I got a veggie burrito. Also the rice and beans were mushy, which made the experience even less satisfying. And the flavor was beyond bland.

I for one never like to waste food, but I could only finish half before leaving it to waste.

AVOID THIS PLACE.
author: Alan N.

description:
No Guacamole! I'm like what? Chips and salsa needs a lot of work. 

But Taqueria Cancun has the BEST wet burrito in SF!! Everyone said the meat need spices but my burrito was full of flavor. Plus you need to share, its HUGE. And those Chorizo tacos, yum! Super tasty.

Not my favorite in the city but it was delicious!
author: Sandy B.

description:
The "Mojado" is the standout dish here and the only burrito I've ever had to dissect with a knife and fork (Mojado means wet in Spanish and in the context of burritos means a burrito the size of a buff guys arm, nearly drowned in delicious sauce and smothered with cheese.) I also judge Mexican places' authenticity on whether they serve cabeza. Check. 

You also can't beat it for location if you're on your way to or from Dolores park. Just don't forget napkins. Oh, and cash. And be ready to dodge some pigeons on your way in/out.
author: Sophie C.

description: At such a low price of $6.50, Cancún's grilled chicken super burrito makes for a filling, satisfying, and cheap meal. It even comes with a free side of chips and salsa, which not all Mexican joints serve (even though they should). Among all the taquerias in the Mission, Cancún has the best chicken in my opinion. It's chewy, juicy, and comes in large chunks. However, I think that other parts of the burrito could use some work. The cooks are heavy-handed on the pinto beans and should grill the tortillas longer.
author: Miko B.

description:
Catch me here on the weekends for my 1:30am Super Quesadilla! Always a winner in my book and a solid pick me up when you want some mexican comfort food or just to soak up a night of Mission Bars :)

The salsa verde can be pretty spicy sometimes, especially with jalapenos on the nachos!!! The burrito is a good get with all the fixings but I prefer to go sans rice and beans on the quesadilla route. The best option is definitely the Carne Asada but a good second would be the Carnitas.
author: Nerissa C.

description:
Taqueria Cancun was my first experience eating in SF's Mission District, and it was good!

I ordered the carne asada burrito and my boyfriend got the carne asada torta. We're big carne asada fans (clearly) and we found both dishes to be very good! The portions were large (and fairly cheap), and the restaurant even gives chips and salsa with each order just in case you don't get totally filled up. Everything tasted so good that we managed to eat everything. This is definitely some of the best Mexican food I've had in the Bay Area.

My only real complaint was that the setting was a bit dirty. There were dishes/trays left at the tables and pigeons kept coming in from outside to perch right at our feet.
author: Julianna W.

description:
Had lunch here on the recommendation of a friend, it was cheap and filling and tasty!  But, there are better places close by.  

The line moves quickly here and the food is okay, just not amazing.
author: Victoria N.

description:
Cancun is the best for affordable, late night food (although they have got less affordable overtime, like everything else in the Bay Area). Plus they make the best quesadillas in the city, with a whole steak instead of strange pieces of meat mixed together. 

I would avoid the restrooms though.
author: Marta F.

description:
Being from San Diego everyone warned me off of even remotely trying any Mexican food in San Francisco. I do live in the Holy Grail of Carne Asada so why try it any where else right? Well I love Mexican food that much to see what all the stink was about here and I'll have to say I was actually pleasantly pleased. 

My cousin raved about El Farolito but we were pressed for time and this was closer to where we parked. Everyone else ordered a Super Taco but I am more of a burrito girl. You can never go wrong with a mobile handheld meal, so I ordered the Super Burrito. It was quite big so I was able to share the wealth with my bf as he also only got the taco. haha. Not only was the burrito and carne asada quite good but so was their salsa! What more do you need to please a Mexican food lover's taste buds? I also washed it down with a Corona. Trifecta or Perfecto.

The place looks dodgey and dingy but what good taco shop isn't?
author: Ivory R.

description: Outstanding. This definitely lived up to the hype. I got the al pastor super burrito, and my wife did the super burrito with carnitas. I thought the al pastor was better by a decent margin, but both were great. The basic components (meat, tortilla, etc) were all basically perfect, and the avocado in the middle really adds something to it. The chips and salsas that come with it were good, but not particularly noteworthy.
author: Shawn H.

description: The tacos al pastor are so good. Always make an effort to come here every time I'm in SF
author: Jessica S.

description:
Solid burrito. Great spicy salsa. I got the al pastor super burrito and it was pretty super. It was the perfect late night snack for me and had the perfect amount of sour cream that wasn't too bunched up in one place. The meat was also good and cooked well (as in cooked to the right texture and stuff, not well done). 

I thought the price was reasonable for the portion size too. It's kind of a tight squeeze and when I went people were coming in and out, so tables were opening up pretty quickly. 

My friends thought that this place is better than el farolito but I honestly don't remember how farolito tasted because it's been too long. Anyway, ya it's good.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
It had been almost 7 years in-between trips to Taqueria Cancun. During that time I've told friends, family and co-workers about this place and dreamed of the day I can get back.

I'll start this off right and get any other ideas out of your head: ORDER THE SUPER QUESADILLA. I stick to the chicken, but choose your protein with no fear. Cheesy, greasy, salty, spicy, messy... and huge. It's literally perfect and everything I want in a perfect quesadilla. Pair it with a Mexican Coke and you're all set.

Forget the rest of the menu, avoid the restrooms (trust me), and enjoy the presumed 1000+ calories.
author: Colin M.

description: One of the best breakfast burritos I've had in my life. The burritos are huge, so you might be able to split one with a friend.
author: Rachel Y.

description:
Do not go here! It is not a clean place. The day I went the most horrible thing happened. While I was waiting for our food, I saw a giant mouse (rat probably) climb down one of the poles and dive under the food serving station. Half the restaurant saw it and screamed. People freaked out and were asking for their money back. When I went to ask for my money, the cashier was on the phone taking in Spanish, probably to the manger, saying that "it happened again and everyone wants their money back." EW

We got our money back and left without trying anything. Please go somewhere else. There are plenty of clean burrito options in the Mission.
author: Diane R.

description:
Que delicioso!! Tried the alambres. They also give you some chips and salsa to start. This is definitely the late-night spot to go if you're craving some Mexican food after a night of dancing (hah...many a times I've hit up the Cancun). The alambres with carne asada are just ...juicy and hit the spot. Solid place in general and solid burritos as well. Try their different meats! (they have beef brains if you're into that too).

As I've been here mostly late at night, it's hard to catch a table (and the bathroom isn't always the cleanest). However, the service is fast and you'll get your hunger satisfied!
author: Natalie M.

description: Oh my God great service amazing tacos super cheap best place you can go to dine on a casual day or weekend we had couple tacos the beef was amazing we tried the carne Asada I would definitely come back
author: Aviad B.

description: I want to like this place, but there are so many better spots throughout the mission. It's conveniently located, but that's about it. The burritos are big but not necessarily the most flavorful. Your taco salads or without beans and have a less than satisfying tortilla bowl. The crust is heavy and moist instead of Crisp. I might stop up here again if nothing else is open, but there is always something else open in that area
author: David A R.

description:
It's the Mission. You need a burrito. Is Taqueria Cancun a worthy contender? The answer is yes. Everyone is stuck to their go-to Mission burrito (but that can change. Trust me. I've been converted.) but Taqueria Cancun is a place you need to check out to see if your soul burrito is here.

The need to knows are:
1. Cash only. But you should already know that.
2. Al pastor is the way to go here. And lengua.
3. Super everything. Burrito or taco, it's the right choice.
4. No lettuce anywhere. That's how you know it's real.
5. There is rice in the burrito. It is good.
6. It's a little cheaper than other spots.
7. The super burrito is most comparable to El Faro. 
8. No salsa bar.

It's a solid burrito. It's worth trying to decide if this is your burrito spot. I still have other favorites in the city (aka La Taqueria) but TC is worth a shot. You won't be disappointed.
author: Kathryn T.

description:
I really, really enjoy Taqueria Cancun. This place was suggested by a friend who is local and very well-versed in the various taquerias in the Mission. It did not disappoint. In fact, it was pretty much perfect, and thus deserving of 5 stars, IF you order the right item.

I chose my standard for trying out a new taqueria - super burrito with carne asada, hold the rice and sour cream. It was supremely on point, lightly grilled tortilla, fresh pico de gallo, melted cheese, and not guac but instead FRESH AVOCADO SLICES! I mean, seriously amazing value, not to mention that the chips & salsa were on point. Both salsas were pretty spicy, but I give the tip of my hat to the red one, which has a richer flavor and a tad more heat.

I really enjoy how at lunchtime, mariachi singers perform solo acts with their guitar, sometimes on rotation. Usually, each person sings a song or two, and then comes back for tips (but are never too pushy). The music really adds to the already authentic Mexican ambiance, which makes the food tastes even better!

5 stars due to taste, quality, ambiance, and affordability. It's cash only, but otherwise all you need to worry about is bringing a 100% empty stomach - the super burrito is truly huge! Keep up the good work, Taqueria Cancun!
author: Anish T.

description:
Taqueria Cancún is by far my favorite place to get tacos in the Mission! Their green salsa is my fave cause it's super spicy. 
This time I decided to try out one of their burritos and oh man..... let me just say, if your burrito doesn't weigh as much as a 3 month old baby, are you even doing it right???
author: Tricia Angela L.

description:
Food 4 stars: really good tacos. I had the carnitas, asada, al pastor, and chicken (and they were delicious in that order). The chips were a bit different because they tasted very grainy, but they were free and they came with some super spicy salsa.

Service 3 stars: pretty much a free for all. After I ordered, nobody checked my number when I went up to get my food. 

Ambiance 1 Star: hella homeless people. One guy actually came in and stole a half-eaten burrito off the table next to me (to his credit it was left behind, but still shocking nonetheless. Also cash only!!!!
author: Phat D.

description: I was tipped off about tYaqueria Cancun by a local while I was visiting San Francisco. It was worth the venture over to the Mission neighborhood. It was busy but service was quick. The burritos are delish. Everything is authentic. The burrito game is competitive in this city and I give Taqueria Cancun 5 stars all the way. If you live in San Fran you have probably already been here, if your visiting put it on your list, great lunch option while your site-seeing.
author: Ashlee B.

description:
This joint has great burritos. If you are on a trip to San Francisco and could only eat one burrito, it should be from Taqueria Cancún, Gordo's Taqueria, or La Taqueria.

When I think of a Mission burrito I typically think of a steamed tortilla, but Taqueria Cancún griddles them. Griddled tortillas can sometimes make a burrito difficult to eat vertically, but Cancún avoids this issue by being careful in their assembly and wrapping process. The pinto beans and pico de gallo are supporting players and shouldn't overpower, and Cancún does this right. If you've consumed other Mission burritos from respectable places, you know what I mean. The rice at Cancún is a bit mushy (but very flavorful), the cheese is perfect, and the slices of fresh avocado really help keep it fresh.

Taqueria Cancún's burrito is a great example of the whole being better than the sum of the parts. They slow-cook their meats. They don't over-engineer their supporting ingredients. They provide their customers with a handful of tortilla chips and salsas (red and green) for free.

Despite not using steamed tortillas, this is the burrito shop I most associate with the Mission. Cancún is a classic, they do things simple and right, and I leave satisfied and stuffed, regardless if I'm sober or drunk.

I will, however, get this inconvenient fact to my narrative out of the way: I HATE their Al Pastor burritos. They taste like pork in sloppy joe sauce, waaaay too sweet and ketchup-y. I come up to SF from San Diego, and we have a different idea about Al Pastor down there. If you've never had Al Pastor pork before in SD, just trust me.... it's better. 

But everything else from Cancún -- chicken, steak, and carnitas -- is consistently top-notch.

If not for the missteps on the Al Pastor, I'd be willing to say Cancún is the best burrito shop in the country. Alas, a bad burrito is harder to forget than a great burrito is to remember.

Still, this is my "go-to" burrito spot when I'm fortunate enough to be in San Francisco.

Food/Décor/Service: 4.5/2.2/NA
author: Jay K.

description:
Ordered the mojado. It's huge and a little spicy. It was good but I think a little overrated for the number of reviews this place has.

Pro-Tip: use the burrito's red sauce as salsa for the chips
author: Tom P.

description: Food was good, seating is limited as they were very busy. They only take cash, but have an atm inside.
author: Melissa A.

description:
Burrito mojado.  Holy cow.  Delicious and enormous.  I went with Carne Asada because I feel like I always need to go classic for the first time, but I was impressed with the fact that they had brains and tongue and head on the menu as well.  I'm kinda sad that I won't be back in San Fran anytime soon to try those out.

The sauces were fantastic, the meat was tender, and the service was quick.  Also the price can't be beat, despite the "cash only" crap that I hate so much.  Both the tomatillo salsa and pico we got with our chips were fantastic as well ... but beware, they're very spicy!
author: Alex T.

description:
I haven't been back here for a while so decided to give them a try again. Had a carne asada burrito and it was just OK. The meat didn't have enough flavor and lacked major juiciness. I had to keep dumping salsa in my every bite to make up for the lack of flavor and dryness. The tortilla was actually tastier than other places and I like that they freshly toast it. 

Here is the really bad part. I ordered a SUPER burrito but barely had any cheese at all! They were stingy on guac too. I mean is it what the SUPPER burrito is all about?!?

Also they messed up our order and gave us enchiladas when we ordered quesadilla.
author: Cartman P.

description: Not usually a burrito gal, but these are damn good and I ate the whole thing with joy. Carne Asada  authentic vibes! Would definitely recommend you put this place on your "places to eat" list!
author: Julie K.

description:
I've been here a few times after going out in the Mission and am just so thankful for this late night Mexican place. My intoxication may have skewed my judgment, but I truly feel like they don't forsake quality for efficiency and despite the fact that they're serving hoards of drunkards at 2am. 

We got there at 1:30am on a Saturday night and luckily there was a table open. The line moved pretty fast as well. We got the carne asada, which was tasty. I like that they give chips with your meal! They also have live music to boot! 

Keep doin you, Taqueria Cancun!
author: Emma W.

description:
Excellent food. I came to the Mission looking for delicious tacos and this is exactly what I got. I got the carne asada Super Taco and it definitely delivered. It was so full that I couldn't pick it up and had to get help from a fork. 

My boyfriend got the Super Burrito with chicken and was also very impressed. It was extremely large - would have been way too much food for me but perfect for him. We haven't tried many yet, but so far this was the best taco place we've been to in San Francisco.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Come hungry, this place will fill you up and leave you super satisfied. Smallish seating area, but nothings stoping you from grabbing a burrito and heading down to Mission Dolores Park. Mission has some tough Taqueria competition, and Taqueria Cancun is always a solid choice, especially if you find yourself out experiencing the Mission's nightlife scene (till 2am). 

BRING CASH
author: Dion L.

description: A Mission classic. Don't come for a soothing atmosphere or beautiful ambiance, but for the Mission burrito near its apex. Which is pretty close to food at its apex. The late-night scene is as wild as you'd expect.
author: Carl B.

description: We came here for the burritos. The super burritos are as good as the other yelp reviews claim. I would definitely come here when I'm in the Mission. Parking is a b and they're cash only.
author: Tammy S.

description:
Super taco. 3.75 no regrets.

Everything about this place is amazing . Just get it all! Hey give you some chips and dip too for free. Deeeelicious!!!
author: Jacqui L.

description: The veggie burrito is really good! Would highly recommend! The salsa verde is amazing
author: Chelsey S.

description:
So I had originally been to the other location and wasn't impressed but this one blew my mind and I wasn't even drunk.

First of all, get here before last call for bars and you're guaranteed to get your burrito in a timely manner. Secondly, you should really be here to order a burrito. Yes, there is a menu with other items on it. But for goodness sakes, you're in San Francisco at Taqueria Cancun, you're getting a freaggin burrito.

Remember, this place is cash only. But you were in the Mission earlier where half the bars are cash only, so I hope you were prepared. 

I always go with the super burrito and was actually super stoked that they have good chicken here! Also, I am a bigggg fan of their salsa (especially the green). But that baby on your burrito.
author: Arezou A.

description: Not much to say other than insanely great burritos. Cash only. Cute little spot in the mission.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Pretty legit, typical hole in the wall with amazing standard Mexican food.  I had a torta with al pastor, it also had avocado, beans, sour cream, tomatoes and the bread was toasted.  They also give you chips and salsa which makes waiting for your food easier.  Prices are pretty average even though the regular tacos are a little overpriced for a hole in the wall.

However I cant complain the torta was not soggy, didn't get all over me and was , great for a quick bite.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
I got the carne asada specialty plate and wasn't super impressed by the overall experience. 

- Salsa is pretty spicy, so watch out. Some people probably love this but my partner and I couldn't stomach it without some water. 

- Carne asada isn't sliced and they only have flimsy plastic forks and knives, which means you're going to need to dig in with your hands. 

- Lots of drunk people late at night. Experienced a guy slouching into a minor fall that pushed food all over the floor. Not really the restaurant's fault. But know what you're getting yourself into if eating in. 

- Might have been a busy night, but tables weren't being bussed very well when we arrived, which makes for a pretty poor experience eating in because there aren't any clean spaces to sit and eat. 

I lived right next to the mission, so I can appreciate a dive as much as the next guy, but I would save my business for a different type of experience. 

Burritos are huge, though. If you're eating out, might be right up your alley. Also the carne asada had nice flavor.
author: Andrew G.

description:
CASH ONLY - I never bring cash, so wanted to point this out.

They give you some tortilla chips and salsa/guac while you wait for your food. The carne asada super burrito was the right move to make. It's a good sizes burrito for an affordable price. However, I was disappointed in some of the ingredients (or lack thereof). The menu clearly said there was sour cream in the super burrito, but I could not find it. For me, eating a burrito without sour cream is like eating an omelette without salsa--it's just not the same! As a result the burrito tasted a little dry :/ 

There's a slew of other taco and burrito spots that I prefer over this place.
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Came here with a bunch of friends on a Friday night and was surprised that there wasn't a line! Lots of table space and food on par with La Tacqueria and El Farolito. So basically solid food, cheap prices and not super crowded - what's not to like?

I ordered a super quesadilla al pastor and really enjoyed it!
author: Lauren C.

description: Taqueria Cancun is one of the better tacquerias in the Mission. Beware that it is CASH ONLY, just like almost all of the other tacquerias. With that being said, there is a ATM inside, and the portions are huge. Really affordable, authentic, and popular place. You almost always have to wait for a place to sit, and there is almost always a line. If you are looking for late night, authentic, and a little bit grundgy Mexican food, look no further.
author: Ross S.

description:
I had the carne asada (steak) burrito and my friend had the pollo (chicken) burrito. They were both fantastic. The rice is extremely flavorful, the meat juicy and delicious, and the beans and sauces combine to create what is probably the best burrito I've ever had (and yes, I've been to La Taqueria). 

This is now definitely my go to burrito place in SF. The burritos are better than those at La Taqueria, and there is almost no line. All in all you'll have your food in 5 or so minutes. Fantastic place.
author: Sherif N.

description:
Got the burrito mojado, finished half, was very full but very unsatisfied, and concluded that I should stick to tacos for life. asdfjk;

It looked great in pictures, the pricing was not bad at under $10 with complimentary tortilla chips and salsa (tortilla chips tasted fresh and house-made), and I noticed it featured as the burrito for those with a hungry appetite. Sounded spectacular and unfortunately turned out disappointing, at least in my opinion. 

I know I shouldn't order a wet burrito and expect it not to be wet, but the tomato sauce was quite watered-down. With the tomato sauce puddle and the overwhelming amounts of melted cheese, the flavor profile seemed closer to lasagna. I hate to be such a downer, but my rant goes on: the guacamole was minimal and diluted, and the al pastor was bland and scant--the interior was mostly stuffed with beans and rice, so fishing around for pieces of pork required more patience than a treasure hunt.

The redeeming factors are 1) the thought that this may be tasty if I had massive drunchies after partying too hard, and 2) that the lively, colorful ambiance is nice to dine in. I've had a wet burrito before in a not-very-authentic taqueria in South Bay and enjoyed it. Maybe my tastes for Mexican food are so bogus it's with the ranks of Panda Express fans. But to be fair, wet burritos aren't even genuinely Mexican in the first place...
author: Edna C.

description:
Everybody has their favorite burrito spot in the Mission. I'm an El Farolito guy, and I swear by the grime on their tables that they have the juiciest burrito in all of Mission. So I was startled, and even slightly offended, when Vegg Mosby comes out to say that Taqueria Cancun is the best place for burrito. 

As you may remember from my previous reviews, Vegg Mosby is a kind of vegan variant. So whenever he says there's a good restaurant, I have to take it with a grain of salt and a packet of MSG. Let's be real, Vegg has never even had Korean BBQ before, how credible could he be when it comes to food?

"Alright, fine fine fine. We'll go to Cancun. I bet it just tastes like some whack vegan joint, but I'll go with you cause I'm a good friend."

When I finally sat down with my go-to burrito (Al Pastor, no sour cream, extra cheese), I had to admit that I was pleased with the price. Eight dollars and some chump change for a super burrito AND chips. This could be good. And so I took my first bite.

Wow. 

The tortilla was toasted so there was a little snap of crunch for each bite. The Al Pastor was as juicy and greasy in just the right way. The taste was further bolstered by a generous helping of onions and cilantro and a healthy helping of beans for the texture. And finally, there were these avocado slices hiding inside that added a divinely refreshing touch on an already heavenly burrito.

I quickly realized that I was eating my words faster than I was the burrito. Taqueria Cancun was legit, and Vegg Mosby deserved an apology.

"Aye man, sorry for discrediting your taste in food just because you're some sort of vegan. I'm gonna have to say that Cancun is just as good as El Farolito."

"It's alright, man. I know a few other vegan joints, too. We should go together sometime."

See, that's why you gotta love Vegg Mosby. He thinks just because he scored ONCE with Taqueria Cancun I'm gonna start listening to him for food choices. How naive, lol.
author: Ringo M.

description: I drive to California just to eat burritos here. I don't know what it is. It's honestly not like it's the best burrito on earth (even though they're really good) but the food and the vibe and everything about it just makes me happy. Go and you'll see.
author: Ted W.

description:
Are you nostalgic? I'm a nostalgic person, in the sense that I try not to resent the passage of time but end up doing so anyway, at least a little bit. I find writing Yelp reviews pretty natural because I take so many pictures of my food and the friends I eat it with, only to look back and pinpoint specific moments when I was particularly happy or sad.

Thinking about Cancun makes me nostalgic because it's been a staple of my diet since I first came to SF last summer. It's right beside Mission Control, a house I've spent so much time at during the past year, and I associate it with so many different things: late night chats with friends after leaving a club or bar, ducking out the house at 1 AM to satisfy burrito cravings, mid-afternoon snack breaks after hanging out at Dolo. Cancun's carried me through a few friendships and several hazy summer nights. I always get the veggie burrito, which is delicious and probably results in an instant three pound weight gain. The place itself is not exactly what I'd describe as hygenic, but I've gotten used to it. 

(Today in Ava-gets-sentimental-over-burritos)
author: Ava H.

description: My favorite taqueria in the Mission (and I've tried quite a few!) The super burrito here is to die for. I always go for carnitas but any of the meats are great. Their salsas are also amazing - I love the verde which is creamy with avocado and jalapeño.  The staff is very friendly.  One guy was making fresh carrot juice and I asked what it was for and he gave me an entire cup full! Always my go to when I'm in the area or visitors are in town. It is cash only I believe.
author: Alexandra L.

description:
First time I came here was in January 2015. I loved my Al pastor burrito and I remember it being hands down one of the best burritos I've ever had. I vowed that I would come back again next time I was in San Francisco.

Fast forward to yesterday, August 2017, and it was not the same quality. While the burrito I had last night was alright, it wasn't anything memorable. They definitely skimped on the meat, filling most of the burrito with beans and rice.

The atmosphere is fun. All of the people who work here are nice, but the food honestly just doesn't hold up anymore.
author: C. Anna O.

description: Your typical mission taco environment BUT - the tacos are amaze! I love the colorful ceiling. It's definitely busy even late on a Monday.
author: Candice N.

description: Best burrito hands down in the city. Consistency is key with taquerias and they definitely have that. Nice quesadilla to.
author: Abdul C.

description:
The super tacos are bomb as hell. Huge dollop of sour cream and avocado slice on there! Fav meat is al pastor! Order at the counter, take a ticket, wait for them to call it out. 
Not a nice interior, but tasty tacos. Can't complain.
author: Anmy V.

description: One of the better burrito joints in the mission.  Prices in this area are generally increasing and burritos now are a whopping $9 usd.  We had the chorizo scramble with decried beans and rice.
author: Erika R.

description: Excellent tacos!  The pollo was well seasoned and perfect with their green salsa.. the chorizo was also excellent, a little salty but great with a Modelo.  Perfect quick lunch spot in the Mission.
author: Sean L.

description: Coming from San Diego I have high expectations for Mexican food. Everything I'd had in Berkeley was either eh or just okay. But this place was my first decent authentic Mexican meal in the Bay. My girlfriend got a burrito de carne asada and I got a torta de carne asada. Her burrito was pretty good . I usually don't have rice in my burritos, but the rice in her burrito was pretty tasty. My torta was really really good though. It was big and stuffed with lots of things and super greasy, just like the tortas I eat in San Diego and TJ. It reminded me of a really good torta I had in TJ. It had tons of queso, frijoles, carne asada, guac, mayo on the telera, and more. The chips and salsa that came with my order were free and pretty good too! Prices are decent too, a lot cheaper than in Berkeley, but not quite as cheap as SD/TJ. I can't speak for their other food, but the torta was great.
author: Kevin D.

description:
San Francisco has the best Mexican food and this place proves it. We got the smothered wet burrito and enchiladas. Both were so amazing. The wet burrito was huge and had a spicy guacamole/jalapeño sauce on it which added so much to the flavor. It was also covered with two other sauces which were excellent. It's safe to say that people come to this joint just to eat the wet burritos. The enchiladas were also amazing and huge. We got these two dishes and split it amongst three people and we were all so full by the end of it. They also give you chips and salsa and that green sauce before your meal comes out. So delicious!!

When you walk into the place it looks like a fast food area and a late night joint. The lines are always ridiculously long and that is the only downside about this place that it does require that you wait at least 15 minutes in the line. but all the waiting is worth it and I would def recommend checking out this spot if you're in San Francisco. It's pretty safe to say that San Fran kills New York City in Mexican food.
author: Sejal B.

description: I got the burrito mojado (tip: it's huge!!) with al pastor and it was amazing! So much flavor in the al pastor and everything blended together very well! One of the best meals in the area - definitely recommend!
author: Aakriti P.

description:
It's with much sadness that I report getting a really severe case of (sea?) food poisoning on Monday after a delicious Tostada de Ceviche and carne asada taco. I've been horribly ill for two days. 

https://www.yelp.com/inspections/taqueria-cancun-san-francisco-5 suggests they really aren't taking food safety regulations seriously enough.
author: Matthew E.

description:
So you know you've got it bad when you wake up the next day craving the food from last night, then proceed to think about it all weekend long until you get your fix. And that's what this place does to me. 

It's possible that my late night binge partying could have had something to do with my fixation, but I digress. And yea, this was just a "burrito", but it was an amazing burrito with a great flavor combination! Everything just worked: it wasn't too dry, wasn't too wet, and the ingredients were put together in the right way to ensure maximum satisfaction. 

The only thing I don't quite like is that I'm not able to see my food made. And I'm a picky eater, so I like looking to see that what I order is exactly what I order (and nothing extra is added in). But alas, this world isn't perfect, and that's a small price to pay for some good (cheap) eats.

Likes:
-flavorful
-cheap eats
-fast and convenient 
-late night hours

Dislikes:
-definitely not your 5-star burrito place, but those aren't any good anyways
-can't watch food being made (it's covered up in a yellow partition)
-cash only (but they make up for it by having an ATM on-site
author: Tracy T.

description: Awesome prawn burrito (which is also extra huugge!) and shrimp cocktail but the cantaloupe drink is to die for (a must get drink!!)
author: Ellie W.

description: Taqueria Cancun never lets me down.  Great burritos and tacos.  Must have when ever I'm in the area.
author: L J.

description:
One of the best burritos I've ever had!
The place is very authentic, offering free great chips and different salsa dipping. Highly recommended for late night food for a after going out!
author: Nir B.

description:
Look. It's hard not to compare a burrito against another burrito but, let's face it, you can't help it. The carne asada burrito at Taqueria Cancún is good. Is it great? Not particualrly. A contender for the top 25 in San Francisco? Possibly. 

What I think makes a great burrito is the tortilla. It's quite possibly the most important component of Mexican food and without a good one, you're already at a disadvantage. Taqueria Cancun's tortilla is a bit more flaky and dry than most and something I'm not used to. Bring on the lard homie! 

The carne asada burrito as a whole was a bit dry and lacked the "wow" factor. The rice was excellent, and the salsas were solid. I think next time I should ask for refried beans instead of the standard pinto to help make the experience a bit more "juicy". Another huge factor that played into my 3 star rating was because of the chips. You've GOTTA be making these in house if you're a taqueria. It's standard operation for most. 

If you're in the Mission and the lines at El Farlito and La Taq are too long, it's a solid option. Otherwise, I'd say there are plenty better in the neighborhood.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
The reviews are spot-on. It's a cash only dive that has authentic food and a fun atmosphere.

Some notes:
1. Good burritos that aren't rice bombs, well balanced filling
2. Taco salad was also good, tortilla shell wasn't too greasy and the chicken was seasoned nicely

Final Remarks:
This place is located in a local, gritty neighborhood that is fun to wander if you're looking for a chance to get a real taste of SF.
author: Lucy G.

description:
My kid and I are on a mission (pardon the pun) to try every 538 burrito bracket joint in the Bay Area. We've been to a few (actually many) and while Taqueria Cancun is good, it's not as great as some of it's rivals down the street.

We had a carne asada burrito (regular). It was steaming hot which is great. The tortilla was soft but wasn't grilled which I prefer. The meat was very plentiful but lacked a punch of flavor and crispiness (I prefer when the meat has just a bit of crunchiness on the outside). And though we ordered medium spicy - there was no kick at all. In fact, I had to ask for more salsa (which was AMAZEBALLS) for finish the burrito.

Unlike many other places, Taqueria Cancun does not have a salsa bar. It's kinda nice not to see other peoples grubby hands all over the salsa ladles, but it's a bummer that there were more of the delicious salsa to be had. There were two types offered - one red (tomato) and one green (avocado). Both were INCREDIBLE and very very HOT.

We also had two tacos - one carne asada and one chicken. They were HUGE with piles and piles of meat. seriously, it was a little insane the amount of meat. But again, it lacked flavor and punch and frankly just a tad dry (perhaps due to a lack of salsa). With the salsa added on top, it was much better.

It was a fine establishment - efficient... but I'd prefer to walk down the street.
author: Madison W.

description:
I was sorely let down by Taqueria Cancun's burrito, which I ordered with both carne asada and al pastor. Both of these items are touted highly in the reviews as being great, but in my opinion, neither of them lived up to El Farolito. 

On a whim as I was ordering my burrito, I also added a side quesadilla with chorizo to share with everyone else. I'm so glad I did because it was amazing. The chorizo was so oily and so delicious that I consider it the best I've had so far in the city.

Overall, I plan on coming back here and having more of the fat laden goodness that is Cancun's chorizo, possibly in burrito form, possibly in another quesadilla, or maybe just by itself on a plate. Either way, this is "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description: Amazing little taqueria! My girlfriend is vegan and she got a huge veggie burrito without cheese and sour cream and she loved it! They gave us complimentary chips/salsa and a bolero performed beautiful ballads in the restaurant. The staff was very nice and we received our orders within 5 minutes. Great stop for lunch! Definitely will be back!
author: Justin G.

description: This is my second favorite burrito in the Bay Area after La Taqueria. I always get the Carnitas Super El Dorado with light rice. It's heavenly. And huge. Their salsa here is spicy which is awesome. Chips are also included which is great. Definitely check it out if you're a burrito fan.
author: Aakash G.

description:
For my 200th Review, I've going to compare Taqueria Cancun here to the mighty El Farolito and La Taqueria. The Super-burrito is what I will base the following ratings on.

Price:
TC: 5
EF: 5
LT: 3
Cancun and Farolito have the same prices but you get free small chips from Cancun! La Taq is the most expensive out of the 3.

Quantity:
TC: 5
EF: 5
LT: 3
Cancun and Farolito both stuff your burrito full of goodies and "not-legit" stuffings and so your burrito is HUGE. Meanwhile, La Taq has the smallest burrito out of the 3.

Quality of ingredients:
TC: 5
EF: 5
LT: 5
Nothing to compare here, as they're all so busy that their meats and fillings are fresh.

The Tortilla:
TC: 5
EF: 4
LT: 4
Here is where Cancun shines, they use a fluffy tortilla which makes the burrito even more delicious! Farolito and La Taq both use standard tortilla wrap.

Flavor:
TC: 4
EF: 4
LT: 5
This is one of the most important categories where La Taqueria wins at. Their super burrito is very wet and juicy. However, Cancun and El Faro aren't far behind. Because of the beans and rice in their burritos, they might be a little more dry, but nothing a little green sauce won't fix!

Cleanliness:
TC: 4
EF: 2
LT: 4
Cancun and La Taq are both fairly clean, thought you gotta give credit to La Taq to be able to keep their store clean which so much foot traffic. Unfortunately, El Faro is the loser in this category, they're the smallest space which I guess makes it harder to clean with all their business.

Hours:
TC: 4
EF: 5
LT: 3
Cancun is open pretty much until 2am, but closed on Tuesdays. However, El Faro is always open til 3:30am! La Taq doesn't seem to want to make more money as they close very early.

Location:
TC: 5
EF: 5
LT: 4
Cancun and El Faro are both on mission near all the bars and restaurants while La Taq is a block farther, but a block farther into nothingness (until you pass cesar chavez). And don't forget, El Faro has more than 1 location in SF!

Average score:
TC: 4.625
EF: 4.375
LT: 3.875

AND WE HAVE A WINNER!!! DING DING DING!
Taqueria Cancun is the WINNER!

Judges:
Stomach (quantity, quality, cleanliness, tortilla)
Tongue (flavor, tortilla, quality)
Wallet (price, quantity)
Legs (location, hour)
author: Da X.

description:
OMG. OMFG. 

I met my introvert buddy TK for a little bit of nom noms and drinky drinks and we decided to eat here because we kept hearing the food was amazing. 

And let me tell you... it was amazing. 

She order some tacos and I had a torta al pastor. It was heaven. I mean, if heaven had delicious al pastor meat ready to be served in all kinds of ways. The sour cream, the salsa, the melted cheese, all combined to take me on a tour of delicious flavors that has become unforgettable. 

Sure, there was a guy on the next table with 5 beers by himself listening to some corridos on his phone, but that just added to the whole ambiance of the place. 

Definitely going back for more.
author: Ezekiel G.

description: Oh yesssssssss. Get the burrito mojado. It will change your life. Spicy, saucy, and jam packed with meat, rice, and beans...we ate the entire thing and didn't regret a second of it.
author: Sarah M.

description: I've been coming here almost once a week for a few years now. If you order a single veggie taco they typically throw a ton of beans on there and you get a ton of food for a great value. Friendly vibe here too, especially this guy named Ever who works behind the register most days
author: Ezra B.

description:
This is probably my most frequented stop for burritos in the Mission. It's a nice ~2 block walking distance from the 16th Mission BART, but even closer for me.

One of the cheapest, and largest burritos I've sampled in my time exploring the Mission. Complimentary chips and dip with orders (even comes nicely packaged if you order it to-go like I do). Personally, I'm a big fan of putting the salsa on my actual burrito but others may do differently. Both of the sauces have a nice spice to it.

Of the dishes I've ordered here, it has mainly been the super burrito. Haven't had one complaint about it, and I've tried it with about 75% of the meat options. I've also had the quesadilla, which was great but I think I'm just a burrito sort of dude.

Having seen friends order the tacos, that's definitely next on my list! Pro-tip: If you go late at night, sometimes you might find a guy playing guitar in between the tables. Cash only, like most places in the mission.
author: Rajeev S.

description: Fast service, have never experienced a bad taco or stale avocado in 3 years. Very spoilt to have this so accessible to me
author: Zuki G.

description:
After a night out with some friends in the Mission, Taqueria Cancun was the perfect option for a great late night meal! 

STEP ONE: 
Walk into a festive and brightly colored decor taqueria.

STEP TWO:
Wait in a line for 5-10 minutes on busy Friday/Saturday nights.

STEP THREE: 
Have your order ready, because at the end of the first leg of the line there is a man who will take your order.

STEP FOUR: 
Continue to the second leg of the line and pay for your meal. (Note: The man at the cashier has mad skills and quickly works the register!)

STEP FIVE:
Within 2 minutes, your order will come in a paper bag with not only your taco/burrito, but also CHIPS and salsa. (Note: Free chips? That's rare at any taqueria in SF.)

STEP SIX:
Devour that Mexican amaziness and never look back! (Note: Order the SUPER SHRIMP BURRITO)

STEP SEVEN:
Say goodbye to your fantasy meal in Cancun and enter the streets of San Francisco. 

I hope you enjoyed my SEVEN STEP list for success at Taqueria Cancun. 

Adios Amigos!
author: Briana H.

description:
I don't know about this. I seldom order a burrito, so I feel like I have to write a disclaimer that this is only for tacos, and they're damn good. But if Taqueria Cancún wins for the best burrito, I must say that El Faralito's tacos are better. 

This is dumb. We are splitting teeny tiny hairs. You can't go wrong with whatever you order. You're in a city with some bomb ass Mexican food. GO NUTS.
