I had the chorizo and beef tacos. I'm an al pastor fan, but my partner and I accidentally switched to which I had zero complaints.
author: Priti K.

description:
I used to live across the street from Taqueria Cancun. Moving away was the healthiest decision I've made in a long time.

Cancun is great. I've tried a lot of burritos in the city but Cancun's is my favorite. I'll say it to anyone who will listen: Taqueria Cancun has the best burrito in San Francisco. I always get super carnitas -- the pork is so flavorful and not too dry (but not too greasy either!) The chips and salsa are damn good, too.

And yeah -- they're open late. Perfect for a late night meal. Also perfect for a Dolores Park lunch. 

Their only problem is that they're always closed on Tuesdays.
author: Trevor B.

description: Wow. Best drunchie experience I've had probably since college. Get some cash, get in line, and just wait for the awesomeness to happen. Super burrito for the win.
author: Lauren J.

description: This is my favorite Mexican restaurant to come to when I'm in the Mission (which is a big statement because the Mission is famous for their amazing food). I personally order the vegetarian tacos and am amazed that a veggie taco can have that amount of flavor in it.
author: Sydney G.

description:
The Mission is known for its incredible Mexican food, so every taqueria in the area is ridiculously amazing, right? Right?? Well, the grilled chicken regular burrito ($7) I ordered at Taqueria Cancún ranks far behind some of the best burritos I've had in the Mission. It tasted bland, and quite frankly, average. Nothing about it stood out and I felt like I was eating something I could have made at home or gotten at any other ordinary taqueria.

Despite the taste of the burrito being not very memorable, the size was generous, especially for a "regular" burrito. They also threw in chips for free and the restaurant is pretty spacious so there is plenty of seating inside. Cash only. 

As I was reading other reviews, people tend to like the tacos here. If you are a burrito snob like I am, skip them here and walk a block or two elsewhere. There are plenty of better burrito options in the area.
author: Jordan H.

description: Got sick twice at this place. Unless you want to get sick do not go there. Cashier with cheap diamond earring does not have any customer service matters.
author: Monique M.

description: A consistent burrito which offer little risk that others might. Just wish they had a bit more cheese in the super burritos.
author: Timothy B.

description:
Both my Uber driver and my friend suggested that I try a Mission burrito during my time in SF and boy am I happy I did! Coming from Texas, I've had my share of burritos, so imagine my surprise when I found a burrito that tasted even better than something I've had at home! 

Filled with steak, guacamole, rice, beans, lettuce all wrapped in a warm tortilla, the steak burrito is to die for. They also have two different types of salsas. The red one is a bit spicier than the green one, but both taste good as a dip and as a dressing for the burrito. Their chips were not like the typical crunchy tortilla chips. They were a bit thicker and had great flavor. 

We went around 2PM on a Saturday and there wasn't a line, but I heard this place gets lit at night with people who have drunkchies :P
author: Cathy S.

description: As a burrito aficionado I think this place was just okay. I didn't feel like the burrito ingredients had much flavor. I appreciated the free chips with salsas but found myself wanting more salsa because my burrito was dry. I wish they had a salsa bar so I could get more at will.
author: Jenine G.

description: Got a chance to check it out for lunch and it was amazing.  The chicken burrito is very tasty.  Definitely planning on returning! 8/10
author: Daymond D.

description:
Rainy day in the Mission.. actually any day in the Mission makes me crave a Mission burrito. I'm a huge fan of the burrito from La Taqueria but my friends raved about Cancun, so I had to try it! 

Cancun is close to 16th street Bart and easy to find if you're walking around the Mission w/ their bright yellow sign. Even though it was pouring rain on the day I came, the restaurant was packed. Cancun has a standard menu of any taqueria. They're fast, and the food comes out piping hot. Perfect for a fast meal that you want to take to go, or if you're starving. I ordered a carne asada burrito (regular comes with rice, beans, salsa, and your choice of protein; the super burrito comes with rice, beans, salsa, choice of protein, cheese, avocado, and sour cream). The burrito also comes with free chips that you can also take with your to go order, or if you eat in. I recommend asking for extra green sauce to go with your burrito, its extra spicy and adds that perfect kick. I do like that they also add regular salsa for your chips. 

I still like La Taqueria better because they have a larger focus on meat (they dont have rice in their burritos) but Cancun is definitely a great alternative. Plus points for their fancy, colorful decor and friendly staff.
author: Annie L.

description: It was a late Saturday night and we came here for post drink food. I ordered 2 tacoes and they were sooooooooo good. Probably one of the best tacoes I had since moving to the bay area. A great place to go after getting a couple drinks in the mission.
author: Galen W.

description:
Okay I admit, I've never been here sober, but this place is AMAZING after those kind of nights.

For me, the free chips and salsa with every order are just okay. But they're free and keep me more patient for my tacos, so no complaints!

Super tacos are my go-to for the actual order. Your choice of meat, plus onions, cilantro, sour cream, salsa, and generous slices/chunks of avocado. SO GOOD. Just describing them is making me salivate T_T 

Skip the burritos. Get the super tacos.
author: Sara L.

description:
This place is a bit of a hot mess (half-empty plates and glasses everywhere due to infrequent bussing of the tables, super crowded) but that doesn't mean the food isn't good. It's good. And coming from a New Yorker, it is CHEAP. $7+ for a massive burrito covered in salsa? $7 for an al pastor super quesadilla that was basically two normal sized quesadillas? Yes, please!

There's been plenty said already so here's my take: Super busy, fun to watch the burrito-wrapping experts, kinda dirty but dirt cheap, humongous portions, tasty food. You won't regret it.
author: Su-Yee L.

description:
What happened to this place? Was today the first time I came here sober? I don't think so.

The food was just bad. The meat was fatty and grisly, both the carne asada and al pastor. Just tons of ligaments and fat chunks in almost every bite. The bathroom is one of the nastiest smelly ones I've been to in a while and the lack of hygiene there didn't exactly instill a vote of confidence. 

I used to think this was a legit taqueria but I won't be back after today.
author: Nina M.

description: Probably the third best burrito place on Mission street. A late night favorite among locals, check this place out if you are in the mood for some great Mexican food. Never been here before? Go for the Carne Asada Super Burrito. Looking for something special? Try the nachos!
author: Derek J.

description:
Came here for a late night snack and it hits the spot. I don't even like mexican food, but I was a fan of the al pastor super burrito that I got at the suggestion of my friend. The meat was marinated and flavorful, and they do not skimp out on the ingredients. The burrito that I got for ~$10 was as big as my face and lasted me two large meals. because it's so big though, I had to do the good ol' bite on the left and bite on the right to get meat and bean in the same bite. 

The restaurant isn't the most spacious place, but who needs that when you're getting a burrito. You get free chips and salsa, but cash only. Dont underestimate the salsa.
author: Grace P.

description: Are you kidding me!? I ordered 5 tacos - 2 al pastor, 2 asada, 1 chorizo. I got 3 tacos - 1 al pastor, 2 carnitas. Seriously how do you mess up such a simple order. It's cash only and $3.25 a taco. Will not be going back here or recommending to anyone
author: Kyle L.

description: Best burrito I've ever had and I've had a lot of burritos. The tortilla is handmade which goes a long way. I got the el pastor super burrito, which I  highly recommend. There are some interesting folks outside the restaurant but what do you expect....and I think it's worth it.
author: Terese O.

description:
As an Angeleno with a constant craving for tacos, I was pretty excited to get some Mexican food in the Mission. I met a friend at Taqueria Cancun for a weekday lunch, and ordered up a trio of tacos. I enjoyed the place, and the food was fine, but I wasn't terribly impressed. Cancun couldn't hold its own against the tacos I have at home on the regular.

The space was fun, casual and cheerfully decorated, with a kind of effortless appeal and easy atmosphere that marked it as pre-tech boom Mission. Service was quick and friendly. We ordered at the cashier, paid up (cash only), and waited for our numbers to be called. Seating was plentiful.

The complimentary chips and salsa were pretty great--crunchy, fresh tortilla chips and chunky,  flavorful red and green salsas. I ordered three tacos, a super taco with carne asada, and two regular tacos, al pastor and cabeza. All three came on soft tortillas with onions, cilantro, and salsa; the super added cheese, avocado, and sour cream. I was definitely into that super taco, and I enjoyed both the carne asada and the al pastor. The cabeza was kind of gross--definitely the squishy, mushy side of the cabeza spectrum, so I wouldn't recommend it if you only like cabeza half the time (I feel like I had a good cabeza run until Cancun, so I guess I was feeling lucky). I also just didn't find anything special about the tortillas or the quality/flavor of the meat. It all tasted good enough, but I wouldn't go out of my way for it.

I'll have to try some more Mexican food next time I visit the Mission. I liked my lunch at Taqueria Cancun, but it didn't step up as a San Francisco taco champion. I can think of a half dozen Los Angeles taquerias off the top of my head that would blow this place out of the water.
author: Steph C.

description: Hands down my favorite place to get a burrito in the mission. This place has the best carnitas and I love that they are so nice and their food tastes so authentic. Being cash only doesn't ever deter me from stopping by this place to pick up a carnitas burrito on my way to Dolores park!
author: April Z.

description:
Never again will I go eat here. Gave it a try again after I couldn't make it to El Farolito because they are usually busy and had to get home. 

Cancun had no lines. Fine. Ordered 3 super burritos. Paid $29 (btw, 3 at El Farolito cost under $25).

Bagged and went home. Took out the burritos. All 3 burritos came out different sizes. The smallest came to about 6".  The largest was probably 7.5". Either way, the worse ever. My 4 and 2 year old split and finished one on their own. That's how small it was. 

Also, what's in their super burrito??? Avocado?  Nope. What the hell did I pay in a super burrito?

Never again!  I'd rather lose an extra 20 minutes of my life in line at El Farolito than to come back here.
author: Tony And Candace T.

description:
Went here for late night burritos last night and man was that a great decision. I am pretty boring with my burrito order in that I always end up ordering a carne asada super burrito but i cant help it, they're always just so freakin' good and this instance was not any different.

I have heard about this place many times before so it was great to finally try it out for myself. The burrito itself was a good size, just enough for late night (maybe a little more than I should've had) but you can't not finish it, am i right? 

Never regret the late night burrito.
author: Ilana B.

description: This place is THE BOMB. Go to spot after a late night out.. or just to grab some delicious Mexican food. The super quesadilla is delicious-- with chunks of avocado, pico de gallo and sour cream all inside. No need for hot sauce, it tastes amazing by itself. Wish they had something like this in Orange County
author: Quynh Nhu N.

description: Delicious burritos! The only thing that wasn't that great was that they only take cash. My husband & I both got carne asada burritos- SUPER good! Definitely happy we found this place!
author: michelle p.

description:
The verdict: El Farolito definitely has better food. 

But Taqueria Cancun has its redeeming qualities too. It's a LOT cleaner and you get complimentary chips, but when it comes down to it, it's the food that's the most important imo! We ordered a wet burrito with al pastor and a plate of alambres. The wet burrito was forgettable, the taste of the sauce overpowered the insides of the burrito. The alambres were good but the tortillas that came with them were dry. We talked to a nice man while we were waiting for the restaurant to open (they opened 30 min after the posted hours) and he said that he comes all the way from Oakland to eat these alambres because nowhere else serves them, so of course we had to order a plate. All in all, I think the food is decent but with so many other options in the Mission, I would go somewhere else next time.
author: Selena S.

description:
Crazy crowded taqueria on Mission street

Damn this place is packed. The inside is small, there are never enough seats, and sometimes guitar/musicians would come in and play, which leaves essentially no room for standing!

This is one of the 2 Taqueria Cancun places in the Mission district, the other one being in Bernal Heights. The decor is very similar, with colorful flags on the ceiling. The food is also similar as well, with crazy giant burritos that taste ok. The breakfast platter I ordered was pretty neat--I've never had scrambled eggs served with beans and piping hot tortillas. The portions are pretty big as well.

Definitely a good place to visit if you're looking for Mexican food in large portions.
author: Henry L.

description: Taqueria Cancun is bomb af. Although I didn't really order anything spontaneous. The burrito I got with the al pastor was so flavorful. Every bite was delicious! Well worth it. Definitely eat here if you're a pastor lover lol you'll be absolutely satisfied.
author: Saucy M.

description:
This probably ranks at the top of my favorite Mexican joints list in the Mission (El Farolito being my #1 of course). 

I ordered the carne asada regular burrito with black beans (~$6.50) and a cantelope agua fresca ($1.80). All orders come with a side of chips and 2 salsas (green & red). There were pepper seeds in my burrito and because I'm not a fan of spicy I had to pick them out myself.. Besides that, I loved how my burrito wasn't gushing with oil and grease.. It actually tasted pretty healthy in comparison to other burritos I have eaten in the past.
author: Lauren K.

description: Yummy burritos, fast service, fun atmosphere. 2 complaints: both the red and the green salsas were too spicy to eat and the chips tasted stale.
author: Jackie L.

description:
Great little spot! Wasn't too sure about how good the food was going to be, but I was pleasantly surprised.

Good portions for a decent price! All the food is very flavorful and cooked absolutely fresh. I ordered two chicken super tacos and they were delicious! Packed with lots of delicious flavor. 

Only reason one star is off is because of some of the interior. Wasn't expecting a five star restaurant, of course, but it seemed like a screw was coming loose on the wobbly bench my friend and I sat on. Place is also a tad dirty. 

Overall, delicious food, good price, fast service! Stop by here for a quick bite.
author: Ankita B.

description:
Yes, I see that this place gets 4 stars and is rated by thousands of people so maybe this was a one off or maybe the consistency here is not great(?) because the Super Veg Burrito that I brought home today was literally 80% rice and 20% pinto beans and dry as the dessert. I so wish I had taken a picture for evidence before throwing the whole thing in the trash but I was so sad at the failed state of my eagerly awaited Mexican food that I didn't think of it in time. 
    My partner, who got the Carne Asada Super Burrito said the meat was good but also was very dry. Together we both were underwhelmed, and made the decision to go back out in the world to find other burritos, because we didn't want to waste our weekend lunch on something we didn't like. Having both grown up in Cali and having our fair share of burritos in our lives (this is an understatement) Taqueria Cancun just did not make the cut.
author: Holden C.

description:
stumbled upon this little places after the beau and i were craving mexican after a night @ Mighty (dope venue, btw). The reviews did not let us down. hole in the wall but OH SO GOOD! I had the camarones burrito. It's MASSIVE! only ate half...the second half was even better on day 2. 

sucky part - cash only. plan accordingly
author: EarthaStarr P.

description:
I don't  understand how this place has 4-stars on so many reviews. 

Their beans are ok. 

The carne asada looked lovely, but had no flavor. Literally none. 

The tostada de ceviche was a solid ok.  Not good, not bad. Edible. 

The tortilla chips are weird. 

The horchata was average. 

The guy behind the counter didn't want to answer one question. 

The Tapatio™ had been refilled way too many times. It might be an original bottle. The vintage is unclear. 

Don't sit at the back table and watch the food prep. Don't do it. 

Sadly, I'd prefer Chipotle. And I hate that place.
author: Cj L.

description:
Mission burrito was on my list of things to get and eat when I was in San Francisco. And did I accomplish it with flying colors with Taqueria Cancun. Best. Mission. Burrito. Let's just say that, as I was walking to this place, a cool 5-10ish minutes away from the 16th st. BART station. 

So what did I order? Obviously it was a mission burrito. I got the Super Burrito with Al Pastor, and holy shit. It was absolutely amazing. This is now my one spot that I will always visit when I am back in the Bay. The meat was tender, flavorful, and with all the things that come in the burrito it was perfect. 

By far, this is and will be my go to spot for mission burritos. I may try and go and discover another spot, but if I'm too lazy, this place will definitely stay as my default. If you have a hard time trying to decide what meat to get, I would HIGHLY recommend you to get the Al Pastor because to me that's a winner hands down.
author: Bruce K.

description: I went to Taqueria Cancun as a stop on a Mission District food tour with Sidewalk Food Tours. I only tried the carnitas taco but it was excellent. The Taqueria was extremely packed with a big line and nowhere to sit. So clearly people love the food here.
author: zenda M.

description:
Taqueria Cancun was the tits. Seriously, some damn good food. We came for lunch on a weekday and got in right away. 

My boyfriend had the enchiladas. They mix meats if you so desire, so he went with half chorizo and half el pastor (marinated pork). The enchiladas came with rice and beans. I had the burrito. It was huge and packed full of tasty goodness. I tried mixed carne asada and beef tongue (lengua), because I felt like living on the edge. Other options were beef head or beef brains but I wasn't that brave this time around. 

The atmosphere was also great - very casual but full of color and fun. I will dream about this burrito for a long, long time.
author: Sol C.

description:
Yum! I'm so happy to finally have a go-to burrito spot in the mission. We had the munchies last Saturday night so we ordered:

Shrimp Burrito: 5/5
Breakfast Burrito: 4.5/5
Chicken Burrito: 3/5
Carne Asada Nachos: 4.5/5

The Burritos were huge and for the most part super flavorful. The Nachos were great as well and I don't even usually like steak! 

Love this place!
author: Jane H.

description:
Lovely hole in the wall kinda place, but when you enter you feel you just traveled to Mexico. Vibrant yellow walls and multi colored flags dripping from the ceiling and picnic style seating makes the place somehow very cozy. 

The service was super fast and they cook everything right there in front of you. I had the cabeza (beef head) and carnitas super tacos. Both were extremely good. Very messy to eat them but who cares when they taste that great, right? 

The complimentary nachos and salsas were just as good as the tacos. Everyone seemed to be ordering the burrito so it must be good. I'll have to try it for myself and judge, but so far Taqueria Cancun you got my approval!
author: Tamara S.

description: Had an pretty good carne asada burrito, which came in a very generous portion. I did takeout and didn't realise that the chips and salsa came with it until much later! Great combination of flavours.
author: Chiang Fong L.

description: I ordered a carne asada super burrito. I was so excited. My receipt said "veggie super burrito". So I asked the guy and said "I ordered a carne asada burrito" he said. "Yeah yeah" and gave me a thumbs up. I took my burrito home. It was a veggie burrito. I am extremely disappointed.
author: R S.

description: Meh. strickly a review of the burritos which were light on the meat and under spiced, AL Pastor should have some depth to it, theirs doesn't.  Also the cross- utilization of utensils is questionable.  Communal table sharing...we're not in Europe, I want my own damn table. Also the follow of customer ordering and paying is annoying...there is always a ass in your face.
author: Sabrina D.

description:
We went with a group of four friends last Sunday and we all got food poisoning! I love tacos and loved this Taqueria, but as a customer, I feel the urge to alert the Taqueria somehow. 
I'm sorry Taqueria Cancún, but I don't think I'll be back soon.
author: Elisa U.

description: I only go here because it's close by and a go to spot for when I'm super hungry after a night out- plus coz the og chicken and rice is all the way east. Get the Prawn quesadilla - it will not disappoint. They are generous with the amount of prawns they put in. Make sure you order some guac Along with it.
author: Kai A.

description:
My girl was enthusiastic about stopping by this place when we were strolling around town based on previous reviews, but I'm a bit more skeptical of peoples opinions and taste for Mexican food in San Francisco. I've never had so much mediocre mexican food in my life since moving up here (no offense).

But at the end of the day, was it edible, regrettable, and decent for what it is? Yes, ehh, yep.

The Spot: 
The spot was cracking. People were either grabbing an early bite to eat, or ending their day drinking shenanigans and sobering up with some burritos. We grabbed the only clean table available in the back.

Comida:
I got a carne asada taco. Meat was a little dry, salsa was so-so, but it was a pretty large taco so it did it's job of holding me over till dinner. I won't come back for the taco again though.

GF got the veggie burrito which was of decent size. As always, I took a few bites and it was way better than the taco. It was "moist" as she put it, kind of like a squishy burrito that you can dig, especially when your drunk. Sour cream, avocado, freshly sauteed veggies, beans & rice. It was solid.
author: Roman V.

description:
The location is great, and it's pretty famous by now, so I've been here several times. This is a phenomenal place to get late night food. Everything tastes amazing when you've had a few drinks. That being said, it seems less magical when you're sober and just want a good meal. It's pricier and greasier than other Mexican places in the area. The food is def solid, but there are plenty of other better options for delicious Mexican food and prob for a lower price too! 

They give you chips and salsa to eat while you eat, so that was nice. The bathroom was not in good shape- no soap for the sink!
author: Aimee Z.

description:
Great local place in the mission. $4 super tacos with free chips and salsa. 

Horchara is delicious and the super taco for $8.50 is huge and a great deal. 

Only negative is that it is cash only which can be a pain.
author: Katie C.

description:
Yo. The super quesadilla is da bomb. Huge and hearty and filling, it is a giant cheesy meat bomb with the crispest tortilla you could ask for. Order with the al pastor barbecue pork as your meat option and you cannot go wrong. The salt umami of the melty cheese marries well with the sweetly rich flavor of the al pastor pork, balancing each other out beautifully. 

The grilled chicken is crunchy and crispy, but not dry, and tastes delicious in a taco amidst the giant chunks of lettuce, avocado, cheese, beans and rice.

This is true quantity AND quality for the price. Bravo to Taqueria Cancún!
author: Joshua L.

description: Got the lengua burrito. Generally on par with other joints in the area. Service was fast and easy. The burrito was flavorful but definitely not on the same level as El Farolito.
author: Rubail B.

description:
Some of the best tacos I've ever had! I stumbled upon this place after having a terrible dinner at Commonwealth and was pleasantly surprised at how good the tacos were here. We decided to give this place a chance because it was packed with people so we figured it must have good food. Best decision we made that night. 

I tried the carnitas taco and the carne asada taco and both were quite good. The meat was flavorful and the ingredients tasted fresh. I even had some leftover tacos and took home a plate of chicken enchiladas with rice and beans to eat the next day and it still tasted great the next day! Loved the green salsa too! Chips were also fried perfectly! 

The restaurant is not the cleanest and they ran out of toilet paper in the bathroom, but the delicious food makes up for it. Just means you can't judge a book by its cover.
author: Mai Y.

description: Low price, delicious, heavyweight, super veggie burritos. No ambiance, but what good taqueria has that? Great location in the bar-mecca Mission. Yeah, parking is a challenge, much like the entire city.
author: Barbara K.

description:
The burrito I ordered was literally the size of my head! The grilled chicken was great and I ordered mine without sour cream. In retrospect, it was a little dry without the sour cream so next time, I think I will ask for a little bit. 

The salsas that they have are pretty spicy but I couldn't stop myself from eating more! Prices are pretty average for a burrito in the Mission so I plan on coming back!
author: Dora T.

description: This is my favorite burrito spot! I always get the carne asada burrito. I highly recommend this place! The green salsa is fire!
author: Ena M.

description: One of my favorite places in SF -- so tasty and so cheap!  Wish they had a NY location!
author: Amrit R.

description:
The burrito mojado here is outstanding.

Seems there are a handful of snobs or loyalists on here comparing TC with a bunch of other neighborhood spots in an unfavorable light which is just silly... The fact you like a place down the street shouldn't detract from your appreciation of this one!

As a Mexican food loving East Coaster I've learned to avoid eating burritos for the most part around my hometown of NYC, it just ain't easy getting a quality burrito around these parts and you can usually find something tastier on the menu. Having said that, if TC were to open up a New York branch you'd find me there a couple times a week gorging on a burrito mojado with carne asada... These things are pretty huge so probably safe to say that consuming more than one or two a week might lend itself towards making you pretty huge as well.

Killer fresh ingredients, they don't use a ton of crappy, dry fillers, perfectly tender flavorful meat, all wrapped up in a beautiful crispy-on-the-outside little blanket of love and then drenched in some truly top notch homemade salsas...

FYI for you veg folks out there - I had the opportunity to try my girlfriend's veggie quesadilla as well which also fell somewhere on the spectrum between great and excellent for such a simple dish.
author: Alex S.

description: One of the better burritos I've had since I've moved to the bay - I decided to skip being vegan for a day and grab a vegetarian burrito with a friend (yay yelp!) and it was literally everything! I'm pretty sure that's the fastest I've eaten all month. I honestly would come here every other day if I could. I'm officially a fan.
author: Morgen B.

description: what more can I say that probably hasn't already been said of this place. this is what I dream about when I imagine a mission burrito. their carnitas super burrito is perfection attained.
author: J R.

description: Of all the burritos I've had in San Francisco, the carnitas burrito at Taqueria Cantina is my favorite. I've actually only ordered that one thing here so I can't really comment on the rest of the menu but the chips and salsa are also tasty and the carnitas burrito is bomb. I order my burritos with just meat, cheese, avocado and sometimes salsa or a tiny bit of sour cream- no rice, no beans, no extra cilantro or onions. The carnitas here are amazing. So much flavor and so perfectly cooked. They are a little more "wet" than carnitas I've had elsewhere, like they've been braised in the cooking liquid. Not so wet though that the burrito is softy or anything. A lot of places will add too many spices to the carnitas or make them dry or have other issues. Here, the meat is perfect and the combination of it with the cheese and avocado is awesome. It is a pretty greasy/heavy burrito and I have a feeling they use lard in their tortillas. So definitely not something to eat all the time or the healthiest option around. Prices are really good too but it is cash only (there's an ATM with a fee inside). I'll definitely be back for a delicious burrito and a beer. 5 stars because I've had the carnitas burrito quite a few times and it's never disappointed.
author: Seema U.

description:
My husband and I came here as our first stop on our honeymoon for a real California burrito. Six years later, we came back and it's even more delicious. 

We got the super burrito with half carnitas and half carne asada for the best of both worlds. And, in true fatty form, we also got the chorizo quesadilla. It was a greasy cheesy mess that tasted like heaven and will feel like hell tomorrow. But who cares? It's so totally worth it. 

Fat on fatty.
author: Caitlin N.

description: I don't even know HOW to write a review for this godsend of a tacqueria. The tortillas all crispy and delicious on the outside and soft on the inside. The sheer SIZE of the burritos. The combinations of flavours! It's beyond description. It's a true San Francisco experience, attempting to finish a super burrito. Take it to go and relax in Dolores park on a sunny day. Enjoy enjoy enjoy!!!!
author: Kat M.

description:
Is it weird that I get really, really defensive if anyone doesn't love this spot (MERELY LIKING IT DOESN'T GIVE IT ITS DUE)?  

Or that I store up all of my weight-watchers points to eat a super carne asada burrito (which I lovingly call 'baby' as it's roughly the size of one) here?  

Or that I don't know how to deal with this place being closed on Tuesdays (SINCE WHEN DID YOU PEOPLE NEED 'DAYS OFF')?  

Or that I was debating boycotting Nate Silver's blog when he didn't have this place win the Burrito Bracket (seriously, La Taqueria? wtf.)?

I doubt it.  Mother says I'm a well-adjusted young man.
author: Farooq K.

description:
Carne Asada tacos for the win!  

Simple taqueria shop with a good section for seating area.  

They don't have a salsa bar that I tend to prefer for a taqueria place, but the salsa that they do provide is still doable.  I love Pico De Gallo with anything and they didn't have bottomless on that, unfortunately.

Cash only spot.

Good place to get your tacos, nachos and quesadillas on!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
YUM 

I got a regular carne asada burrito and it was great! This was my first Mission burrito experience, so I can't compare it to other Mission taquerias, but it was definitely better than the ones I've eaten in Berkeley. I didn't get a super burrito because I knew I was getting boba later and didn't want to be too stuffed, but it was v tempting. 

CASH ONLY. The line moves quickly, and they also push orders out super quickly too. I got my burrito literally 3 minutes after ordering. 

I'll want to explore more places in the Mission, but Taqueria Cancun set a great bar.
author: Connie C.

description:
Thank goodness for new friends! Based on his expert recommendation we now have a favorite post beer drinking hang out. Taqueria Cancún is fast, friendly and well priced. Portions are massive and the quality stellar, what more could one ask for? 

Onto the foods..

-Carne Asada Burrito Mojado - Huge mega sized burrito filled with rice, beans and meat, like lots of meat. After trying a few burritos around the bay Im happy to report that this burrito had the perfect meat to filling ratio. The burrito is served slathered in green salsa, red salsa and sour cream. With so many different sauces each bite was different from the last, gotta love variety. The meat was tender and had a slight smoky flavor, good meat, good meat. For the price I felt this was a bargain!

-Al Pastor Torta - I think everything is super sized at TC! This torta was thick and oh-so-messy with the fillings leaking out all over my hands during each bite. The al pastor had a nice sweet and smoky flavor, they sure know how to cook meats here. Beans, onions, avocados and sour cream graced the roll which had a nice chew and moist crumb. 

-Cheese Quesadilla - Cheese and a tortilla joined together through melting and ever lasting love. Not much to say here except yummy love.

-Cheese Enchiladas- These were just fair in my opinion. I prefer a richer thicker more smoky chile sauce rather than the thin more brightly flavored sauce on their version. I mean these were good and stuff but weren't that satisfying to me. The beans however are f-cking superior. So creamy and smooth with a deep rich flavor that I will order a bean and cheese burrito next time we eat here. 

-Horchata - This wasn't nearly as bad as the sludge served at The Little Chihuahua, this version was pretty gritty and not easy to drink. After a few sips I threw it out. Note to self, stop ordering horchata. 

Another huge plus for TC is the fact that they're are open late night! Oh, they are cash only so make sure you're good to go. Also, parking is a bitch in this neighborhood. Took us close to 15 minutes before we lucked out landing a spot a block from the restaurant. Your patients will be rewarded.

James R, you kick ass my friend. Thank you again!
author: Alexander C.

description:
My friends and I always get into arguments about this place.

*Fight*  *Fight* *Fight*

Here's the thing, every time I come here for a burrito or taco (always with carne asada) it's just okay. It's not to die for. It's nothing thrilling. 

I mean the way my buddies talk about this place you would swear that Kate Upton was making the tacos or something.

They only give me mini container of salsa. Their chips are that lumpy corn kind from a bag that I can't stand, yet this place is always packed.

Packed like it was the Victoria Runway show or something.

Me: "Can we go to another Taqueria? There are like hundreds of them here."
My Friends: "No dude, this place rocks. Just try it again. Don't be a downer."

Needless to say, no matter how many times I get dragged to this place it's always a downer.
author: Jack R.

description: Good burrito with a decent atmosphere. I believe it is cash only too. The place is usually crowded but it shouldn't be too difficult finding a seat because most people take their food to go. Overall, I thought the burrito  ($9) was great but nothing super special about it compared to a delicious burrito I get elsewhere. The restroom is here pretty sketchy, and the environment in the place is not the most fancy place.
author: Eva H.

description:
Dropped in for a midnight snack. Bought the super burrito - it was just AMAZING! The pork was tender and flavorful and the taco was amazing. 
The quaintness of the joint and the wall hanging CD jukebox made the place look rather retro. Didnt get to explore the place indepth since we ordered a take out. 
Loved the place enough to make another trip over there. 

Only gripe- Only accepts cash!
author: Madan M.

description:
First off, let me say that the food here is legit. Cash only but decently priced (for 2017 SF) with the freshest sesos (pork brain) in the mission. This is one of my go-to spots for a quick mexi meal. (Crispy tacos or carnitas at El Buen Sabor, Cabeza tacos at La Oaxacaquena, Carnita Torta at Yucatasia being the others.) If it's primetime, call ahead and your food might be ready by the time you get to the cashier.

I'm giving them 2-stars in this review because of the subpar service I received the other night. I called in an order of a double meat (camarones and sesos) super burrito and had to wait another 5 minutes after paying before it was ready, which is perfectly fine and didn't influence this review in any way. They were really busy that night. My disappointment started when I got home and took about 4 bites before it was evident that they had only put shrimp and left out the sesos. It sucked, but mistakes happen. This in itself wouldn't have earned a negative review. I called them up, explained my predicament and the guy begrudgingly told me to come back to grab a replacement burrito and to make sure I brought the other burrito with me. Again, this was all fine enough. The lightweight attitude was a bit off-putting but, whatever, maybe they get scammed with this shit all the time. What put it over the top was upon my return, the cashier/phone guy looks at my partially eaten burrito, disappointingly shakes his head and mutters something about "you almost finished it". WTF? I ate a quarter of it max and this fool thinks I really went all the way home and back to come up on a few extra bites of shrimp burrito? They f'd up and he tried to give me a guilt trip about it. GTFO of here with that BS. 4 stars for the food (as always), 0 stars for the guilt trip and implicit scam accusations = 2 stars.

It's important to point out that this review is mainly about the late middle aged male cashier that was working there that night. The younger dude that usually works the cashier is cool as hell.

Last note: shrimp and sesos might sound gross to some of y'all but don't knock it before you try it. Or don't try it and leave all the fresh sesos for me and all the folks I've put on to its deliciousness. Also, the combo goes just as well in a quesadilla.
author: Carlo B.

description: Heard about this place on a Youtube video of "musts" in San Fran.  I went late on a weekend night. Parking was atrocious, but I lucked up on a space directly across the street after a few passes.  This place was super loud and busy.  I didn't know they were cash only until I was already in line and I don't use random ATM machines (there is one in the restaurant). So I was limited in my purchase.  I ordered two steak tacos and found a spot at a dirty table.  The tacos were excellent but be warned they are hot! They don't tell you that they put a hot sauce on it.  But they were so flavorful that I suffered through it with water!  They also give you a free side of chips and gauc that is also good.  One of the better meals I had in the Bay.
author: Candace W.

description:
My friend told me that this place has the best Mexican food in the Mission, so I had to try it, and let's just say I thoroughly enjoyed the food I had.

The thing is, I don't like a lot of the ingredients that come in a burrito (beans, sour cream, and salsa) so I'm really picky about my burritos, but I got a burrito nonetheless. 
I actually got a super burrito without beans, sour cream, and salsa ... heh. I asked if I could have two types of meat and they let me (not many places do) !! I got carne asada and pastor (marinated pork). The burrito was so good. I love avocados, so when a burrito says it comes with avocado, I expect there to be a huge amount and at most places there isn't, but here, there is plentiful !! The tortilla is slightly crispy and I love it cause when you bite into it, you get this slight crunch, and it's great.

The chips and salsa that come with each order is really good too. I don't know why I love their chips so much, but I just do. They are really crunchy and don't seem that oily either ! Also, the avocado salsa that comes with the chips ... pure greatness. 

The burrito was $6.50 + tax (cash only) so it a little over $7 in the end, and it was worth every penny. 

I am clearly a fan !!! Perfect for late night burrito cravings !!

Also, I saw a guy eating a quesadilla, and it looked magical. The tortilla looked so crisp with all that oozing cheese, definitely going to try that next time !!
author: Alesia C.

description: This placed was packed but with a high turnover. We came here on a foodie tour and despite being in a large group we were able to sit down, use the restrooms and fill out water bottles. Each meal is served in a little plastic basket unless to buy it to go. I had a soft taco with pork which was pretty good. I would go out of my way to come back to this place and give the other items on the menu a try.
author: Sue L.

description: Best burrito in the Mission. You don't like the service? No one cares. They make Mexican food.
author: Bryan L.

description:
The real deal! This is GOOD mexican food in the mission. If you want your fancy wancy fine dining place, stay away. 
This is a simple place, which just has great food! I havent had their famous burritoes yet, but got the tacos.
Let me say this, I will be coming back many times. One of the best tacos I've had
author: Sourav C.

description:
Wonderful and flavorful tacos, generous portions, and most of all, kind staff! 

This is a special review, but here we go: twice during my lunch, a heavily drunk man came in and began cursing and threatening my friends and I at our table, but luckily the restaurant staff came to our rescue and calmly but firmly escorted him outside. As a first-timer in the Mission area, this encounter scared the hell out of me, but I'm ever grateful for the Taqueria Cancun staff for standing up for us; they genuinely care about their customers' safety and will handle dangerous situations with professionalism. 

Also, best tacos I've ever had, period. Fantastic experience all around.

In the restaurant I never got to say a proper thank you, so here it is, and I sure hope you see this!
author: Candice Y.

description:
3.5 stars.

Had two tacos ($6) with carnitas and al pastor topped with onions, salsa, and cilantro. The al pastor was good and spicy and definitely my favorite of the two. The carnitas was tender but the pieces were so large that it reminded me of stewed meat. There wasn't enough sear, so it didn't have that nice crunch that you look for in carnitas. Corn tortillas were served grilled and soft. These were good, but it just can't compare with SD/LA tacos.

Great prices and free chips with every order. Careful though- the green salsa is pretty hot. I've heard good things about the burritos, and I saw alambres on the menu that I want to try next next.
author: Alice T.

description:
Gosh I love this place!
Incredibly authentic & legit mexican food! 
The burritos are great, I don't know anyone who disagrees! My friend even liked the taco salad!
They frequently have a long line but it really moves fast. They are efficient here for sure! There is ample seating for both small & large groups. They bus the tables quickly & keep the place really clean even when it's busy!
Simple good food.
author: Ashley G.

description:
I've never written a Yelp review before however the food poisoning I received from this place last night is possibly the worst I've ever had and I feel obligated to leave some criticism.
 Cancun came on the recommendation of some friends who I joined to eat. The taqueria was really crowded and busy (usually a good sign). I ordered a chicken super burrito along with the rest of my party, who fortunately came away unscathed. The burrito was average, nothing spectacular. 
4 hours after leaving the restaurant a category 5 hurricane of cramps, vomiting, chills, aches and fluid bowel movements made land in my stomach and is enduring going in 19 hours. 
Fair warning!
author: Matt M.

description:
Been asking around for where to obtain a great Mission burrito, and people have been pointing me towards Taqueria Cancun.

Quite impressive I must say. The super burrito, of course, is amazing. The super taco is as well. Love that they offer complementary chips and salsa.
author: Tunaidi A.

description:
Well, this was surprising. I wasn't expecting to ever find an El Farolito replacement, but, then I want to Taqueria Cancun. Twice, in a single weekend. And I'll say this: while I still like the burritos at El Faro better, the tacos here are superb.

My first trip here, I ordered one of their al pastor super tacos, which comes loaded with just about everything, and super generous portions of avocado to boot. My second trip a few days later was to try a carne asada super burrito, which, while still tasty, lacked the stand-out flavor you can find at El Faro. Now, if you're close to Cancun, is the difference worth trekking out to El Faro for? No. But if you haven't decided then, then, well!

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - While the space isn't huge, and it can certainly get crowded, Cancun is far more accessible than El Faro, if not simply because of gaps in the walkway that allow for easily maneuvering through lines.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Beautiful and cheap hole in the wall Mexican food!
What more can you ask for!!!

I've been needing a Mexican fix for awhile now and this place REALLY hit the spot!

You can tell the locals really love this place.  Everyone was in food ecstasy sitting in each of the tables.  The cooks and cashier were also having a great time as well.  Laughing and taking pride in serving their food. 

I wanted to order and eat everything if I could.  Everything looked so damn good.  I just went off the Yelp highlights.

Got the pastor burrito and carne asada taco and seriously, I could feed a family with just those two items alone.  They were HUGE!
I did not have dinner that night.  

They also gave you free chips and salsa which was a bonus.  Their salsa is the best I've had, and I really wanted more.  But waiting in line to get some didn't seem worth it.  They should make it easier to get more and hand them out in bigger portion sizes.

I finished EVERYTHING! My only concern was how clean the baskets were (of if they were cleaned after every use at all...). They burritos and tacos are really wet, so they rip through the paper and touch the basket....

Anyways, my stomach was more or less ok after that meal, so I think I'm ok! =)

Will definitely be back!
author: David W.

description:
Have you ever craved a drunk burrito? Until, my friends took me to this hole-in-the-wall, Taqueria Cancun, I never thought I wanted Mexican after a night of drinking. Now, a burrito from Taueria Cancun is all I can dream about.

So, the line is insanely long on weekend nights and for good reason. Once your order is placed, they have a fast turn around. There are places to sit, but they fill up quickly and some tables are communal seating, keep that in mind. 

The burrito...it comes with chips and salsa, which was a huge perk and surprise! Everything about this burrito is perfection, from the way the cheese is melted to the amount of rice there is. After having the burriot, I am sure you can't place a bad order here. 

Pro tip- bring cash! There is an ATM, but you don't want to lose your place in line to get cash.
author: Kendal Ann M.

description: Excellent tacos. Carnitas is the meat to get here. I went with a carne asada super taco and the carnitas regular taco and it was a satisfying amount of food and one of the better Mission taco spots in my opinion.
author: Michael S.

description:
We wanted some Mexican food in the Mission and someone suggested three places we could go to and some how we ended up here. As far as I know, we ended up at a good place. I split the cabeza quesadilla with my sister and with each getting half a quesadilla and a basket of chips, it was the perfect amount for us since we were going to dessert after. 

The cabeza (beef head) was moist and flavorful and there was a lot of cheese which I love because the thing I hate the most getting a quesadilla and not being able to taste the cheese. 

Overall, it was a really good quesadilla and I would come back for another.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Came here late night for some food before I went home.  The wait was a little long, but I took it's popularity as a good thing.  The crowd was full of friendly people.  They also had a mariachi band playing which was fun.  My football size wet burrito arrived shortly there after and hit the spot.   Price is right, location is good and it's delicious!

No complaints.
author: Nick G.

description:
I've written a almost identical review for the SoMa Taqueria Cancun location but this one deserves a review also.

I walked into Taqueria Cancun my first weekend in San Francisco. My roommate was raving about having to try a proper burrito and this was his favorite spot. As a burrito lover, I look back on that day as a beautiful moment that changed how I rate burritos forever.

FREQUENCY: I've dined at this establishment more times than I can count (and I've only lived in SF for 3-4 months). I had to cut back to once a week because I like to stay healthy and fit and I was probably eating about 3 of these burritos per week.

FOOD: Get the super burrito. Taqueria Cancun has other items on their menu but it might as well not be there at all. They have about 8 different meats to choose from (or vegetarian if you prefer) and I've tried them all. Each is delicious but my go to at this point is Al Pastor. Your burrito will come with chips plus one green and red salsa cup. I prefer the green salsa so now I ask for two green salsa's. I can't speak enough about how amazing the burrito's are here. I grew up on the East Coast and I'll honestly probably never order a burrito when back home ever again. San Francisco Super Burrito's and San Diego California Burrito's have spoiled me. TRY THIS BURRITO! It's the first thing I take any visitors to do. And it's under $10 for a mound of food.

DRINK: Taqueria Cancun offers a good selection of beer, fountain drinks, and water. I'm personally a fan of a Pacifico with my burrito but my buddy gets the soda and really enjoys that too. 

ATMOSPHERE: Taqueria Cancun has the standard vibe for a taqueria in the Mission. Tables are usually filled with people having conversation and it can get a little loud at times. Plus depending on the time of day the line may be out the door. I promise it's worth the wait. But I've learned when they are and aren't busy from my multiple visits.

STAFF: I have literally never spoken more than my burrito order to the staff. They are quite and keep to themselves but since they are all behind a counter making food I don't mind nor am I offended. They have consistently made me amazing food so they get 5 stars in my book.

PAYMENT: Taqueria Cancun is cash only. They have ATM's on site.

There is one location in The Mission and one location in SoMa. Both are awesome and I go to each one regularly. If there is one thing that anyone takes away from my Yelp profile it is to try a burrito at this place!
author: Christopher D.

description:
I honestly have no idea why anyone else likes this place! I got the carnitas super burrito and found it to be extremely bland, overpowered by sour cream, and just filled with oil.  I felt gross after eating it.

The chips weren't fresh and the salsa they give you with the chips was literally tostito's brand (when I mean literally, I mean I've had this salsa from the grocery store before.)

I have to admit, I come from LA so the burrito/mexican scene is a bit different, but this was absoutely the worst burrito, chips and salsa I've ever had. I would never come back.
author: Gieselle A.

description:
How this place has a four-star average rating is beyond me. The quality of the food here is below average. Bad ingredients, quick preparation without care, unfriendly service... 

Do yourself a favor and go over to 16th St if it's late at night.
author: Dan Z.

description:
This is where you go for authentic south of he border food with a traditional sense of food preparation. The corn chips were not from a bag nor did anything else seem like that. All fresh and perfect blend of flavors. 

The super tacos with lengua or tongue was perfectly braised and with cilantro, sour cream, salsa, avocado on corn soft tortillas was amazing. Perfect bite to eat and was glad was shown this gem of a place to dine.
author: Travis K.

description: Taqueria Cancún may not be too pretty on the outside, but it's the food inside that counts. They serve some of the best Mexican food in the Mission at the right price. From the free chips and salsa to the sizeable entrées, this spot delivers on both quality and quantity.
author: Chris G.

description:
The super nachos ($10) were ginormous, a huge pile of meat and chips and stuff. The cashier had asked if I wanted everything on it, but not really knowing what that constituted, I said sure. Heads up that it includes a lot of jalapenos in addition to their spicy green salsa! Besides the random bites of extreme spice, the nachos were pretty good. Great ratio of stuff to chips. Maaaaybe could use a little more avocado. 

The regular tacos ($2.80) were regular - both carnitas and al pastor somehow spicy even though they didn't appear to have any of that green salsa in them. They're generous with the meat in the tacos. 

I guess I can't really complain about the food being really heavy, because it's pretty obvious walking in that you are not going to feel refreshed and healthy after eating here...

Place was not too busy at around 7pm on Sunday night. Total price was around $17 after tax for two of us - we didn't finish our last bites.
author: Jenn W.

description: This is hands down the best taco I have ever had in my life (and I'm from LA). The carne asada is so flavorful and perfectly cooked. Opt for the super taco as the added avocado really makes it. 10/10
author: Olivia P.

description:
I was in Mission district and got Soft Taco for $2.25.
This may not seem like a lot of money, but I normally get Soft Tacos for $1.50 from food trucks in Alviso.  The quality was very similar, so I can only compare the price difference.  I suppose rent in SF is much more than operating from mobile food trucks.  Sorry for being cheap but this is my bias opinion.
author: Connie W.

description: I got nachos and they were microwaved to the point of the chips being so STALE!!! Absolutely awful ):
author: Lauren L.

description:
Good place! Open late and super popular with climbers from nearby Mission Cliffs. 

The food is tasty, the line tends to be long but moves quickly and the guys working there are super quick. 

The atmosphere is super bright, tends to be loud, so feels pretty festive. There's a jukebox that people use.
author: Julia O T.

description: My favorite Mission-style burrito. Open late so a great place to come sober up with some great Mexican food.
author: Luke N.

description: One of the best burritos in San Francisco! It's very authentic and a hole in a wall place. Ingredients are fresh and very on point. I ordered the super burrito with carne asada. If you want a great taste of a burrito, look no further!
author: Jenn L.

description: Yeahhh
author: Dan A.

description: Come to the Mission and get what? Mexican food of course! We were given some recommendations, but for some reason, we still yelped it and came up with this place.  My sister and I shared a cabeza quesadilla and was completely satisfied. The meat was flavorful and was really tender. There was a good amount of cheese and the tortilla was grilled perfectly. The only thing is that a ton of liquid (from the cheese??) was leaking out of my quesadilla which I suppose gave it some flavor....
author: Stella Y.

description: My definite dark horse underdog for a mission burrito . I feel like Taqueria Guadalajara and el faralito get most the attention but this one is hella underrated. Might even be the best
author: Slavic D.

description: Best tacos I've had since relocating to SF about a month ago and I love me some tacos. From the perfect seasoning to the Spanglish while ordering this place is super authentic and hits the spot. Full selection of beer. Quick service and available seating on a Saturday night completes my 5 star review.
author: Lauren K.

description: My sister and I went here last week after a long Thursday night ha! The food is great
author: Lady R.

description:
This is my first visit to the mission location. I've been going to Taqueria Cancun for about 13 years. I usually go to the one on Market and 6th and didn't know there was another location until my last visit to the city. 

First and foremost, Taqueria Cancun is my favorite restaurant in San Fransisco. Not many people equate the Bay Area with amazing Mexican food, but they are so mistaken. Taqueria Cancun makes some of the most legit Mexican food ever. It rivals anything from Southern California. 

My go to meal is 2 Super Tacos with Carne Asada. They are essentially amped up versions of street tacos. They come with usual fixings, onion and cilantro, but they take it to the next level with cheese, sour cream, and avocado. The carne asada is tender and flavored to perfection. Top of your meal with a coke or a beer and you are set to go!
author: Andrew D.

description: Really disappointed.  The chicken was dry and the staff was not friendly.  Really had higher expectations for this place given the reviews.
author: Sara K.

description:
In the Mission, and in San Francisco, there are several taquerias and definitely no shortage of Mexican food. But this one is by far my favorite in the Bay Area. 

I've had several things here, including tacos, burritos and taco salads; but from that, the Pork Tacos are probably the best. (The Fish Tacos take a really close second.) But regardless, the flavor, authenticity and the size of your meal are so incredible for the pricy you're paying. Service is incredibly quick, even in the busiest of times. 

I've been here on numerous occasions and never been disappointed. Great spot for locals and for those new to the city... 11/10 would recommend to anyone in a heartbeat!
author: Adi P.

description: Get the cantaloupe juice! It's fresh and loaded with meaty pulp. I got the messy burrito swimming in a red and green sauce. The carne burrito was delicious! This place is no frills which lends itself to the authenticity of the simple and comforting food.
author: Kim M.

description: There was no lineup Sunday evening so the service was super fast. The super burrito was as large as the super burrito at El Farolito. They serve complimentary tortillas chips and salsa. The two types of salsa were both very spicy. The burrito did not have as much rice as El Farolito. The avocado was freshly cut as they were being placed into the burrito. I could not taste the sour cream. The beef was tender.
author: James S.

description:
Not impressed whatsoever. 

1) cash only 
2) pricey burritos/food in general
3) unimpressed by the carne asada burrito, I got it with enchilada sauce too
4) no condiments counter, no radishes 
6) their guac sauce was subpar, but their pico was good
7) chips for tortilla were stale

Overall, I would venture somewhere else.
author: Amy H.

description:
This taqueria has a ceviche tostada for $2.99
Anyone who likes ceviche has to try it because it is a great dish that usually costs about twice as much at other restaurants. 

I am giving them four stars because they do not take credit cards. What's wrong with them? We live in USA, credit cards are part of our lives.
author: Kiaan O.

description: The salsas are absolutely killer. I usually neglect the green sauce in favor of the red or even pico, but the one here is just so good. Tacos and quesadillas are all great, but It was the recent al pastor burrito that made me declare Taqueria Cancun as my current favorite. I wasn't aware they were renowned for their al pastor until a quick online search moments ago. Makes me feel like I don't know how to internet. The pork is a right balance of spicy, sweet, and fatty. I was so caught up in that moment of deliciousness that I recklessly applied the entire salsa ration on the first half of the burrito.
author: Huey N.

description:
"Everything's good," is what a friend said when we asked for recommendations on what to order. Realllly not helpful, and usually a biased, untrue statement, but we figured, why not?

Let me tell you, this place is legit, amazing, and worth the effort it takes to find parking in the Mission.

SUPER TACOS.
Got a mess of these, and made a mess devouring them all. They come topped with fresh, sliced avocado, and sour cream, along with generous scoops of whatever meat you decide to order. Highlights for us include:
+ lengua (tongue)
+ carnitas
+ sesos (beef head, my favorite!)

LINES.
Just brave them. They come and go, seemingly at random, and you may be hit with a 20 minute line, or a 5 minute one, but it's worth the wait.

TABLES.
You have to have the eye of a hawk to spot a group leaving their table in this crowded place, and you need to act fast, as at any given time, you're competing with several other shrewd-eyed table-hunters as well. Be patient, though.

Definitely coming back again and again!

Note-  CASH ONLY.
author: Claire S.

description:
Taqueria Cancun is great!  This spot has been named one of the best in San Francisco and I totally agree.

I love the carne asada super burrito, which I've eaten both times I've been here.  I also tried the grilled chicken Super Burrito, which was as tasty as the carne asada burrito. There's something about the flavor of the meat that adds to the deliciousness of the sour cream, black beans, rice, avocado and salsa all mixed in the tortilla and nicely wrapped in foil. The portions are pretty big.  I got full after eating just half of my burrito, so it was pretty filling. They give you a basket of chips with your burrito, too!

The restaurant itself is cozy, a bit small. My fiance and I had to share a table with another couple because it gets crowded in there. Especially late night! 

When I'm in the Mission area and I'm craving a burrito, Taqueria Cancun will always be the first to come up in my mind.  I will definitely keep coming back to this spot!
author: Regina B.

description:
I wanted to come here after I read in Eater SF that this place may close due to them being "too" popular and that they can't keep up with the high customer demand.  In any case, after a night at Southern Pacific nearby, we saw them on the way to the BART station and why not end the night with some lengua tacos and a burrito?  I got the tacos because I'm health conscious, for real, and my friend got the burrito.  When we went in, we lined up at the wrong end of the counter so we eventually made it to the far end  and lined up to pay and then waited.  At around 11pm, the place is occupied at all tables.  Total damage for two lengua tacos and a lengua burrito was $12 after tax. That's not that bad!!

I didn't eat my tacos until an hour later and maybe I was still a bit buzzed but I do remember eating them(foil wrappers in my trash prove it) and my friend said that he had his lengua burrito the following day when he found it on top of his bedframe(what?).

I'd love to come back to Cancun when I'm a bit more sober and perhaps at their Market location but next time, I hope to remember a bit more than what I recollect at this moment.
author: Ben H L.

description: My friend and I found this taqueria by pure accident one day and this is my third time back, so I figure I should review it.  Everything about the burritos here are amazing.  I get the vegetarian burritos and they're extremely flavorful and don't skimp on any fillings (including avocado!).  The salsas are perfectly spicy and complement the burritos.  The tortillas are also somehow perfectly flaky- I've never really relished a tortilla before having the burritos here but they've really changed the tortilla game for me.  It's cash only but completely worth taking a trip to get cash back somewhere for a burrito this good!
author: Shravya G.

description: Definite hole in the wall with some definitely fantastic tacos. I mean this place felt and looked real deal. I wasn't sure what to expect when I walked in but let me tell you people from all walks of life were coming in there for tacos or burritos either to eat there or to go (that's how you know it's good!). We ended up getting one carnitas, one asada and two al pastor all to share. They are the smaller corn tortillas so it's only a couple bites. They also give you free chips with homemade salad. The al pastor tacos were so flavorful it was just like Mexican music in your mouth! With a beer and amazing food we made a memory we won't soon forget. Would definitely recommend it if you find yourself in the mission district.
author: Celeste G.

description:
Good place for a LATE night stop. Went in around 2am on a Friday night and it was packed with drunks everywhere! Quite entertaining to say the least.... Yelp says they close at 2am, but on Friday nights they're open til almost 230am. 

Small space- hella people during the late night! As soon as you walk in grab the first table you see- even if theres peoples plates on them. Don't worry they'll come pick up the mess shortly after you sit down. Theres a long line, but they have a really good assembly line going on so you won't have to wait long for your food. 

Greasy ass mexican food- but so so good! Tad bit pricey, but worth it. Large portions!
$3.25 for a super taco which comes with choice of meat, guac, melted cheese (drool) onion, salsa, cilantro. 
Carne quesadilla- again, super greasy, but delicious! 

CASH ONLY!
author: Jessica B.

description:
Been hearing some great things about Cancun, and from trusted foodie friends. Being a taco fiend, I went with my usual faves to get a good sense of their quality of meat but was pretty disappointed. Not worth a meal there when the amazing La Oaxaquena is just a block or two away.

Between chorizo, al pastor, and carne asada, only CARNE ASADA was worth trying I'd say. Chorizo and al pastor were both soggy, lacked crunch, and were basically unmemorable pieces of meat mixed in with the salsa on the tacos. At least the carne asada had a crispness and therefore texture to the meat, though it was still a little dry. 

I was feeling adventurous with a friend and we also got a BRAIN taco - if you've ever made a broth and seen blood when it's cooked in boiling water, that's about the texture of brain - soft, spongy, with a little bit of give on the outside (like when creme brulee or boiled milk has that thin layer of skin at the top). Jiggly but  disintegrates easily once you start chewing. This is worth a try, not bad! 

On the tortillas - they are on the thinner side, seem freshly made, perfectly fine but not super memorable.

See below for photos:

* Brain taco - 3.5 stars
photo: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/g0VCHer2uE5NLOEdblZuSw?select=koW_av3kvhn8azGDReuBuw#koW_av3kvhn8azGDReuBuw

* Chorizo taco - 2.5 stars
photo: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/g0VCHer2uE5NLOEdblZuSw?select=koW_av3kvhn8azGDReuBuw#DfLQyXLxxunLmQXUSaTvbQ

* Carne Asada super taco - 3 stars
photo: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/g0VCHer2uE5NLOEdblZuSw?select=koW_av3kvhn8azGDReuBuw#E3LxL9G_H-rSMNt3PJguvw

* Al pastor taco - 2 stars
photo: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/g0VCHer2uE5NLOEdblZuSw?select=koW_av3kvhn8azGDReuBuw#4YY-lI_xfS_9AGlwTVDkXw
author: Ziyan C.

description:
The best tasting ugly salsa I've ever had.

Seriously, it looks watery and the tomatoes look bland.  But it's surprisingly good and there's a nice kick.

I would choose the Burrito Mojado over the tacos for sure.  The tacos weren't that special to me, maybe because the lengua and al pastor were okay.  It's not bad; they just make it a different style where the lengua is more soft and the al pastor's marinade is more sweet, almost like ketchup.  

Now, the Burrito Mojado is really something.  It's big, it's full of goodies, and it's topped with even more goodies (enchilada sauce, sour cream, guacamole, cheese).  My husband and I literally inhaled this thing and licked the plate.  Although I prefer enchilada sauce to be thick, even cheesy almost, this thinner version still packed a punch.  

It can get pretty crowded because the line to order can get to the bathrooms and then people crowd around tables to wait for their order as well.  You'll most likely share a table with people but it's not so bad.
author: Shannon L.

description: Burritos fell extremely short of my expectations and was just overwhelmingly spicy. The seating arrangements are a little but awkward, but other than that I have experienced better at other taquerias
author: Bernard W.

description:
Been coming here over 20 years, and I never get tired of my weekly Cancun burrito.  Most of the (all-male) staff has been there since I first started coming, and their perseverance is the secret to the unwavering consistency of Cancun burritos:

1. The green salsa is unlike any other.  Don't bother buying some and taking it home, because it will be too spicy on the second day.  The in-house salsa is not only fresh everyday--it's fresh every hour.

2. The carne asada is always done fresh, never reheated.  (Of course, steak should NEVER come out of a reheating tray.)

3. In the first big burrito craze of the 90s, when Pancho Villa had everybody lining up for fun giant, rice burritos fresh from the steamer, Cancun was doing their tortillas on a grill.  Never burnt, just a little crisp.  Perfect.

4. That same burrito craze led to a guac-overload, but Cancun continued to put a fresh half avocado in all veggie and super burritos.  (Freshness is becoming a theme...!)

They aren't the best at everything.  Farolito still makes the best Suiza, and the carnitas at La Taqueria are superb; but Cancun's veggie and carne asada burritos are still the best in the Mission.  Enjoy!
author: Nels J.

description:
Best burritos in San Francisco!  Need I say more?

My friend who's a local took me here after we finished hitting up the bars.  They open really late here, so it's one of the best places to rock after you're done getting sloshed and need something to soak up all the alcohol you consumed.  It could just be that whenever I went here I was drunk and hungry, so they made for the best burritos in the world, but that only means you'll also get the same tingling sensation in your own taste buds for these bad boys.   

And the best part is, this place won't break the bank.  Whatever you do, get the burritos!
author: Diane V.

description: We stopped here on our food tour -- I'm half Mexican so I think when I say this place serves authentic Mexican food you should believe me. It's pretty small inside but service was muy rápido. Oh & do yourself a favor and get a sidral apple soda (the best!).
author: Janell S.

description: People are either El Farolito fans or Taqueria Cancun fans and we both know who I'm writing the yelp review for. Taqueria Cancun is worth pulling out cash from the ATM for and circling the block endless times for a parking spot. It's just that good. Every location has fun and festive decor that makes you feel like you've crossed the border. The burritos are delicious and they even give you free chips and salsa. Their green salsa is everything. I stopped coming here because this was me and my ex-boyfriend's spot and OBVI I didn't want to run into him and his ugly new rebound. SO. You can find me at La Taqueria, I've moved onto bigger (literally) and better things! Also, they're open super late so it's perfect after a night of drinking.
author: Crystal P.

description:
This place seems like your average Mexican eatery, and in some ways it is, but I'm loving the cafeteria style benches as seating because I've made a few random friends just sitting with strangers haha.

I'll be honest. This was (hate to admit) my first time trying Al Pastor. Usually I prefer Carne Asada, but I felt adventurous. I ordered the Super Burrito, which was REALLY HEAVY. Taste wise nothing too special.

They ration their salsa verde (which is very spicy) and their salsa (which is not as spicy) so you might get lucky if you ask them for extra. I was disappointed because my friend ordered the ceviche, but they ran out. I didn't realize this was possible, but it is!! It wasn't even too late at night when we visited. I'll have to go back to try their Tostada de Ceviche.

EDIT: Their Carne Asada Quesadilla is so godly. This is now my favorite thing to order here, and I'm happy to have a go-to Mexican food that satisfies my cravings! I eventually got to try their ceviche, but it was a little disappointing. It was fresh and delicious but not the best out there.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
(Not so) Hidden Gem. Living in Betnal Heights, this is the only place I go when Papalote or Farrolito feels too far away. 

Great burritos and super quesadillas, but I just tried their super tacos and Jesus are they good! 

One of the few places that adds slices of Avocado along with the rest of the works. And for $3, it's a steal. 

Dangerously tasty.
author: Carlos M.

description: Catching up on my reviews from the last holiday... This place lives up to the hype... We went for the burrito carnitas... Chips and salsa... Classic! I don't think it's the best tacqueria in the mission... But worth a visit and if here on vacation it's easy place to find... Go for the Mexican soda for the sugar hit...
author: Reg B.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)

1/1 Star: found parking quickly but I felt super lucky. Parking looks very hard to find around here. No wait to order.

_____

Service (Waiter / Cleanness / Ambiance)

0/1 Star: fast food service. Kind of dirty.  Nice abiance for a whole in the wall.

_____

Taste (0=Not Edible / 1=Edible / 2=Good (average) / 3=Must Try!)

3/3 Stars: the burritos here are really good! Must try! 

_____

Overall Experience

4/5 Stars 

_____

Last Words
Yum yum
author: Elliott N.

description:
Haven't been to such authentic Mexican restaurants for a while!

This place, located in the Mission district on Mission Street, takes advantage of the busy traffic and attracts lots of customers so do expect some wait for an order.

-) Super Size Steak Burrito: A-. $7.25, this super size burrito is not huge but it is super filling to finish the whole thing. When you order, you just need to choose what meat to get and they will automatically put all the toppings for you. Steak was tender; cheese was added with a right amount which enhanced the taste; and the most wonderful thing was the slightly hot sauce + sour cream + the brown rice, they taste super good together! Tortilla was thinly sliced which is good too.

Solid 4-star as my first time experience. I already know what I'm getting next time: Beef Tongue Quesadilla, looking forward already!
author: Simon C.

description:
Every resident of San Francisco has a favorite burrito joint, and that's doubly true for burrito joints in the Mission--disagreements over the best spot can turn into religious holy wars.  Personally, I've been trying to find the best burrito in SF for some time, and was a longtime believer in the excellence of El Farolito.  However, in the battle of La Taqueria vs. El Farolito vs. Taqueria Cancun, Taqueria Cancun has won over my heart (read: stomach).

Al pastor burritos here are a religious experience for me.  Yes, they are that good.  Whether you order the regular or super burrito, you will get a massive amount of food with quality ingredients, but obviously the super burrito is better because of the avocado.

An added plus is that the restaurant itself is larger in size than El Farolito so you're not bumping into other patrons while you wait.  I wish they were open on Tuesdays, but that's the definition of a first world problem.
author: David B.

description:
This place doesn't need anymore reviews. It rocked my life tonight. Total taste explosion. Affordable AND delicious!

I got the super burrito with chicken and black beans. Soooo delicious. Huge! I ate it all. So glad I wore my stretchy pants. Mmm stretchy pants.
author: Sara P.

description:
i would gave this review 3 stars but the place is not clean at all. 

the tables, the floor, dont get me started on the bathroom!!! 

but decoded to give it a try for the high rating. food was good not the best but decent. its just the uncleanness that did it for me. 

probably never coming here again.
author: Tyler G.

description:
So good!!

Get the super tacos. Heck, get anything that is super but be warned, you'll end up giving birth to a baby burrito.
author: Kemi A.

description: This was taco 6 out of 6 on our tour of the best tacos in SF. We ranked this #3. We got the chorizo tacos-- really good flavoring, we were impressed. There are 5 or 6 longer wooden benches where you can take a seat. Salsas were too spicy for me-- mouth was burning afterwards. Would recommend this spot to anyone who wants to gobble down a couple authentic tacos quickly for cheap.
author: Hideko T.

description: Very good food.  I enjoyed the HUGE burrito I got here.  Not a very nice place to sit down and eat but a great place to pick up product and eat elsewhere.
author: Joe M.

description:
If you are nearby the Mission district, chances are that your SF friends have told you to try the infamous Mission burritos. With so many options in the area (i.e. La Taqueria, Farolitos, TLC, etc, etc.) it's hard to know which one to go to. 

Taqueria Cancun has been my go-to Mission burrito place since I moved to SF a month and a half ago. While I could walk a little further down the street to La Taqueria (aka the acclaimed "best burrito in the world"), it's really nice to be able to just sit down in the restaurant and enjoy your food without the chaotic crowds of people surrounding you on all sides (which the typical experience you will have at burrito joints closer to the Mission BART stations). 

Taqueria Cancun has your standard burrito offerings like all other burrito places. $8-9 gets you a standard sized burrito with chips and salsa. I usually get the super burrito with carnitas to satisfy my constant burrito cravings.  

It should be noted that there are two Taqueria Cancun's in the Mission District. I usually go to the Cesar Chavez one since it is much less crowded than the one near 19th St. If you are just going to grab-and-go, either destination is fine, but if you plan on sitting down and enjoying your meal I would definitely recommend the one closer to Cesar Chavez.
author: Derek L.
