description: Had the breakfast burrito. Food came quickly. Tortillas were amazing! Light and doughy. Fun atmosphere.
author: Jason S.

description:
I want to like this place, I really do. Unfortunately, the food does not agree with me. I've been here several times, and each time I've had bad stomach pain several hours after eating and an upset stomach the following day.

That aside, the food has always tasted very good, but not necessarily better than other taquerias in the Mission. It also is always packed with people when everyone's hungry after a night of drinking. Even so, the wait isn't too long.

I couldn't imagine many people wanting to eat here sober because it is pretty dirty. The staff cannot keep up with clearing tables of dirty dishes, nor wiping down the tables after customers have finished eating. That said, what really doesn't make sense is that there doesn't seem to be any trashcans for people to scrape their own plates and throw trash away. Seems like a poor management decision because trash just ends up on the floor instead of in a receptacle. Also, the bathroom is rank.

If this seems like a negative review, that's because it is, but I want to state that I would probably eat here again with friends late at night if my stomach could handle the food. Better luck to you!
author: Jordan G.

description: This place absolutely lives up to the hype. I love burritos, especially authentic ones with rice and beans. Stopped in here on our way to the airport after a wedding. The burrito was literally the most beautiful thing I had laid my eyes on. two nights ago we ate at Thomas Kellers Pop up restaurant, Ad Lib, and my boyfriend said the burrito may have been better than his meal there. This place and burrito are worth the trip... Highly recommend!
author: Molly M.

description:
Best burrito in the city. Forget Taqueria, forget El Farolito, this is the one.

Ingredients distribution: 10/10
Temperature: 10/10
Meat ratio: 10/10
Salsa: 10/10
Chips w/ burrito: 10/10
Avocado chunks: 10/10
Size: 11/10
author: Joe H.

description:
Taqueria Cancún is authentic Mexican, from the bright and colorful interior to the ginormous burritos. 

The carne asada burrito I got for a measly $7 was filled with meat, beans, rice, and all that other stuff you've come to grow and love. The salsa's got just the right amount of kick to it, and everything is fresh. Well, everything except for the chips -- what's up with that?

I just wish they offered more meat and less beans. Just seems like they're cheaping out for the sake of cheaping out.
author: Casey S.

description:
Smack in the middle of The Mission, Taqueria Cancun sports some of The City's best burritos.

With wooden tables and benches, faux brick walls, and adobe tiled floors, Taqueria Cancun screams "burrito joint" from the moment you enter. The menu holds no surprises, and none are missed. When you wander into this dive, you want a burrito, taco, or quesadilla, straight up with no frills.

The regular burrito ($6.25) features rice, beans, onion, cilantro, salsa, and your choice of meat. The standard meats are well represented: carne asada, pollo, carnitas, and veggie are on hand. There is also lengua (beef tongue), cabeza (beef head), and sesos (beef brains) for the more adventurous. The super ($7.25) adds cheese, avocado, and sour cream. Since it is included as a separate ingredient, the cilantro overtones may be too much for some diners, while others may find it pleasant. 

The carne asada super burrito was sizable (not epic, but still large), and there was a good mix of ingredients throughout, making each bite a multi-taste pleasure. Taqueria Cancun burritos have a higher steak to filler ratio than El Farolito, and the tortillas are griddled rather than steamed, providing ample differentiation between the two big Kahunas of Mission burritos. 

Though the tortilla chips are complimentary, but there is no salsa bar. Rather salsa is doled out by the cashier in tiny, miserly plastic cups. As in any good Mission burrito joint, there is a myriad of well priced domestic and Mexican beers, Mexican and regular sodas, and aguas frescas.

Yes, the lines can be long, but they move quickly. Yes, it's cash only. Yes, it can be smokey at times.  What else would you expect from one of the quintessential burrito joints in The City.
author: CJ G.

description: Burrito was great - very filling and didn't skimp on the carne asada or the avocado. The chips were not my jam - they tasted cheap and stale.
author: Amy R.

description: Taqueria Cancun is always highly rated, for good reason. I've been though almost the entire menu except for sesos (brains). The best item is the burrito Mojado, a  burrito covered in enchilada sauce and salsa. It's enough for two people and under 10 bucks.
author: Alexander S.

description:
Looks like I have a new favorite burrito spot in town. 

I eat a fair share of burritos and have no plans to stop, and this place rocks it. Super burrito with carne asada: fresh quac and salsa, mexican rice, refried beans, solid steak under $10 in San Francisco? Yes please. 

Not much to add here, stop reading reviews and go to this place.
author: Bud P.

description:
The first time I came here, the super quesadillas were unreal. I dreamed about them every night till I returned about six months later...

Maybe my taste buds weren't as alcohol-induced? The quesadilla was still damn good but it doesn't compare to the ones at El Farolito.

Still not by any means bad, but chips and salsa could definitely use some work.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
In competition with Sancho's Taqueria for best burrito in SF area. If you're looking to maximize the experience, bring Sancho's exxxtra hot sauce, and you may have just made the best burrito north of LA.

Super Carne Asada Burrito: 9/10
author: Rahim H.

description: Got the al pastor classic super dank burrito. Burrito time A super plus yeah. Chips + salsas are nice too.
author: Dan C.

description: The super burrito and burrito mojado are both fantastic. The various meat options are all incredibly flavorful and juicy. I'm partial to the al pastor, though I haven't yet tried the chicken or vegetarian options. The rice stops it from getting too watery, which can happen at La Taqueria when you mix all that sour cream and guacamole without any rice.
author: Dayton T.

description: When I had a bite of the al pastor super taco I was blown away!!! I've never tried a taco that tasted anything like it. I ordered a regular carne asada taco and one al pastor super taco and I definitely recommend al pastor over carne asada it has more flavor. Also the super tacos are pretty filling so if you get full fast like me I recommend you to only get one super taco first and then see if you have room for another one. This place gets packed so if you are with a group(5people or more) it will probably be hard to get a table for everyone. And this place is cash only!!!
author: Joselyn Z.

description:
You know how people say that Mexican food in Cali is far superior to any Mexican food they've had on the East coast? I get it now. I really really do. Super taco with steak and regular nachos covered in magical cheese. My husband's pork burrito was equally amazing.

Great, now I'm going to crave something that I don't have access to on a daily basis. Probably the best for my waistline.

Dee-licious.
author: Shu Jin S.

description: Been to a few spots on misson this is my favorite one the food is so good and the staff works hard and fast always packed but worth the wait
author: Sac M.

description:
Yum yum.  $2.50 + $.99 for tostada de ceviche with extra avocado.  If you know what's up, you'll get two of these plus an agua fresca.  The ceviche is flavorful and refreshing with fresh avocado and lots of fish.

I tried the burritos here and they are also pretty good.  Good backup to El Farolito!
author: Kathleen W.

description:
Taqueria Cancun is a premier SF Mission burrito.  Great value, good size, excellent composition and mix.  Ingredients are quality also.  They are known for the shrimp super burrito.  A salsa bar would take this place to the next level. 

The other location in Bernal Heights is also known to be top tier.
author: Tom F.

description:
My friend insisted that I should go down to the Mission to taste some of the best Mexican food in SF.  So I gave in and strolled along. 

The atmosphere is that of a typical hole in the wall place. I figured the food would be descent just based upon it's appearance. The prices were average but the food was delicious! I was honestly shocked by the powerful flavors within their meats and other dishes. 

The quesadilla was filling, flavorful and fantastic! Well-priced and authentic!
author: Becky W.

description: Absolutely delicious. I got the super burrito with chicken and it was the best Mexican food I've had in a long time. They also gave complimentary chips which were delicious. I have a low spice tolerance and it came with some spicy salsa. It hurt so good. If you're ever near the 16 St. Bart station I recommend coming here!
author: Ray K.

description:
As a newbie to SF, I was guided here by my older brother. I've grown up listening to his sound advice and have yet to be disappointed. (This includes the decision to grab a burrito here!)

I had never experience the Mission, but was excited to see a new part of the city. We walked along, unsure exactly where to go, but knowing we would eventually find the place he had "the most amazing burrito ever!". Now, as east coast Canadians, we know practically nothing of what a "good burrito" is, but I am quite certain I can say with confidence, this place has them! They have much more than this as well, we went with the vegetarian option with beans and pretty much everything else! They are HUGE and very well priced! You can also get taco's and many different meat options. When you order they also give you some chips and salsa while you wait...Delish!

The wall paintings are also something worth the visit. They are brightly coloured amazing illustrations that just make the experience more enjoyable. The men working there were nice and fast, getting you ordered and served in no time!

I would definitely recommend going, maybe check out a map first if you have never been, as to not waste ANY time getting there!
author: Jacqueline N.

description:
Its hard to beat el farolito or taqueria san jose... taqueria cancun is as good as it gets....

Quantity of food 
Price
Quality / freshness / taste
Service / quickness
Cleanliness

And i gotta give em thumbs up for their decoration.. bright yellow happy colors with the mexican party decorations all over the place.. very colorful without over-doing it...

We ordered a regular burrito and a super quesadilla.. she couldnt finish half her quesadilla and my little donkey was FRESH... just perfectly balanced.. not too wet.. not too dry.. just yummy..  with 2 large horchatas the bill came up to be $25 and we were outta there in half an hour.
author: Wankalows E.

description: I brought my kiddos here while on a field trip and we enjoyed our stop, but I guess I just didn't see what the fuss was about. The burritos are huge but they're not cheap. The salsas are good but I feel like I've had better. The al pastor didn't blow me away. Honestly for me this was a pretty forgettable burrito, but I will say that their ratios of fillings are pretty spot on. I got a good mouthful of beans, rice, tortilla, meat, avocado and other yummy things in every bite.
author: Bethany A.

description:
OH. MY. HEAVENLINESS. 

This place is the best of the best when it comes to cheap, street Mexican food. It's so authentic and I loved the vibe. 

I ordered a super quesadilla and was very, very impressed. I could only eat one half and took the other home for a second meal! It was a measly $8 total and came with chips and salsa.

They were pretty busy at the time, yet our food took about 5 minutes to come out. My boyfriend said his burrito was one of the best in the city and for the price (about $7-8), it's almost a crime not to go there! Way better than Papalote food & prices......sorry!

I love supporting hard-working people. If only there was one closer to my house...
author: Alyssa H.

description: Today I went to this lovely place having a wonderful moment in my life. My aunt ordered Wet burrito with Beef and everything in it. It was so Mexico!! I totally into the chilly tomato sauce and the whole favor. F* tasty! It won't be my last time definitely!!
author: Jacob S.

description:
I've been slowly making my way through the taquerias in the Mission . . . Taqueria Cancun was next on my list and i had heard great things about it.  I had a carne asada super burrito with everything on it. I just have to have sour cream, guac/avocado, and cheese - the good stuff! Their regular burrito only comes with meat, rice, beans, and onions. It's not too expensive in the first place so I wouldn't fret about having to order the higher priced burrito anyways.  For less than 7 bucks i had a large burrito packed with delicious carne asada. Every order comes with chips and salad. Woohoo! 

Good, but doesn't beat El Farolito.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Everyone raves about this place but I'm not picking up on what the hype is all about :\ Maybe their burritos are better than their tacos, but the pastor didn't have quite the kick that I've come to expect from the Taco trucks of Fruitvale. 
The tacos were $2.90 per, which seems steep compared to the truck tacos, but you get way more meat so it definitely evens out. I got 4 tacos and felt like I'd eaten 8 by the time I was done, so definitely a decent deal as far as money goes.
author: Casey C.

description:
My friend has been recommending this place cos it's his favourite burrito resto.

Really good food and great fast service. The price is just right and the portion size is great. 

They also have bottled Coca-cola imported all the way from Mexico. 

Tips:
- avoid busy hours as it gets full easily

This is definitely not my last visit.
author: Alliv S.

description:
Quesadillas as big as a burrito. 

That's my kind of quesadilla!
author: Jess C.

description: Got the carnitas super burrito, it's pretty big so I over ate but it was so good I didn't notice how full I was until after. The line gets pretty long but it moves fast and there's enough seating so I didn't have to wait to sit down. I like this place better than el farolito down the street.
author: Solomon G.

description:
It's in a bit of a shady neighborhood, but for casual food without reservations, Taqueria Cancun cannot be beat.

We walked into fluorescent lighting and picnic bench seating.  Got into line and saw HUGE piles of dried whole peppers in the back.  One of the kitchen staff was de-stemming the peppers into a 32 gallon plastic bin (like the ones used for trash).  This place is for real!

The super taco with Carne Asada and Carnitas were amazing.  Juicy, tender, supreme flavor. 

With food like this, no wonder all sorts of people, including guys in suits, show up in this inconspicuous joint in a slightly shady-looking neighborhood!
author: Kathryn C.

description: Best vegetarian burrito in the world. The way they toast it slightly on the outside is the key. The fresh avocado is great every time. Granted, I haven't been here in a while, but I have yet to find a better veggie burrito anywhere in California.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Tony and Candace T. would rather save a few bucks by eating at the far inferior El Farolito.  I would rather eat the best tasting burrito in the mission.  This place has it.  El Farolito is bland as hell.  Seriously, who cares if they have avocado when their meat tastes like it has had zero seasoning at all.

Don't waste your time elsewhere.  This is it.

Get it dorado style and they'll crisp up the outside on the grill after they throw it together.
author: Rob H.

description:
Vegan burrito (Veggie burrito minus cheese minus sour cream plus jalapeños) and a bottle of pacifico beer and I'm a happy man !
 
Brilliant flavors , colorful place , friendly staff, very reasonably price . The salsa tastes different(read way better) here than commercial taco/burrito joints.
author: Jinesh S.

description: Hands down best quick Mexican food in SF. Better than anything I've had in LA too. Unreal. Super Nachos! Super Burrito!
author: Niles L.

description:
Cancun City: Resort beach town located in South-East Mexico. It has taquerias in Cancun.. I think.

Taqueria Cancun: Restaurant located in the Mission serving some of the most legit Mexican food in SF. Located near the 16th and Mission Bart stop, this is an ideal place to satisfy your hungries, munchies, and drunchies by devouring some super tacos, nachos, burritos, quesadillas.. Pretty much anything on the menu because they're all SO BOMB. 

My go-to is the Al Pastor Super Burrito which is loaded with delicious goodness. Usually I'd list what "deliciousness" includes but I can't even put it in words because of how good it is. Just go and order one. You'll thank me later.

Other notes:
- Cash only so holla' at them dolla's before you arrive
- Legit late night joint. Don't be afraid of the questionable characters in this establishment. Just don't get in between them and their Super Burritos
- I really like the salsa verde that comes with the FREE CHIPS
- Serves beer
author: Chris W.

description: I think this place is really a hit or miss depending on what you order. I usually order Lengua at mexican restaurants but find the lengua here to be mediocre. My friends swear that the Al pastor burrito is good, so I'd have to try that next time. Portion for burritos is huge, so come here if you want your bang for your buck. Good place to hang out late at night with friends if you're around the area and need a midnight snack!
author: Michelle O.

description: This is the mission burrito. My girlfriend and I visited here as soon as we got in. It was the only place open, and boy I am sure glad it was our only option. It was not a dense burrito but the flavor of my chorizo was spicy as my girlfriends attitude. Everything was good but I would not taking a dump here is my only concern. Take it to go and compliment it with a nice episode of "Better Call Saul" episode 3 of season 2
author: Willem H.

description:
One of the fabled trifecta-Taqueria Cancun, La Taqueria, El Foralito, when it comes to Mexican food in the City. 

Based on items I've tried, Taq Cancun is better than El Foralito but worse than La Taq.

Their Al pastor is bomb!!
author: DJ R.

description: Vegetarian burrito was delicious, and massive, and comes with a side of corn chips.Win
author: Emily S.

description: 20 years and counting still the best damn burrito in the city. Glad to see some things ddint change.
author: Kenneth S.

description: I'm only just beginning to start making my way to taquerias for tacos and burritos in the Mission, but I was so happy this place got recommended. I love the laid back atmosphere, the uncomplicated but wide menu, and the delicious food. It was cheap, it was great, and it was fast. No complaints!
author: David B.

description: INCREDIBLE SHRINKING  BURRITO!!! Burrito Mojado has shrunk by 1/4 from previously. No longer worth it. Coming here for 5 years. I always order Burrito Mojado  price was $6.50 is now $8.25 for Pork or chicken.  Not sure why they need to cut back on beans and rice.
author: Will L.

description:
This is definitely a great spot for getting some Mexican food, and it's even better when you're drunk. (You might regret it in the morning though). Solid 3.5 stars.

First, this is between civic center station and powell station. You can get off either stop and walk here. When you walk in, you'll notice it's a little cramped with limited seating. Hopefully you came with a friend who can save a seat, though, the few times I've been, it was never really super crowded.

You order at the counter and get a complementary chips and salsa. However, there is no salsa bar, and they definitely do NOT give enough salsa for the chips. You either have to keep going up to ask for more salsa, which is annoying, or order a wet burrito, and just scoop the parts of the burrito that fall out. 

The burritos here are huge and are definitely very filling. They are loaded up with pretty much everything at a reasonable price! I have not tried their tacos though.

+2 for making hefty burritos
+2 for great tastes
+1 easy to get to / convenience
-1 for no chips and salsa bar
-0.5 being so cramped
+0 for the grungy-ness of the place, a little dirt and homeless people hanging out never hurt anyone (maybe except in the TL).
+0 for hours. I wish they would open later for when I finish drinking at 1am or 2am.

Solid 3.5 stars, recommended and will return for good food.
author: Kaje Y.

description:
I really hate to be the one to do this, but I didn't really feel too strongly about this burrito. I had the mojado burrito which is the one with the enchilada sauce, crema and salsa on the outside. I don't really eat my burritos with meat (maybe why they don't taste as good?) so I got this sans the carne and added avocado because it doesn't come with it. This thing is unbelievably huge for the $6 price tag. Even though the service was great and the guys were not, I have to say the inside of the burrito was pretty bland. Like I said, this was probably due to the fact that I didn't get any meat in it, but so what? It should taste good anyway. As an aside, the tortilla itself was heaven. It tasted so fresh! I also got the horchata for a buck and change and it was sooooooooo sweet!! A little too sweet for me, but really good nonetheless.

The recommendation for this place came from a girlfriend who's Mexican and grew up in Mexico City (but lives here now) and says that this is the most authentic place she's encountered. So, if you're looking for authenticity, give it a try. I'm still going to shop around for some other places (El Farolito is next!).
author: Amanda C.

description: Perfect quick bite. Ordered  wet Burrito mojado.  It has lots of fillings (beans and rice) Wish it could have more meat inside!
author: Carrie Z.

description:
This is my favorite place for a burrito. $5.41 including tax for a killer veggie burrito loaded with avocado and sour cream. Free chips with two excellent spicy salsas. Don't leave San Francisco without trying a classic Mission burrito!

Update: comes to about $7 for a vegetarian burrito now but still the best deal in town. Their chips could be improved but the burritos and salsas are top notch
author: Matthew G.

description:
So we stopped here based on other reviews and we're from Atlanta.  It was ok but we actually have better Mexican places back home.  The chorizo didn't have much flavor.  We're more a fan of black beans since they don't get as mealy.  The salsa was a bit bland.  Love the atmosphere though.  So we're checking this off the list because we don't need to come back. 
  We've also been to Mexico twice and when the street stands there are better you're eating city Mexican food.
author: Brian H.

description: We paid $30 dollars for three burritos- drove 40 minutes round trip- two burritos in the bag. don't care to comment on how the food tasted because I'm so annoyed
author: Marisa R.

description: Honestly, it is open so LATE and thank god. My drunk brain thought the food was alright, but honestly, can't beat the great hours.
author: Swati R.

description:
As much as I wanted to be, I wasn't that impressed during my visit. Granted, it was post bar so Cancun was packed full of idiots (and of course, you can't hold that against them.) But my veggie burrito just wasn't that flavorful. It was big and cheap, I'll give them that. But I feel like I would have liked it more if I de-constructed it and added a bunch of sauce to it. And some more veggies. And some tofu.

Sorry, I guess I'm just not that into authentic taqueria food.
author: Jon T.

description:
Things of note:

-the large horchata / ague fresca is really large. think big gulp.
-both red and green salsas are super spicy. it lights my mouth on fire every time and I just keep it coming.
-the distribution of sour cream and guac on the burrito mojado is not even across the whole length.
- the al pastor is my favorite meat here for tacos and burrito mojado, closely followed by the carne asada.
author: Jennifer W.

description: After a summer of traveling, the first thing I wanted when I got back to California was a Mission Burrito and this place delivered! Full of flavor, it was exactly what this Bay Area girl needed!
author: Carol G.

description:
After a long night of club hopping in the Mission, my buddies and I needed some sustenance before the journey home.  Mexican food is perfect after a few drinks and we ducked into the first joint we saw on the strip.

I ordered the carne asada super burrito which had great flavor and the meat was perfectly seasoned.  It was a pretty heavy thing with all the fixin's and really hit the spot.  I later found out that they were nominated as the best burrito in the city 10 year's running, so that's a pretty damn good endorsement.

I'm not sure it's the BEST burrito I've found in the city, but it's definitely up there.  Service was speedy even on a busy Saturday night and it looks like it's a favorite of clubgoers.  I'd definitely rely on Taqueria Cancun to calm my cravings and I highly recommend it.

Food: 8/10

Service: 8/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description: Delicious tacos....fresh and very flavorful.  Good service too.
author: Dave R.

description: We came here for the burritos everyone is raving about, and ended up with burritos that are, yes, pretty good.  In comparing Taqueria Cancun to other traditional Mexican spots around the country, I think they are just okay.  We had quick and friendly service (although they mislabeled which burrito was which), and the price was okay.  This just wasn't a blow it out of the park experience that I thought after all of the hype.
author: Stacy H.

description: No way... Came here around noon... Had tacos de asada, lengua, and pollo... All were gross. Service was good.
author: David F.

description: Cheap authentic Mexican food at very affordable prices.  Taqueria Cancun is the perfect place to go after a night our drinking in the Mission.  I like getting the wet super burrito or the burrito mojado which is smothered in red sauce. YUM!  You know you got something good when you bring your food to your table and it makes people's head turn.  I love it when you're food tastes as good as it looks.  People seem to eat and go so although seating might be limited, the probability that you'll get a seat is pretty high.  At least it was for me every time I visited.  Yes you get the occassional crack head/homeless person coming in every now and then, but hey, everyone's gotta eat.
author: Christine D.

description:
When in the Mission I normally go to El Farolito.  However, a friend recently introduced me to Cancun', and I almost forgot about Farolito'.  

The fatassery was in full effect, as I ordered a half chicken-half asada burrito AND a asada quesadilla.  I had just got done watching the Seahawks and Niners game and needed some comfort since the Niners lost.  Don't judge me, haha.

Both selections were quite tasty.  The burrito's rice to meat ratio was skewed though.  They definitely use the rice here as filler and skimp on the rest.  The cheese in the quesadilla was gooey, creamy, and delicious!  The salsas here are fresh, full bodied, and spicy (I love it)!  

The reason I choose Taqueria Cancun over El Farolito is because the flavors and seasoning are better here.  Farolito' has this one dimensional taste to it, there isn't as much depth or flavor.  This place is definitely worth checking out if you want some awesome Mexican food!
author: Josh S.

description: Bought 2 super burritos. They not only got my order wrong, but the burritos were cold...major fail. Added a star for the chips, but $20 wasted...
author: Hanna R.

description:
I moved to SF 3 years ago and on that fateful day, FEB. 21st 2013 my heart sank into the half  quesadilla in my pocket. 

I will forever love you Taqueria Cancun. You always make me feel like family no matter the meal!
author: Ashana D.

description:
This is a great place. It's my second favorite taqueria in San Francisco.  It's almost always packed so don't make the mistake I have and show up starving... It can take quite a while to get your food! 

I usually get the carne asada super burrito and I always ask for the tortilla to be toasted. It's pretty fantastic. They also give you free chips which is getting to be pretty rare in the city! However, the last time I was there they were giving out salsa in pre-packed little containers which kinda sucks-- I prefer choosing my own as El Farolito allows as do many other places. 

Still, it's a classic and it's pretty damn good.
author: Jen K.

description: I went because it had really good reviews bt honestly it didn't live up to the hype at all. I went last night ,I got burrito mojado. It sucked, really sucked, way too much salt. worst burrito I had in sf by far.
author: Jeffrey A.

description:
I'm pretty sure this is my favorite place to get a burrito when I'm drunk.  Aside from being a lively place to finish off a weekend night, the food is really good.  The most flavorful selections of meats!  

I had the Carne Asada super burrito, and I don't usually get super, but here everything is sooo good together you can't pass it up, and slices of avocado!   The carne asada nachos some girl offered me were really good too (hey, if they are cute enough to make out with, its okay to share food, haha).  

Their drinks are also really good!  I had the melon juice, and i could taste the cantaloupe and honey dew in there, sooo good and fresh!  

The place has a line, but it moves fast, you'll probably get your food before you find a table.
author: Veasna H.

description: Taqueria Cancun is a solid place to go for burritos. I have stopped by here twice to get burritos on my way to Dolores park. Their carne asada super burrito is quite good. They also give you free chips and salsa to take with!
author: Sarah K.

description:
When you go to a Taqueria, this is what you expect!  
Great authentic Mexican food at a very reasonable price. I've been coming here since high school in the eighties and the prices haven't changed much at all.
You don't come here for foodie fare like Cranberry Habanero Chutney for chrissakes... you get a Burrito Mojado that can practically feed a family of four. Hit this place up before or after a club and you won't regret it.
author: Lee N.

description: Suuuuper tasty! And such a great price for the food given! Their enchiladas are solid and you can get them with different meats- not just chicken or beef!
author: Liz F.

description:
The Al-pastor was delicious! Well marinated, balanced nicely with onion and cilantro.  

The chips and salsa are yummy, the salsa was super spicy but  tasty. 

The service is quick and the staff is nice.

The restrooms were not very clean though.
author: Rachael S.

description:
There are many taquerias in San Francisco. In my opinion, this is just another one of them. While it does seem to be authentic at its roots, it has a pretty generic (and limited) menu, and a production-line feel. They do the classic dishes alright, but you can't find anything new.... or healthy.What they do offer is pretty good.  

The interior is sort of dingy, lined with picnic tables - which works well for big groups of bar-hoppers or late night crews, but I certainly wouldn't reccomend it for a date. The price is right and the food is decent, but you could definitely do better if you care to look around.
author: Catie F.

description: Best Tacos and most valuable I ever had! Highly recommend: Carnitas (Fried Pork) or Lengua (Beef Tongue). Best to go with Corona (added with a hint of lime)
author: E T.

description:
I have been on the search for a great burrito place since I moved here.  I was recommended this place by many people, and I finally made it here.  I was impressed right away.  I got in line and there was a guy chopping a ton of onions.  This told me that the food was made fresh in house.  I got the regular burrito with carnitas and sour cream.  It came with rice, beans, salsa, onions, cilantro and your choice of meat. This is the best burrito I found in SF!  And it's under $10!

The burrito also comes with chips and salsa.  The chips are definitely home made.  The green salsa, which is also the salsa in the burrito, has chunks of avocado in it.

Note:  Bring Cash!!  This is a cash only restaurant.
author: Rose Z.

description: Sauces were a bit too salty for my huge carne asada burrito but still delicious! Also seriously where else can you still get such a huge burrito for ~$10?
author: Mingmei N.

description:
I can never be unhappy with a burrito right in front of me and
I'm sure everything else here is ten times better than my vegetarian burrito with no rice. Nevertheless, this place will be one of my go to taqueria spots.
author: Lisa T.

description:
I was really excited to eat at this place because I was extremely hungry and am always in the mood for some good Mexican food. 
Waited in line and was able to get a table pretty quickly. 
I got the al pastor burrito and was able to try some of my friend's ceviche. The ceviche was good but wasn't as good as some other places I like back in LA. The burrito was super dry. I felt like there was way more beans than there was meat. I ordered an al pastor burrito and wanted as much meat as I can get but it was disappointing.
author: Dayae K.

description:
I was told this place was voted one of the best places to grab a burrito in the city and in the US.  Keep in mind, and I don't drink much at all, but I was full blown blasted at around 2AM.  I probably could have been shoveled hot coals down my throat and I would have been happy.

Pros - barbacoa burrito was dumbo good, line moves quick and relatively efficient considering they are dealing with tons of drunks
Cons - location sucks for taxis.  Uber can be the only option depending on when you go
author: Chris S.

description:
My standard for juicy carne asada burritos has always been El Farolito which do just about everything right. I think this place is my new favorite.

When the guy making your burrito doesn't even bother asking you about what you want in your burrito and makes it the only way they know how to make it, you got to take a hint and be like aite, there's a good reason for this. Don't be picky, just get the carne asada burrito, your taste buds won't regret it.

Be mindful, there's no salsa bar so some people might not like that since its a staple fixture of any taqueria in the Mission & the chips served are kinda underwhelming.

I've also tried the tacos, they're alright. Do what's right just get the carne asada burrito, skip everything else.
author: Steven C.

description: I ordered super burrito with avocado. Paid extra for avocado. When I got it I verified with the guy there was avocado in it. Sure enough get home and there is no avocado. I should have checked when there but wanted to keep it warm... It's good but still rude
author: Jason M.

description: The food is really good, but getting the order correctly has been a repeated problem.
author: Peyton P.

description: Dutch guy here. Never had burrito's till i came to the states. Gotta say this is one of the best burrito's i've ever had. I took the CHicken chipotle burrito btw :)
author: Coen L.

description: My favorite tacos this far in the mission.  Usually I like carne asada best, but here the carnitas tacos are the most delicious.  I love to get them to go and eat them in Dolores Park.
author: Jacqueline R.

description:
Nate Silver lied.

http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-burrito-brackets-first-round-comes-to-a-close-with-a-major-upset/
author: Marisol S.

description: My home away from home. Love the veggie taco and ceviche tostada, my go to meals. Their black beans, frijoles negros, are very yummy, and they are always generous with the avocado on the veggie tacos.  The chips, while better than some, leave something to be desired, on more than one occasion I get home and they are stale. otherwise, 5 stars, much love for this place.
author: Coco J.

description:
I got the most amazing, cheesy and melty enchiladas here! I would highly recommend the beef enchilada plate, which includes 2 huge enchiladas along with beans (very smoothly mashed up) and some other side that I don't recall. But everything on that large plate was delicious, and I usually don't even like beans. It was my first time ordering enchiladas at a restaurant and I was so impressed. They were soft and hot, which was perfect because that night was super cold and rainy. They had fully melted, soft cheese on them and were filled with yummy ground beef that was juicy and delicious. Just writing about them makes me crave them. 

The service was good, the food came out really quickly and the water is self serve.  They have plenty of seats inside and also open relatively late.  The restaurant is in a slightly shady location and the ambience was nothing special.  However, I would definitely go back for those enchiladas!
author: Kailin H.

description:
The San Francisco Mission district is arguably *the* place to get the best Mexican food in the country, and with so many excellent options within a 6-block radius, picking one taqueria and labeling it as "the best" is just not possible. The one thing I can say without hesitation is that Cancun has the best salsa and tortilla chips of the bunch, no contest. Both salsas indulge your tastebuds with exploding flavor and just the right degree of spiciness and sourness - it is unmatched. I always order extra.
But that is not to say that the burritos and quesadillas are anything short of spectacular. In fact, the only reason I didn't 5-star this place is the quality of meat cuts they use (too much chewy little chunks of fat), but alas, such is the standard at this price point.
Expect very long lines on weekend nights.
author: Abdel H.

description: Shared a mix of the chicken and carne super burrito w/ my mommy. It was good but I cannot say it's my favorite Mexican spot in SF.. We ordered to go so maybe I should dine in next time for a proper experience!
author: Michelle L.

description: They make burritos the RIGHT way here. Fresh, moist, delicious and oozing with the flavors of Latin American cuisine. On par with El Farolito. Huge portion for a $7.25 super burrito that can definitely satisfy two people. We ordered a steak and a beef tongue/marinated pork mix. The steak was amazing perfectly cooked and full of flavors. The mixed lingua/pastor was a little spicy with the meat marinated in a special sauce with cilantro. There was definitely more rice/beans than meat in the burritos which make up the bulk. Service was fast, friendly and the atmosphere was lively. While we were eating there was a guitar guy playing Spanish music. It was great. Overall another great burrito joint. Highly recommended. We went for brunch on a cold day and what we got did not disappoint. Bueno!
author: Hua T.

description: I think I like El Farolito better but I was pleasantly surprised by Taqueria Cancun. I ordered a carne asada taco especial (with all the fixin's including avocado) and it was delicious. The meat was perfectly cooked and the taco was bigger and heartier than I was expecting. The tacos come with 2 tortillas and so much stuffing that you can actually make 2 tacos from a single order. I'm a genius, huh? This place is YUM!
author: Denise H.

description:
During my five year survey, Taqueria Cancun has declined in quality slowly but surely. First they reduced the salsa serving cups from 3 oz to 1.5 oz which they only filled halfway. You need at least three green salsas to adequately spice up a burrito. Then they hired this cranky old guy who rolls misshapen burritos with gaps and uneven ingredient distribution.

For a couple years, things remained stable -- ask for extra salsa, go somewhere else when cranky was rolling -- but then the decline accelerated. They painted over the glass sneeze guard through which you were once able to watch your burrito being prepared. That is a highly suspect move! And they've put up a sign which states they soon will no longer be open on Tuesdays. Why? It's packed every single night.

Today I ordered my old favorite -- the shrimp burrito. At its best it's crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside, shrimp drippings mixing with sour cream to form a delicious orange mess. Needless to say, today was a let down. My $9.10 shrimp burrito contained only five 35-count shrimp and a disproportionate load of black beans and rice. It was a sad burrito.

What happened? Meat prices gone up? Health insurance biting into profits? I hope there is some reasonable justification for the continual push to cut costs, but nevertheless: Taqueria Cancun, your day has passed.
author: Jeremiah B.

description:
One of the best burritos I've eaten. I got a super burrito with carne asada and carnitas. Like most mission-style burritos, one of the best parts is the variety of flavor in every bite. Some bites are more of a black bean, rice, and guacamole burrito, while some are heavier on the carne asada and spicy salsa. It makes the entire experience unique and tasty because it doesn't get old. 

The place is pretty busy every time I've seen it: noon, 3pm, 10pm-- they serve great burritos and folks know it.

Cash only--so come prepared.
author: Neal C.

description: This taqueria is excellent. The food is affordable, tasty, and the service is fast. On the weekends, there's often a line but it moves quickly.  The burritos and tacos are generously sized, making for a filling lunch or dinner.  Out of the many mission taquerias, this place stands out.
author: Nicholas K.

description:
This place is historically overhyped. The five three eight "best burrito in America" award boggles my mind. Without exaggeration: This isn't even the best burrito on mission St within a one block radius. Do yourself a favor and skip this one. El farolito is much better, or better yet, La Palma mexicatessen on 24th.  

Problems I had with this burrito:
The rice is mooshy, tasteless, and ends up clumped together for nasty rice only bites. If you are going to put rice in a burrito, it had better be good
The tortilla is stale and it's texture was papery. It should be chewy like a crepe! (LA Palma does this well) 
It was way too spicy(seriously what's with this? I can always add hot sauce if I want it hotter) 
The beans were tasteless and added way too much water to the burrito. 

The good :
The meat was very well seasoned
I can't think of anything else :(

This place would only be a good idea if you were drunk.  It redefines over hyped, and it makes me sad to see them get so much love in the press. There's plenty of better mom and pop Mexican joints serving up great food, who struggle to keep afloat while these jokers get all the love. I don't understand and I hope that you, seasoned yelp reader, will be savvy enough to ignore the hype and be more adventurous on your quest for delicious burritos.
author: Yan L.

description:
I've been an adventurous eater for a long time.  So I got the seso and the cabeza.  Yes, beef brain and beef head.  Cabeza was OK, not as good as lengua.  But seso looked and tasted pretty much like what you'd expect, and I don't mean that as a good thing.

So why four stars?  Because the quesadilla and burrito tortillas are toasted just right (with butter or lard maybe?) and the non-seso non-cabeza meats are wonderful.  Go for al pastor.  It's the Mexican version of that red Korean marinated pork.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Was seriously disappointed by the tacos here after seeing all the positive Yelp reviews. 

Our tacos were super sloppy. That's not how it should be. Slathered in salsa? No thanks. Tortillas were not great, and we could barely discern the meat (pastor and asada) with all the crap they put on them. 

Flavor overall was alright. If I went back, I'd definitely ask to have my tacos "dry". Typically, in authentic Mexican restaurants "everything" means cilantro and onions. Salsa on the side, please.

Tortilla chips did not seem like they were house-made. 

Customer service was non-existant, but I won't hold that against them. A dive's a dive. Too bad the food doesn't make up for it.
author: Robert K.

description:
After a day in Dolores park, we headed here for some pork pollo and carne asada SUPER TACOS. They are called super for a reason. They are, in fact, super. And there is no thesaurus definition that could justifiably describe them otherwise. 

I think it was something like $3.50 for a super taco, and $2.50 for a regular taco, which is kind of unheard of...for edible food, never mind something super. 

Lurve. Will definitely be back when I'm in the mood for some super duper tacos.
author: Ellie W.

description:
Yummy taqueria but very average Mission St food.  I had 2 al pastor tacos. The meat was just ok. Al pastor is usually slow roasted w pineapple juices dripping down on the meat which makes it quite flavorful but this one was just ok. The tacos were hooked up w meat so that's good. I also had a side of rice and beans which were pretty good. My friend ordered a mojado carne asada burrito. It was huge and he LOVED it so I guess a burrito is the way to go! 

This spot is known in the city tho. And it is tasty. You really can't beat it for a late night bite. They stay open SUPER LATE.
author: Cynthia Q.

description: Burrito wasn't good as it looks. It was very crowded after 10pm. My friends got tacos, which looked good. The place is not big so you need to kinda hustle to get a table.
author: Tsubomi N.

description:
One of the best tacos I've had in my life, hands-down. I got the carne asada super taco and the carnitas super taco. I wish I could give the carne asada super tacos a 6/5 star rating because it went above and beyond my expectations. I've never had anything so delicious in my life. The carnitas didn't compare to the deliciousness of the carne asada but it was still good. My friend got a super burrito and my boyfriend got the enchilada and those were delicious as well. 

Line was long but it moves pretty quickly. They only take cash so be sure to go to the ATM beforehand if you don't want to be charged for ATM fees within the restaurant. Don't use the bathroom. Seriously, it's disgusting. So disgusting to the point that they even covered their health score.
author: Hana K.

description:
Word of Warning: The second that it gets dark, everyone from Dolores comes here. Expect some major lines on weekends, but partly because this place is a very solid post Day-in-Dolores taco place. 

For some reason I really enjoy watching my food cook in front of me. Make it is just seeing the raw ingredients become something so deliciously palatable. Or maybe I don't trust people want to see how fresh it is. Regardless, the food at Cancun is as fresh as can be as I watched it all prepared in front me me. I got a carnitas burrito, and I'd say that I could have probably saved what I had left for breakfast the next day. Incredibly generous portions, in my opinion.

A small touch that I particularly liked is that they cook the tortilla in such a way that they make it a touch crispy. It gave the burrito a texture a bit closer to a quesadilla, but I really enjoyed it. I've had enough burritos in my lifetime that it can be fun to see someone mix it up a bit.
author: Jake B.

description:
My first taste of a "Mission burrito" occurred at this establishment in 2008 when walking around the neighborhood. Little did I know that 6 years later, it has still held up to be my gold standard burrito. I tried other popular joints like El Farolito and the so-called "best burrito in America" at La Taqueria, but Cancun has got to be by far my favorite. The tortilla wrap has a great texture and really flakey. The rice has a hint of lime that tastes awesome with the avocado. Although there have been times where the avocado was not distributed evenly, I learned that you can add in extra avocado for free! And it lowers your chance of having avo only on one side of your burrito. I have come here both drunk and sober countless of times, and either way this place is amazing. I am also thankful for that "best burrito" place directing the crowd over to La Taqueria as I can now stroll in and get my favorite burrito with a shorter wait time! 

UPDATE: I came back here after I wrote this review and discovered that they'll be closed every Tuesday starting on October 21st. Is this the beginning of the end?? Rumor has it their lease will be expiring :(.
author: Nancy C.

description:
I like Taqueria Cancún. It's not mind blowing nor is it close, but it does serve up some tasty Mexican fare. I put off writing my review until I gave them a second try, which happened to be months apart. On my initial visit, I ordered a trio of tacos, in which I tested their three meats, carne asada; pollo asado; and al pastor. It was good but my friend's torta was much more impressive than my taco plate. Last night, I followed up with the same order and tried all three tacos all over again.

Taqueria Cancún is definitely a Mission taqueria with late hours and plenty of drunk hipsters. I can't begin to describe the amount of blasphemy I heard inside the taqueria. "Sup, dude...can I get a..." and "Can I get a bean and cheese burrito with guacamole, no beans." These are just some of the type of things you can expect to hear at 1am. The taqueria is pretty cramped and gets packed with steady business, especially during late night hours. It can be a bit of a gamble to get a table, but as long as a friend stakes out a table while you order, you should be okay. 

Considering the amount of orders they're processing, I'm impressed with the quick turnaround. My three tacos and my friend's shrimp burrito were ready in five minutes or so. We initially were taking our food to go, but after finding a table, we decided to enjoy our food while its hot. I have to say I'm disappointed in that Cancún took my three tacos and wrapped them all in foil. If I had taken them home, they would have turned into soggy, juicy tortillas with three different meats. I do realize its a means to cut cost, but had I come home to soggy tacos, I probably wouldn't return to Cancún.

Cancún is plenty of generous with their portions, as they stuffed the tacos with plenty of meat. [see pic] The first taco I tried was the carne asada and the meat was tender and had plenty of flavor. Next up was the al pastor, which always tends to be my favorite and this was no different. The al pastor was tasty and had great flavor as well and most importanly was not greasy. Last up was the pollo asado taco which was good as well but if I had to rate the tacos it would be: al pastor, carne asada, and pollo asado. All were great and filling and reasonablly priced at $8 with tax.

I do think Taqueria Cancún is a great spot for Mexican food in the Mission, but it does have its problems. At the top of the list is the fact that there's no salsa bar. I'm sorry but what the hell am I supposed to do with two pinner salsas when I have three tacos and a bag of Costco bought chips? Yes, the salsa is made fresh and does have real avocado, but what's the point of teasing me with salsa for two or three chips. There's absolutely no way I can go back and cut everyone just to see if I can get more salsa. Forgive me but I love my condiments, salsa especially. Lastly, the cashier is always less than custom service oriented. He can often be seen texting and simply isn't a people person. Nevertheless, I will say that these small imperfections will not stop me from coming back.

Ambiance/Decor: 2 Stars (out of 5)
Food: 3 Stars (out of 5)
Service: 2 Stars (out of 5)
Price: $
Overall: 3 Stars (out of 5)

Pros:
+ Mission taqueria
+ Great prices/value
+ Generous portion per price
+ Good tasting Mexican
+ Fast turnaround 
+ Mexican/Domestic beer 

Cons:
- No salsa bar
- 2 salsas per order
- To go tacos are put together all in the same piece of foil
- Chips are not made in house
- Cashier lacks people skills
- Cash only
- Hipsters
author: Alexander E.

description:
Reminder: cash only!! 
Small place that gets pretty crowded so know your order in advance. Food is incredible every time. I always bring friends visiting from out of town and have yet to here anything other than praise.
author: Abby S.

description: Authentic Mexican food, conveniently located in the mission district. I've gotten their tacos each time I've been and I've always enjoyed the taste. It's usually busy so finding a place to sit can be tough, but you can always take it to-go and it'll still taste delicious.
author: Samara C.

description:
I wanted something hot and spicy,
I thought I'd give this place a chance.
Perhaps it could fulfill all of my wishes?
What should I order? Taco? Burrito?
I had a hunger only tacos can stop.
I know exactly what i'll order
Three tacos, two tostadas, and a soa pop
Yea-ah, and don't forget the hot sauce
Ooh, tacos so good in my tummy yummy yummy give me more.

Chips were good too
author: Bryan C.

description: Pretty good burrito for pretty cheap price. Don't expect any frills here like clean tables or nice atmosphere. Instead, just expect a hole in the wall place but with terrific food. Probably best for late night. All food comes with some free chips and salsa though it's nothing to write home about. You're going to be constantly bombarded by announcements for orders so just come here for the quick bite and go.
author: Victor W.

description: Oh my god. This place was sooooo good. My boyfriend and I had about 30 minutes in San Francisco before we had to hit the road to Yosemite and in our previous trips to sf we had never had a chance to get Mexican food in the mission. I just googled 'best Mexican in the mission' as we were low on time and this place came up. It was soooo unbelievably good. From the outside the place looks a little unexceptional and there's really nothing special with the decor inside. But the fact that the restaurant was full and there was a line was an omen of something special. There were plenty of tourists there who must have googled the same thing I did, but there were also plenty of locals. The guys working were super speedy and efficient. I got a super veggie quesadilla and my boyfriend got burrito mojado. We were both incredibly happy with our sizable meals. The tortillas were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside and the cheese was perfectly melted. We were very fat and happy after finishing. This was one of the best Mexican meals I've ever had.
author: Elyse N.

description:
I don't care what SFist/the Bold Italic/etc say but this place has the best burritos/quesidillas/tacos, especially for the drunchies. Actually, for any meal for that matter. 

Just greasy enough, and the food comes out pipin' hot! I usually go for the lengua super burrito, but if you're not really feeling all those stuffings, a quesidilla will suffice. The line can get wrap around at times, but the kitchen is reasonably fast. 

Customers often leave a mess on tables, and the guys sometimes don't come by often enough so new customers are often left cleaning up tables themselves. Maybe a solution would be to have a self-bussing station like chipotle where there are receptacles for baskets and trash?
author: David P.

description: carne asada wasss soooooo juuiiicccyyyyy
author: Yelena K.

description: Quickly served, cheap and tasty food. It does have very limited seating but strangers were just sitting at tables with each other. Would not recommend for large groups.
author: Patty C.

description: They just raised their prices to a ridiculous amount and I will now boycott them indefinitely. Plenty of other places to go in the mission. The owner decided to get greedy and increase the price for a super and veggie burrito to $9 ($10 after tax). Insane. Absolutely boycotting.
author: David C.

description:
Came here for my Mexican food fix while visiting SF.
We ordered the 
Nachos - very loaded up with tons of chx! 
Ceviche tostada with extra avocado ($1 more)- I should have ordered more :( the fish was absolutely delicious and they basically added 3/4s of a whole avocado on top of that! 
A pretty long line but only really took 10 mins to get my order in, then another 15 to get my food.
Would def come back again!
author: M C.

description: Ceviche is sooooo freaking good! And I'm really picky when it comes to al pastor tacos but they were delicious!!! 100% recommend!
author: Manny B.

description:
I like the fact that there are open late very late (until 2am)!

It's great to find one of the best taqueria in town after late night parties!

Cash only :-(

The carnitas super quesadilla is a must try! The meat is so good!
author: Arnaud H.

description:
This was the first stop of our little food tour in the Mission district.  We only tried 1 taco, super carnitas taco, and it was great!  

I was really not expecting anything amazing because, well you know, LA has the best mexican food... but the super carnitas taco was pretty dang good.

2 tortillas with some cheese melted on it, tender/flavorful carnitas, several avocado slices, onions/cilantro, and their salsa verde, made for a great start to our food tour. 

I definitely wouldn't mind coming back here to have more of these super tacos.  

Note: Being from LA, i must say, the entire area looked pretty damn ghetto...
author: Sennett L.

description:
Get to this place after your last drink of the night and you will swear that Taqueria Cancun is holy! You will look up to their Our Lady of Guadeloupe shrine and you will cross yourself. I don't really think it makes a difference what you order because it's all good. I usually just go with some tacos.
By the way this place isn't secret and it can be very busy on any given night. Do yourself a favor and resist the bacon wrapped hotdogs on the street and come in for something better.
Come to think of it, this place is pretty good for lunch as well.
author: Tommy W.

description: Taqueria Can-cun is placed in the heart of the mission surrounded by murals, shops, and vibrant hispanic community. This place is cash only with an atm inside that requires a $2 fee. With red and yellow the the theme the restaurant is quite charming emboding the essence of the mission. Walls are aligned with their many awards and paintings. Complimentary chips with 2 salsas are given after purchase is made. Chips are salsas are fresh and the salsas has a hint of spice. I ordered the Super burrito. Shell is cooked will a slight crunch. Although they are heavy handed with the beans the burrito was very enjoyable with tender steak. I could see myself coming back.
author: Rubin S.

description:
Didn't change my life. 

This is supposed the be the best, but I wasn't too sold. The meat was kind of fatty and I could barely make it through 3 bites without having to pull a too fatty chunk out of my mouth.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Rat heads get nothing but cheese yall. So I'm the poor co-worker that ate a chicken taco salad mixed with a bowl of baby shit! They don't ever have to worry about this black African American queen walking up in there again!! My folks said she tried to tell me about the 85 orange ass score card but I guess I wasn't paying attention, because I didn't see it at all. I'm just going to put it like this, if you hungry and that's the last place on the block open you better take your ass home and eat a cup of noodles. At least you know it's safe unlike this trap spot! #eww #dontdoit #
author: Tenia D.

description:
These are the best burritos for the money in SF.  It just blows my mind how delicious they are.  Personally I love the carnitas... They really do a great job with it, it has a great savory spice flavor to it... Super yummy.  But don't ignore the Al Pastor.  At a lot of places, it's fatty and oily, but here it's actually a legitimate meat.  I love it.  Then you got the carne asada, which is wonderful, and the pollo asado, also good.  And if you wanna do the funnier meats like lengua, they got you.  Basically, everything is delicious.  And the price is like $7.50 or $8 for a burrito you should win a trophy for finishing.

BTW they put true avocado on their burritos / tacos here.  NOT guacamole.  It's great... the texture is so much better, and you get to taste the rest of the ingredients too.
author: Jon E.

description: Carniasda tacos are too chewy.. I believe it was something like cow tongue.. never come back...
author: Alice S.

description: Solid tacos with a lot of meat and a great burritto!
author: Frances H.

description: I could eat the vegetarian burrito every day. Taqueria Cancun claims to have the best vegetarian burrito in town, and it did not disappoint! Full of flavor, slightly spicy and creamy. Served with salsa and chips, I'll definitely be back!
author: Sam K.

description:
Absolute. Fire. 

Tacos are super dank. Cash only though.
author: Evan L.

description:
EDIT: Dropped three stars because I've spent the rest of my evening in the bathroom. WILL NOT go back! 

Original Review: CASH ONLY!  ATM inside has a $2.00 fee. Food's really tasty aside from being on the salty side. The staff is friendly and the cooks work fast. Will definitely go back!
author: Amy P.

description:
OMG!!! ME AND MY SISTERS where hanging at a bar, we decided to grab a bite so we came here. NEVER again will I step in this place. I was already hesitant about eating here because I didn't like how the glass was covered. (I like to see my food being prepared) as I'm standing deciding on what to eat A HUGE COCKROACH crawled up the counter under the glass where the cheese,  Salas, guacamole etc. Was. 
I was disgusted. I tried to tell the staff but the ignored me. Never ever will I step a foot into that dirty hole in the wall.
author: Kiana M.

description: I've been eating wet burritos my whole life, and this one was the WORST.  I ordered the chicken super and that isn't what I got.  The chicken was grey, over cooked and crunchy.  The sad part is I hoped on the 49 bus and went across the city to try this, because of the reviews on yelp.  I should have stayed in my neighborhood with my tried and true Taqueria.
author: Skot L.

description: Burrito was very salty, and the chicken was fried. Less fresh tasting than other Taquerias around here.
author: Evan L.

description: Super burrito is bomb!!! Great atmosphere and service. Went with a friend and had a great time.
author: Michelle M.

description:
While in pursuit for the taqueria in SF that will make my panties drop the way La Pinata in the east bay does, I became infatuated with Taqueria Cancun. I had never had it but it was always on the "Best of" lists for the burrito category. If this many people think this is the best burrito ever, they can't be wrong...right? Wrong. Well, wrong according to me anyways. Everyone has different tastes and everyone has a different description of their "perfect burrito". Taqueria Cancun just isn't my type of burrito. I think if TC were a boy and we went on a date, I would decline the second date, saying to him, "Look, you're a cool guy, we're just different people." I wouldn't bad mouth him to my friends, I would just tell them that he just isn't my type. Ok, let me explain why.

In my typical fashion, I ordered the biggest, wettest, sloppiest burrito on the menu. I ordered the Burrito Mojado with carne asada (see pic.) I noticed on the menu that it didn't mention guacamole being in the super burrito, which is odd. Normally the super burrito from any good place has guac included. So I asked the guy taking my order to add guac to the burrito. He informed me that they do not have guacamole, but do have avocado. I almost passed out, but held myself together and told him to go ahead and add the avocado. 

Upon arrival, I noticed the burrito was of "okay" size. Nothing monstrous. In order for a burrito to rate high with me, it must be the size of a small child. I cut the the non-child like figure in half for the official Liz Burrito Inspection. 

First immediate gripe: They gave me f****** whole beans. I immediately went flaccid. I hate, I despise, I LOATHE whole beans in my burrito. I love re fried beans!!!! They make the burrito more wet and mushy so that all the items blend together. I knowwwwww, whole beans make a more authentic Mexican burrito. But this review is based on my personal burrito preferences so I'm whining. The dude taking my order didn't ask my preference of beans (usually they do) and I suppose it is also my fault for not thinking of emphasizing that I wanted re fried beans when he didn't ask. But still, I was irritated. 

I picked a piece of the carne asada out of the burrito to try it's quality alone. I must say that it had great flavor and was nice and moist. Taqueria Cancun DOES make a very tasty carne asada. So 4-5 stars for that. 

I didn't see much evidence of avocado being in the burrito upon slicing it open. So I dug in and still didn't find much avocado. I was bummed out about that. 

They did smother it in a lot of enchilada sauce, which I really enjoyed. However, they didn't put a sh!t load of sour cream on top. And it was really runny looking sour cream. I am wondering if the stuff on top was actually creme (in Spanish pronounced 'crame-uh' but with an accent and stuff.) I think creme is similar or maybe the same thing as Crème fraiche. Creme is good, but not as good as our typical sour cream, in my opinion. 

So, the burrito was OKAY. I must add that the prices were really impressive. Pretty cheap. But still, I would rather pay a few extra bucks and get my guac, thick sour cream, and a few extra inches of length and girth. I think perhaps that Taqueria Cancun is more on the traditional Mexican burrito path. Which is great, don't get me wrong, but just not my thing.
author: Liz M.

description:
There currently exists a great deal of hype for Taqueria Cancun, as it has been considered the creator of California's best burrito by many a food critic out there. 

I, however, am currently on a quest to discover the greatest chicken quesadilla, and this place sure didn't disappoint. It seemed a bit cleaner than its rival (El Farolito), and though I'd give Farolito a slight edge on flavor, I still absolutely loved my quesadilla and would rate it a close second. Check it out for yourself!
author: Madhur B.

description: Great tasting tacos that are fresh and yummy. The aqua Fresca drinks were also delicious and well worth $2 compared to a bottle drink or soda pop. Cash only.
author: W A.

description:
Awesome place in the Mission, especially in the middle of a fun night out. You get a great amount of food for cheap, and it's delicious too. I've had the burritos here and have never been able to finish them.

My one knock is that the lines are usually long, but that's just a testament to how great this place is!
author: Nikhil S.

description:
I am ashamed to admit that I have lived in SF for almost a year and haven't gone to an authentic mexican joint. This is what you would expect, massive eats, cold beer, good prices and limited english. 

It would have received 5-stars but the limited hot sauce selection and failure to deliver a SPICY burrito is the only knock. 

PS: cash only
author: Ben K.

description:
$7 burritos with salsa and two kind of chips.  If you had to measure tacqueria cancun against the other tacquerias in the area then it would rank pretty highly.  They have floury and flaky tortillas, and they know how to do it right!

Be prepared for lines, and an extremely large number drunk hungry people.
author: Alex H.

description:
Oh Taqueria Cancun - you have single-handedly foiled all my vacay eating plans.

I came to San Francisco with a huge plan to eat at a bunch of well-rated and bourgey restaurants that I had found on Yelp. But when I took a bite into my first super burrito here, I decided that this is where I wanted to eat for the rest of my trip.

AND SO I DID. In the week I was in SF, I must've gone here at least half a dozen times, maybe moreso. 

Yes, I did try El Farolito - for those that may question me. My Cancun experience far exceeded Farolito. The main difference for me is the tortillas here at Cancun were so butter soft. Literally the plastic butter knife had very little resistance cutting into these amazing burritos. 

The second thing is that this location was a lot less irritating than that of El Farolito. Farolito's is just too busy of an area and kinda touristy.

Thanks Taqueria Cancun for ruining all my plans, in a good way!
author: Timothy P.

description:
Best burritos in the city. Nom.
Don't forget they're cash only!
author: J F.

description: This is my all-time favorite burrito place.  I typically order super nachos or enchilada combos as a standard practice at taquerias... but I stray away from my norm here. Not quite sure what they put in the burritos, but it is completely entrancing. I enter into an otherworldly eating experience which happens to be the perfect mix of meditative, whimsical and friggin delicious.  I'm a better person after eating burritos at Taqueria Cancun.
author: tiff g.

description:
came here after a late night of drinking... This place hit the spot with its greasy goodness. We ordered a burrito and torta to share amongst 4 of us and we still had left overs. Based on 4 girls..

Will be here again next time we are in the area..
author: Jay B.

description:
Biggest cheapest most delicious burrito in town, period!
Location is closed on Tuesdays but behold..it's open any other day of the week until late at night..late-er night is usually crunch time for them so there will be a line!
author: Kevin G.

description:
Drunk munchies are the worst. I try to avoid them at all costs but I somehow always find myself here -_-

Either before I get wasted, as I'm getting wasted or after a long night, I will inhale my meal here. Centrally located in hipsterville, you will encounter some strange people. You have your typical thirst bucket paisas that will fuck you in the ass with their eyes...then there's the waxed curly mustache hipsters trying to order in 'espanol'...You'll run into your typical bros being their usual douchey selves. Yup, shit gets real in there. There's always a long line...ATM is forever out of service...tables are never empty. 

The food is palatable. I'd recommend the super tacos de asada, super burrito and quesadilla.
author: Lydia L.

description:
The only complaint I will accept from people who's actually patronized Taqueria Cancún is that the line can be crazy long.

News flash:

Worth it. 

I'm working my way through the menu and I'm currently big on the carnitas. But seriously, everything is good.  Just remember, CASH ONLY!
author: Jon D.

description:
Haven't return in a while, so when a mini-bar crawl ended (Mission Bar, Lone Palm, Doc's Clock), I was glad the remainders stopped in here for some tacos. This place gives El Farolito's regular al pastor tacos a run for its money.

This is their second of three locations (i.e., the name should include "#2" is what I'm saying). You can also phone in orders before showing up! Brightly lit, wall murals, wooden benches and tables, semi-private booths and relatively clean.
author: Peter L.

description:
I live on the same street as Taqueria Cancun and it has never disappointed me. Anyone who visits me gets to experience their delicious mexican food, ambiance and service. I absolutely recommend:

-Huevos con Jamon: they serve this all day, and it's by far the best thing on their menu
-super nachos con carne asada: if you're really hungry, this is the thing to get. so much food!
-super tacos con carne asada: yummm
-jarritos to top off anything you get here!

Random thing I noticed: no women work here.
author: Mariam T.

description: HUGE burritos that I can never finish in one sitting! I love their Al Pastor and the whole avocados so well placed all throughout my food. It gets crowded real quick, even on weeknights
author: Marakia R.

description:
Taqueria Cancun is located a block away from my bikram yoga studio. It's estimated that doing bikram for 90 minutes burns an estimated 600-1000 calories.

I gain it all back here. Those carnitas tacos are dangerous.  Not to mention, muy delicioso!
author: Janice C.

description: Super burrito is a monster. Packed with meat on meat on meat. Prices are very fair and food is great. Authentic vibe. Feel like I'm in Mexico city.
author: Brandon H.

description:
Been coming here for years but in the past year the quality has really taken a turn for the worst.  

Better bets for burritos can be found at El Farolito and La Taqueria.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Next time I'll have to try the al pastor that my Yelp friends rave about, but my carnitas burrito was still a solid late night snack when split with the boy.  Luckily, it's been quite some time since I've had a truly awful burrito.  Every one I've had within memory was either 'good' or 'goddamn this is good' - this one was the former with the carnitas being present but not terribly memorable.

All in all, it's a lively spot and the service stays top notch into the late hours, making it a gem in my eyes.
author: Krystle S.

description:
I got a carne asada burrito for second dinner because this place is supposedly the best... Uh, what, why?

Long line. Dry tortilla chips. Only two choices for salsa. Super small containers for said salsa. Teeny water cups. Bland rice, bland beans, and small portion of bland shredded beef. They got my friend's order wrong (gave her beef instead of chicken) and wouldn't do anything about it. Generally filthy eating area. No receptacles for trash or used bowls/plates. Not enough staff to clean up the tables. The same homeless guy interrupting our dinner twice because he forgot he had already come by asking if the bottle at the end of our table was empty.

The tortilla was yummy, though. Def the burrito's saving grace.

Safe to say I would not go out of my way to come here again.
author: Michele P.

description: Delicious tacos served up quick and friendly in the Mission, I got some kind of terrifying super taco that could not be contained by the light and lovely soft shell but I made it work. And it was worth it. We tried the grilled pork and steak tacos and the meat in all was seasoned spicy and perfectly crispy cooked. With a bowl of complimentary nachos, two kinds of fresh salsa and a couple of Pacificos we were good to go. A pigeon may have wandered in, tempted as we all were by the music and good smells, but he soon wandered out again, no harm done.
author: Risa D.

description:
My sister says this place has the best quesadillas in the city...

Sometimes I'm inclined to think she's crazy (haha jk) but really, I think she's got this one. Or maybe she is because we came here after having a bunch of drinks. Who knows. Either way, it was delicious. It's also pretty darned crowded... the late night crowd does seem to favor this place! (AKA lots of drunk people)

Like any Mexican place, service seems pretty quick. Sure there was a small line, but not a lot of waiting. Cash only though! Most of the tables were filled when we walked in, but by the time we had ordered our food, a table freed up and we could sit down. We did just push the last person's food off to the side (and didn't see anyone pick it up while we took a couple bites). Noticed they sold beer too, but we'd been drinking all night...

We ordered the *infamous* quesadillas to go, which were actually pretty big (they cut a whole one in half, so you get two thick quesadillas... like thick), but super in taste. Between two people, we wolfed that down in a blink of an eye. And damn. it was good. Every bite had the perfect distribution of meat (we got chicken), cheese (CHEESE GROMIT!), salsa, and guacamole. Definitely a little bit on the spicy side with the salsa, but still delicious nevertheless.

Originally, we were going to get it to go. Let's just say only the chips ended up being to go. Yum. Would go back because it's cheap and awesome! Or maybe after drinking it is cheap and awesome. Take your pick.
author: Denise C.

description: Best taqueria in the mission according to my Mexican taste. I believe you will never taste the same tacos as you do in Mexico however this place is the closest I have found in the Bay to be authentic Mexican food. Their tacos are delicious and so are the tortas. Love the staff and big space to sit and enjoy your meal. If you come here make sure you have cash since they only take cash, the good thing is they have an ATM in case you forget!
author: Suzy R.

description:
I came here with a large group of people because a few of my friends had been here before and really enjoyed it. I usually don't like Mexican food, but I really enjoyed the food here! I ordered a Mojado burrito (with carne asada), and it was hugeeeeeeee for $6. Because it was so large, I shared it with my roommate, and we got full off of eating half each o.o... It was pretty difficult to eat; we couldn't hold it in our hands because of all the enchilada sauce/sour cream/cheese around the burrito. I really like cilantro, and the burrito came with a lot of it wahoo... but it also came with A LOT of beans. ~70% of my burrito consisted of beans, so next time I come here, I'm going to ask them to go easy on the beans. I also got free nachos with salsa and guac on the side. The guac is pretty spicy... I've never had such spicy guac before.

The inside of this place is pretty small so it gets pretty packed when the line is long. Finding parking around this area was pretty inconvenient for us.
author: Annie S.

description:
The tacos here are legit. Flavorful, cheap and packed full of meat and produce. You cannot fail with these gems. I scarfed down quite a few of these, and was completely satisfied for the rest of the night. 

Word to the wimpy: for a "non-spicy" item, it's still got a punch to it. Grab some water, some chips, and some beer to wash it down with. 

The area that it's in is...lively...so good luck finding parking! Public transportation it!
author: Tara H.

description:
Ive only eaten here after bars so my judgement is often clouded.
I get the lengua burrito and mix horchata with fresa.

I shared a burrito with my gf last time and my sister was pretty boozied up and actually took my half and scarfed it down.  She's the type that eats beef and like white meat chicken only.  It wasn't till I told her that it was actually beef tongue that she thought it was gross. LOL
author: Anne-Mary P.

description:
One of the more amazing burrito's I've ever had. Went with the al pastor super burrito which comes with all the stuffings. You can get it toasted and it was delicious without being messy. You also get free chips and salsa, but let's be serious - you didn't come here for free chips.

My girlfriend ordered a quesadilla and it was also very, very good.
author: Josh T.

description:
I moved from SF to DC almost two years ago and I've been seriously deprived of good Mexican food ever since. So,when we visit SF we make sure to stop here for lunch.

I always get a shrimp burrito with black beans, sans cheese and sour cream, usually I get extra salsa and pico de gallo on the side as well. Also, I get a cantaloupe agua fresca which in my opinion, is one of the most delicious beverages ever.
