(1) The inside is done up so that you think you're in Ensenada instead of Alta California.  Gaudy paint job.  No separate tables;  everyone sits at the picnic tables indoors, making new friends (or trying not to).
(2) The food is a notch above other Mexican foods here, but the prices are not.  I've had the tacos, the enchiladas, and the burritos.  They've all been winners.  I still remember that I had a spicy enchilada right before going to an Argentine Tango class;  not a good idea.

Suburbanites take heed:  This is the Mission, and there ain't much parking here.  Expect to walk for blocks to get to this place.  But try to plan your hike to be on Mission Street for as many blocks as possible;  it's total immersion into a different culture.

Enjoy, and prepare to fall in love.
author: Ron L.

description:
Worth every parking ticket I got while eating there!  Go back to your BEEHIVE, officer!!!!  http://www.yelp.com/biz/sfmta----the-beehive-san-francisco#hrid:g59aNXzDFiV-CZWcgbMUZA

So I grew up in the Central Valley, home of the world's BEST TACO TRUCKS.  No question about that.

But this place isn't for cheap food, and it isn't "Alta Comida Mexicana" (in price or quality).... but it is the perfect marriage of the latter and your typical Mission taco shop.

(For Gramma's home cookin go here http://www.yelp.com/biz/tommys-mexican-restaurant-san-francisco-2#hrid:mU-ckGedPoOHYERu1l95dQ)

First off, they have the most amazing tortilla chips in town.  I have no idea what they make them out of, but it's like comparing Fresh Bakery Organic Mutli-Grain Wheat to, say, Iron Kids.  Wet burritos are amazing.  All of the food is just top notch.  They even have fresh squeezed OJ or Carrot Juice (get 50/50, seriously), and a number of horchata's and beers.

Service has never been bad, and the price isn't too steep.  Specially considering the quality.

I once rode my bike here after wasting my time and money at http://www.yelp.com/biz/lone-palm-san-francisco#hrid:cVB-dHvqRW7Xzzwb3-AaEg  ...which saved the night!

It's open acceptably late, so the only thing that would make it 6 stars would be a full bar for tequila shots and a place to tie up my horse (since my car's been towed by now)
author: David D.

description:
my friend introduced me to the al pastor burrito a few months ago and I have been back at least 9 times.

the only time the al pastor wasn't that good was at night maybe the last of the rotation, but all other times it was consistent.

these burritos are huge, I wouldn't get anything else other than the al pastor burrito with less rice and  extra salsa.

also the casher has positive energy even though he probably works long ass hours and hooks it up with salsa 

I'll be back keep up the good work !!
author: DOM d.

description: Came here once over a year ago and the super burrito with everything I've ordered was one to die or let's say live for lol! The ingredients were fresh and they'll roll your order right in front of you just like Subways. No wonder why this spot was jammed pack that night and continues to be! Ideal Mexican spot in the Mission. Parking can be a hassle for majority of the day and there could be a long line but well worth the wait!
author: Sam M.

description: Came in after Carnavale for an authentic taco and was pleasantly surprised with how fast and DELICIOUS our meal was! Ordered carnitas and carne asada super tacos. Carne asada is a must order! We also had al pastor burrito which was dank as hell. Very loud inside: mariachi and constant juicing. Bar order and festival seating. Would come back!
author: SarAh G.

description: Maybe I went on an off day, but the stuff my friend and I had was odd tasting and thoroughly unappetizing. Chips and salsa were good though.
author: roger t.

description:
After a late-night of beer and drinking games, my friends and I were searching for a spot to satisfy our brunch-y cravings. We passed by Cancun and instantly knew that giant burritos were just the thing to satisfy us... and they did. They sure did. 

My friend was opting for the healthier route and got a vegetarian burrito. It was not as delicious but... I guess that's to be expected. 

Open until 2am so you can satisfy your drunk-y cravings too!
author: Carolyn K.

description: I love this place! I can see why people have been disappointed in this place after all the hype that has been happening about it. It's the same if someone hypes up a wonderful movie and you're disappointed when you see it. This food probably won't change your life, but it definitely will make your day. I recommend the super shrimp burrito. The shrimp is seasoned so well and they give you tons of it!
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Everything always tastes AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS to me after a few drinks.

Maybe that's why I thought Taqueria Cancun was so great the first time I went. The other night, when I was more sober, I took my friend here. Fail. Carne asada was chewy and bland. Quesadilla was excessively oily.

Two stars for being open in the wee hours of the night.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Consistently the best burrito in SF. I lived around the corner for more than ten years and it was my go-to spot.

Nice chunks of avocado, especially in the veggie burrito. The al pastor is so delicious and is great in their hearty tacos.

I've never been a fan of their tortilla chips as they are thick, yellow corn. Just not my preference. And unlike some places, they are not made fresh. But the chunky salsa verde makes up for it.

I also really like the cantaloupe agua fresca, which not a lot of places seem to offer, as it's not too sweet.
author: Jess G.

description:
Nothing fills you up better than a little late night snacking...and there aren't too many things to eat that can top tacos!

Definitely one of the hot spots for the post-drinking crowd, as the line that forms can get ridiculous...especially when a number of the people just stink of alcohol.  The tacos are just good enough to make the wait worth it though...regardless of whether you're one of the drunk people in line.  A handful of different types of meat to choose from, in addition to having the option of having a regular taco or a "super" with the extra toppings.  

The carnitas was pretty good, and the carne asada met my personal standard.  Was intrigued by the beef tongue, but decided to stick with something more traditional for comparison's sake.  Might go for one on my next trip, though Vicky L's review has got me thinking that ordering a burrito is a must.

And in case you were curious, this place is pretty damn legit.  How do I know?  Well, the fact that they serve cow brains on the menu is a pretty damn good indicator that you didn't just wander into a Taco Bell.
author: Mike L.

description:
When I walked in here, I thought I subconsciously walked into El Farolito. The color and setup are almost identical. I believe this is a little more spacious. I came here on a friday night, an it was packed, as expected. The line to order was pretty long with a little bit of waiting. I ordered the super burrito with carne asada and everything for $7. I'm a large guy with a huge appetite, so anything smaller would be a snack for me. It was pretty good, although a bit bland. The chips that they give you come with two kinds of salsa. One is mild the other is a bit spicy, I preferred the green one. It's not enough for all of the chips though, they should probably give you 4, instead of just 2. 

The service was decent, and the wait was a little longer than at most places. First come first served seating, so grab one as soon as it's available. You order at the cashier, but they will get your order while you are in line to expedite the process. Cash only, are you surprised?
author: Phan H.

description: Finally found this place after a week in San Francisco. It's so nice to see a neighborhood and restaurant that reminds me of home. The fajita plate was sooo good (get corn tortillas!). Most of the people there were gringo, had burritos, and seemed to like those. So that seems safe. The place itself is as vibrant and a la Virgen as any other truly Mexican restaurant. I loved it!
author: Gregg O.

description:
My Favorite burrito in SF. 
Love everything about this place other than the late night after bar crowd. But that is easy to avoid
author: Stuart S.

description:
It's Zagat rated and has been on my list for a while but while Taqueria Cancún didn't exactly fully disappoint, it didn't leave me craving for more nor planning a return visit soon. 

I had a carnitas burrito and it's a pretty big thing for the price so I guess it's good value. The carnitas were well flavored and had a good crisp and the rice had a distinct cilantro hit to them. My biggest issue was that while the meat was piping hot, the rice and beans were stone cold. Perhaps I was supposed to wait a little longer for the two to counteract each other. I ended up just scooping out the fillings and eating it like a burrito bowl. Special kudos though to the salsa verde - that was something special.

 It's cheap, filling and somewhat tasty but I wouldn't say that Taqueria Cancún is the absolute best. With that said, I might be back to try the cow tongue though... just not too soon.
author: Jon L.

description:
Taco is the thing. I rarely eat burritos as rice, beans, guac, sour cream, cheese, etc. are extraneous and prohibit a puristic evaluation of the meat. After trying tacos in various places in the mission (sober & anytime of the day, not just late-nights), this place is still the best. They pile enormous amount of meat per taco. Taste/cost ratio wins again. Everybody gets a bag of chips with TWO types of homemade fresh salsa. Sometimes you actually bite into chunks of avocado or jalapeno. It might be unpleasant but I like knowing that the salsa is made from real ingredients.

Most importantly, the carnitas actually have fried bits and the carne asada actually have charred bits, unlike many other places, where they just stew the meat in some mystery liquid. I have no complaints of crowds or homeless people. The high volume of customers ensure freshness and the crowd is still much better than any other taquerias closer to either bart stations.
author: pH R.

description:
My quesadilla suiza was delicious, but I had a nagging feeling that Taqueria Cancun tastes far better while you're handsomely inebriated than than while you're boring and sober...

Also, my friend deeply questioned her choice to have a late night burrito here the next morning atop her toilet. "Why? Why did I eat that burrito?" she asked herself as she did unspeakable things in the bathroom.

Still, I would drunkenly venture here again. After all, she did enjoy her burrito thoroughly before it passed through her like a full grown spanish bull, ablaze.
author: Trang H.

description:
I only ever get the Chicken Burrito's and they are excellent.

Pros:
- Chicken Burrito
- Chips and salsa

Cons:
- The line can be long
- No salsa bar
author: Dipesh G.

description:
Wow. This was, like, the best tacos I've ever had in my life. This was back in June. I had super tacos with carnitas. It was just so seriously delicious. I don't know if it was because it was truly the bomb or if I was just starving, but rarely has anything tasted so good in my life.

I haven't been back yet, but now that I live here, I want to go...
author: Jennie S.

description:
There's not much about this place that hasn't been said already, so I'll just make this quick. 

$5, carne asada, be full till tomorrow.
author: Peter Y.

description:
Hands down my ... second favorite taqueria in Mission!

The prices are competitive, food is delicious, but most importantly, the atmosphere is amazing! It's a circus of entertainment, even at 2am. From the guys at the grill yelling out your orders in Spanglish, random singing and guitar playing, hipsters talking about lobotomies, I don't think anywhere else defines Mission. 

The meat is a little dry for my liking (tried al pastor and carnitas) but I loved the lengua. Your standard salsa and chips round out the selection. 

Pretty watered down horchata, but definitely a delicious cantaloupe agua fresca. I was hoping they'd have some Jamaica, but apparently it's not as well received. 

And bonus - open till probably 4am, or some ungodly hour.
author: Sharon F.

description: If it's late and there are no other Mexican places open... Ugh, I guess go here. Bland
author: Glen D.

description:
Yes! Yes! Yes!

Fantastic veggie burritos, kick-ass nachos, fresh juices, wonderful horchatas.  The guys who work there are all friendly too.
author: Jon L.

description: This is my go to place for shrimp burritos!!!!!!!!!!  I've been going here for years and hands down, they make the BEST I've ever had.  The cool thing about this place is the quality of the food (were talking big portions and tasty), service (include free chips and various salsas with each order), and price (which is reasonable at $8-9 for super shrimp burrito).  The only downside is that the lines can be really long here, plus its cash only.  I'll definitely be back for my shrimp burrito fix!
author: Mike M.

description:
Big line, hella hipsters, wack green salsa, they didnt give me limes with my tacos, 

BUT they did have brain(cesos) which was cool but they didn't chop it enough, diced would be cool....

i didnt like this place because of the atmosphere, the line, and the mediocre product, had a few up the street that were better and at a less busy place....

what is up with tacos being so expensive and not even that great in the bay!!! I may be a taco snob but shit all I want is some salsa that gives me the hiccups :/
author: Raheem P.

description: I'm not sure why people rave about this place so much.  I think it's ok for a late night snack, but much prefer Pancho Villa's sauces and burritos more.  You can get a solid burrito here, but something is still missing for me here.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Super cheap and delicious!

The quesadilla was awesome...and unlike the typical flattened out quesadilla.  They looked more like fat burritos stuffed w/ cheesy deliciousness.  The burritos, however, weren't that good.  I tried the beef one and the meat was just kind of chewy and it was overall pretty bland.  The tacos were also fantastic!  They give you chips and salsa for free and they also serve beer.
author: Lilli C.

description:
This place is great for what it is, a small restaurant that serves Mexican food at very reasonable prices!  The place is open until 2am on weekend nights, thus this is the perfect spot to recover after a night of partying nearby.

The veggie burrito is great plus its under 5 bucks as of early 2010. The food was great overall, as it wasn't too greasy nor bland.  The ambiance may get a little stuffy, plus the yellow walls and shoddy benches won't win any decoration contests for most people.

Overall, if you're looking for good Mexican food in the Mission, this should be on your list; near the top if you have less than $10 to spend.  Beware, I don't recall them saying they'll accept credit cards, so remember to bring cash.
author: Rob L.

description:
Pros:
1.  Very good basic mexican food.  
2.  Very casual, great place to have a beer and some enchiladas.
3.  The ceviche is pretty good too.

Cons:
1.  Can get pretty crowded and tables can be really tightly packed together.
author: Jensen L.

description: In a sea of burrito places, this place is good but not so amazing to stand out from the copious amounts of other burrito places. The ingredients are fresh, the burritos large, and the food flavorful. There is also a nice selection of salsas. However, I think I'll have to continue that search for the best burrito in the area.
author: Brent W.

description:
The food is pretty good. It's not Oakland taco truck good, but still good! So why am I giving it a two star review? 

Well ambience sucked. A homeless guy walked in, started begging for money, MULTIPLE times. It was very annoying. "Sorry but I have no change." So the raging homeless guy ends up throwing food at my boyfriend and I. UNCALLED FOR! I'm only angry because he wasn't kicked out for loitering in the first place! He was only kicked out after he made a mess and every other patron uncomfortable and angry...
author: Jeanette Y.

description: Another place to get a cheap or inexpensive burrito. I am tired of paying $8-9 for something I am paying $7 for. The problem is this place is fairly small and could be a little cleaner..
author: M C.

description: Amazing burrito and enough for the hubby and I to share! We asked what type of meat was recommended and he said chicken. He was right - it was great! May have ruined all future burritos for me. Go here now!!! Great prices too.
author: Lindsey W.

description:
I met my friends for a late night bite here after going out on the town. 

It was small, loud, crowded, and downright amazing. It looked like a long line but it went pretty quickly. Apparently the burritos are amazing. However, I ended up getting a quesadilla, which was also delicious. Everything is made to order and service is speedy. 

Only annoying thing is that the guy on the loudspeaker screams directly into the microphone and it gets loud and hard to hear the numbers he is calling out.
author: Saroya W.

description: The best burrito I ever had! The meat (beef steak) was very tasty, heaven in my mouth :)
author: Eva T.

description:
Who doesn't like heading into a restaurant and seeing everything decor'ed out like it's your second Quinceañera all over again.  Certainly not me.  How about dining inside what looks like a hollowed out Piñata? Love it.

This is one of my favorite places to go when the sun has gone down, the clock has struck midnight, and you just want to take your sweetheart to a romantic burrito dinner next to some romantic Jesus candles. 

Seriously try the mojado, (also known as the Wet Burrito).  Its a giant burrito topped with Salsa, Guac, Sour Cream, and Cheese.
author: Lam N.

description:
Pretty good tacos and burritos but the place is a bit grungy with very kitschy decor-- think holiday string lights and painted murals of yellow and red haciendas. It made me feel like I was sitting inside of a El Paso brand taco box. 
Seating is painted communal picnic style benches.

I got the lengua (tongue) and al pastor (pork) taco. Hubby ordered the carne asada super burrito. Everything was really yummy. Finishing the burrito is definitely a gut buster if you aren't used to eating things the size of a small baby.
Our order came with some crispy tortilla chips with a green tomatillo/avocado sauce and salsa that tasted really fresh.
author: Lisa F.

description: The only place in SF that even comes close to SoCal mexican food. The burritos here would be OK by SoCal standards but up here it's a real stand out. They are also open late which is always a plus. 5 Stars in SF, 3 stars down south.
author: James R.

description:
Wow. I have been going to Cancun for about six years. I go at least once a month. Well, I went about once a month. Always loved the food, and I have always tipped around 30% - 50% of my bill. I am never going back. Frak these guys.
I was looking for a spot outside to lock up my bike and this gentlemen was sitting on the bike dock smoking a cigarette.
 
Me: "Pardon me sir, may I lock my bike up here?"
Him: "What?!?"
Me: "Could I lock my bike up here?"
Him: "Yeah, you would want to do that,"
He then walks inside and begins talking to the cooks and pointing at me.

I order two veggie burritos.
The guy at the counter takes my order.
Part way through making my food he asks if my burritos were veggie.
I confirm.
He goes "Cool."
He hands me my burritos.
And I confirm: "these are Vegetarian, no meat right?"
and he says: "No meat."

I get home and start eating.

Inside of the burritos is not just a single piece of meat, but many finely chopped and strategically placed pieces so it is impossible to pick them out.

If you want to eat at a place that has people who will put things into your food to "mess" with you, this is your place. I see some semen sour cream or feces beans in some jerk faced dudes future.

Keep in mind this was the treatment I got for politely asking to lock my bike up at the only bike dock on the street that was available. 

Being in the service Industry I find this behaviour uncouth.
Avoid. At. All. Costs.
author: James P.

description: What is all the fuss about! Hipsters have horrible taste. This isn't even good tex mex much less mexican food. Horrible quality chicken, tasteless beans. How hard is it to make a burrito? Yet somehow they mess it up. Don't believe the hype
author: Josh N.

description:
SF Mission District. Home of the foil-wrapped burrito.

Never been? Grab a Carne Asada Burrito Mojado. It's a gigantic burrito served "mojado" or wet-style. Served on a plate of enchilada sauce, topped with sour cream, as well as the house made salsa and guac. It certainly won't help your diet, but it'll turn any frown upside down, and make any drunken haze that much more, uh, memorable?

The super burrito sans mojado is wonderful too - packed with avocado and meat and cheese, with just the right amount of salsa, beans, and rice. If you're not as hungry, make it a torta (same idea, but on a french roll - think Mexican sandwich). Also, the quesadillas here are absolutely rocking. Heck, they even serve menudo (tripe) and lengua (tongue)! Burrito runs you about $6.50 - quite reasonable.

I tend to show up here after 10 PM. Oddly enough, I'm usually sober, but I've been known to come here after some Golden Gate Park shenanigans. 

As a note of caution, the salsa and guac vary in spiciness by the day, ranging from mellow to jalapeno craziness. You'll know when you bite into your first chip (served with every order!)

I miss the San Diego joints (carne asada fries anybody?), but you know, Cancun keeps me pretty darn happy. :)
author: Conrad B.

description:
This place. My FAVORITE taco and burrito joint in ALL OF SAN FRANCISCO. Granted, I haven't tried them all... but whatever. I'm still going to use a bunch of caps to express my PASSION for this wonderful establishment.

Tip: do NOT forgo the green salsa. DO NOT. I once got a dirty look from one of the workers because I asked for six little cups of salsa. Did I care? Maybe a little. Was it worth it? Yes, my friends... yes it was.
author: Julie D.

description:
For years now, this is the place I will go to get the authentic mission style mexican food. 

The super prawn burrito is some of the best I have ever had. CASH ONLY btw. Took some friends that never had good mexican food before till recent. Everyone was very satisfied. 

To add, sometimes there will be someone playing some music inside. ill be back for sure.
author: David P.

description: Had the chicken burrito mojado which was large and affordable but tasteless (despite lots of red sauce) and mostly rice with some beans inside. The real adventure started about six hours later when I spent the next 24-30 hours projectile vomiting and shivering in a fetal position. No vale la pena.
author: Geoff C.

description: This was the first taqueria I visited when I first came to the Bay so maybe I'm a little sentimental but damn. The super burritos are fantastic, both al pastor and carne asada. Chips and sauces are included with to-go orders and I always load up on their amazing jalapenos (with carrots and onions) while I wait. Okay yeah I'm always starving since I hit Cancun after my favorite bar but damn, those peppers are good. I fill up a plastic cup and help myself. Another plus is personal: cilantro is optional. I'm new here and haven't yet gotten used to the cilantro in everything so if I can request its absence, I politely do so. The clerk I've always dealt with is a sweetheart and service time is minimal, even on packed Friday nights. I live closer to Farolito but Cancun just hits the sweet spot.
author: Rebecca P.

description: Simple but delicious. Also one one the best bargains in the city. Try the burritos, tacos and tortas. It's hard to come here and not try everything the first trip. The quality and service is consistent at all locations.
author: Kevin-louis B.

description: I stopped in here for a late night snack after a few drinks. I ordered the tostada ceviche with extra avocado. It was delicious and spicy. I devoured it pretty quickly. My friend got the carne asada, which I had a bite of and thought was excellent too. The place was packed on a Wednesday evening.
author: Madeline S.

description:
What a deal the burrito mojado is. For about $6 you get a normal burrito with the normal fixins inside it and the meat of your choice, and then its caloric value is roughly doubled by the application of melty cheese, enchilada sauce, guacamole, and sour cream...!

Seriously though, it's finger lickin good. I shouldn't have eaten it all at once (portlier looking guy next to me having the same thing stopped at the 2/3 mark) but I was so happy that I did. BTW, I got mine with Al Pastor. It was not the best I've ever had but it was very good.

Also, try their green salsa. It packs a punch that few other taquerias in this area dare to pack for fear of chasing away the chili milquetoasts. I was breathing fire all the way out the door!

I'd like to come and try their ceviche and/or their enchiladas next time.
author: Josh K.

description: Maybe I have an advantage on this place as a Latina from SoCal, but this place wasn't worth all these ratings.. Got a burrito and it was lacking some serious flavor. I'm so bummed cause everyone made this place sound like heaven.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Can't totally remember the details but good carnitas super nachos. It was late and hit that post delirium cravings well.
author: Misha T.

description: Fun hole in the wall place that has some authentic Mexican food. The super quesadilla is definitely worth a try as well as the Big One! Those visiting the mission district need to try this place
author: Kevin G.

description: Growing up in Texas, I've had my fair share of great Mexican food. Taqueria Cancun is my go-to when I get those hankerings for a yummy burrito. The burritos are delicious and enough to share with at least one other person - unless you don't want to!
author: Mitalee M.

description: I read that you have to eat a mission burrito while in San Fran- it's literally on one of the top 10 lists I found! And it was so right! I love Mexican food and this place is the real deal! The burritos are big enough to share but don't be afraid to order a few tacos on the side too, they're also full of flavor!!
author: Alyssa T.

description: Authentic, affordable, delicious! This is a true mission burrito feed destination. You will get full here.
author: Deacon J.

description:
Just okay. After intensely googling the best burritos in the mission, cancun came up at the top several times. my main problem with these burritos, and SF style burritos in general, is the lack of meat in relation to other things inside of the burrito, and this place continued that trend.

pro- cheap, good location, good free chips, free water, toasted tortilla (way better than steaming it to make it all gluey a la chipotle or other SF style burritos)

con- TOO MUCH RICE in that goddam burrito. The al pastor was in name only, it was more like a hybrid of barbacoa and pork, nothing near the true al pastor where it's on a spit. My friend's chicken was kinda dry. another downside, tons of hipsters all over the place. boo. also doesn't take credit card but really what kind of legit taqueria does?
author: Samir K.

description:
Dirty and greasy mexican food that always hits the spot when you're a little tipster. 

Quesadilla was cheesy delicious from what I remember :)
author: Annie L.

description:
One of the best Mexican restaurants in the city. Everything is fresh . A true authentic experience. I am a burrito guy so that's what I usually order here and when I get Mexican. I always leave full after eating one of there well portioned delicious burritos. 


Recommend: 

1) Al Pastor- Perfectly marinated, good kick but not too spicy
2) Carne Asada- Juicy, tender, and always a safe bet
author: Justin R.

description:
I used to go to this place religiously.
It has nice colorful mexican paintings and large communal bench seating.
I would come here exclusively for the burrito carnitas, basically I would only eat carnitas when at a Mexican place. Why else? Fried or grilled pork is so good its a sin, and you know thats true!

However, I've switched to El Farolito. Their carnitas werent that great from the get go, but their steak burrito is bomb!
It has that nice smoky flavor and its not tough or chewy, just juicy tasty tender steak.

I hope I've converted you by now.
author: Ash R.

description: eh. just your average run of the mill mission taqueria with larger than life greasy food. I tried to go healthy by getting a plain quesadilla with black beans, but the thing was HUGE. I only ate half, and am kind of regretting eating even that much. The one thing I do like about this spot is the chill atmosphere. Is has that casual dining vibe which is great for getting together with friends.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Best al pastor in town! Can't go wrong with their burritos, nachos, or super tacos. They all hit the spot!!
author: Brendo D.

description:
As Lana del Ray says; "heaven is a place on earth with you....burrito" 

I've been coming here for years and not once have I been disappointed.
The burritos are so finger lickin' good I dream about them. The service is quick, the prices are exquisite and the food is outta this world. So, put on your space pants people and be prepared to get taken out to planet of the burritos.
author: Brenda L.

description:
Holy crap I love me some gut-bomb Mission Burritos so much that if I were to live equidistant between El Farolito and Taquería Can-Cún I would be on the fast track to an early death from an obesity-related heart attack. I would at the very least be 100 lbs overweight. 

Farolito had been my go-to for Mission burritos when in the City, but a stop today by Can-Cún put an immediate halt to my one-track thinking on this. My asada burrito was pretty much exactly as tasty as the ones I get from Farolito, and pretty much for the same price. The salsa was not quite as good, but much spicier. The chips are the same - from a bag (not fresh). The space itself is larger, and not quite as filthy dirty. It's still a small, filthy counter-service taquería. 

Overall, a great burrito, for a great price.
author: Don B.

description: Great fresh salsa verde! I got two tacos, one al pastor and the other pollo asado, they were both great! The chicken was nice and crispy. Saw some other people eating wet burritos which looked mighty tasty
author: Devin M.

description:
Everyone has their favorite taqueria in the Mission, and this is mine by far. Where to begin? Every ingredient of their tacos and burriots are high quality and done right -- the meat is excellent, the tortillas, tacos, rice, and beans are cooked just right, the cheese is perfect, and the vegetables are fresh. After a long day at work, there's nothing that cheers me up like this place.

Tip: instead of getting the super burrito (which is awesome), get two super tacos. Roughly the same amount of food for the same price, but less rice and more yummy avocado/sour cream-y goodness.
author: David B.

description: I had a super steak & prawn burrito from this place and it was so good!! You can't eat at all Mexican food spots but this spot it's Ok! Some tables were not clean when we came in but other than that service was great
author: Leanna W.

description: All great! But they don't clean the tables and there is no mirror in the restroom. ESL in CCSF is for you
author: Alexander S.

description:
Solid taqueria.

The lengua burritos are awesome. If tongue isn't your thing, just get the carne asada. If meat isn't your thing, well then go pick up a stalk of brocolli at one of the many nearby mercado.
author: J K.

description: What can I say except that the food is consistently good.  Good service.  Could be cleaner though.
author: blink v.

description:
=( no more carnitas. Fine, I'll have the carne asada burrito.  

More meat please! Otherwise, it was a decent burrito, nothing great.

I won't be making any special trips to SF to visit this place.
author: Mel P.

description:
My Mexican friends brought me here late one night after the club so you know it's real. I got tacos and a horchata. BOMB!!! Better than any East Oakland taco truck I've ever tried and trust, I grew up in Oakland so I've tried plenty.

The lines can be super long at 1 in the morning, but moves fast. Beware the tables fill up quick and you may have to deal with drunk club goers or the occasional hobo looking for spare change. I definitely wanna come back in the daytime the next time I'm in the Mission.
author: Michelle T.

description: Overrated. Came here cause of the Nate Silver burrito bracket and was disappointed in this restaurant. First, a giant cockroach came out and crawled all over some other tables food while I was there. The roach then proceeded over to attack me. I stayed and ate after my friend killed it. Second, the food was subpar. I got the carne asada super burrito and was not impressed. The beans and rice were bland and needed more spice. The meat was ok. No salsa bar or unlimited chips. The green salsa was good. This place ain't no la tacqueria.
author: J. W.

description: Stumbled across this taqueria searching for a place to use the bathroom. Not only did they not care if we bought something before we used their bathroom, but the inside of their restaurant was spacious and clean. I ordered the breakfast burrito with black beans for about $6 and was not disappointed. I took it to go since we were making our way down Mission for the Carnaval and they packed up my burrito with the best homemade tortilla chips and salsa.
author: Annabelle P.

description:
4.0 Stars

A late night exploration of the Mission district led me and my group of friends to Tacqueria Cancun. It was 1AM and this place was packed full of people. We thought it was a good indication if the food was good or not, so we went in to give it a try.

I wasn't even drunk the night I went and the food was TASTY! I have yet to find a good Mexican place in San Jose that can rival the awesome Mexican food in the Mission district of San Francisco.

Looking at the bright yellow menu you'll see they serve your typical fare of Mexican choices like burritos, tacos, enchiladas, quesadillas, and nachos. That's never a bad thing because they make them well.

I was craving tacos at first, but then realized they're $2.30/each! Holy cow that's expensive. I was thinking in my head, I'll still be hungry after eating a couple of these. So a quick tip for the HUNGRY beasts out there: get the burrito for the "best bang for your buck".

I ordered the Burrito Mojado with Carne Asada and I couldn't be happier. This is their version of the wet burrito. It was loaded with meat, rice, pinto beans, onions, cilantro, and salsa and then topped off with red enchilada sauce, green salsa, melted cheese, sour cream, and more salsa. I had to share this because it was that BIG!

Taqueria Cancun will also provide you some chips with your order. The chips are thicker and have a very grainy texture to them. On the side it comes with Guacamole and Pico de Gallo. Both of the Guacamole and Pico de Gallo have a spicy kick to them and I love it!!

I had an awesome experience exploring the Mission and my stomach was even happier to explore Tacqueria Cancun.

It's CASH only, but they have an ATM inside.

== A MUST TRY! ==
author: Jason H.

description: It is not my favorite Taqueria but it is a good alternative. It's huge so it's great if you want to have lunch and dinner for the price of one meal. It is kinda busy so you have to wait in line a bit. It is not in the best neighborhood of SF. Overall I would recommend it if you want good Mexican food and you are in this neighborhood.
author: Nicolas V.

description:
A burrito like this is guaranteed to shut up even the most annoying drunken chatter. I promise. So if any friends are in town visiting and you've run out of things to talk about, come to this edible mexican version of a library.

The moment your two hands cradle a burrito behemoth of this proportion, your eyes will lock into focus and the feasting will begin. 

You can try to save the second half of Taqueria's hand tossed tortilla burritos for later but I doubt you'll be able to hold back. The freshly sliced avocados, heat checking sour creme, and don't forget mounds of salty n crunchy meat bits are damn impossible to pull away from.

Just ask your friends. After they're done eating of course.

Until next time. This was Spencer C.
author: Spencer C.

description:
Super burrito me because it's THAT GOOD here.  

The ENCHILADAS are also the best enchiladas I have ever had.  The sauce makes this dish.  The rice and beans on the side are perfectly cooked!  

The prices here are also amazing.  I always bring my out of town friends here to experience some real Mexican food.
author: Sharon L.

description:
Had the burrito mojado sin carne. It was fairly good, but the enchilada sauce that covered the whole burrito was overpowering and made it a bit soggy, although I was expecting the sogginess. Excellent salsas though (and unlimited too!) I'm a lettuce and tomato kind of guy, so I would have liked it if the burrito had more inside than beans, cheese, rice, sour cream, and avocado.

Say what you want about the area surrounding this place, but you can't deny that it has character. An afternoon here would only be made better by a burrito in my hand, and Taqueria Cancún's isn't shabby by any standards.
author: Rutvij B.

description: Fun, festive, delicious, spicy and inexpensive. Two people split the main event carnitas burrito and an al pastor taco. The fresco was peach and pineapple - very good! Will go back for sure.
author: PK R.

description:
I'm not sure why but I love this place.  It's a total dive but their burritos are awesome.  I almost always get the super burrito which comes with guacamole and avocado.  Their salsa a default medium.  They toast up their tortilla on the grill instead of steam heating giving it a very light crunch, and everything comes nice and hot, not warm like most places.  The prices are pretty cheap too.

This is a classic dive Mission burrito place that is good both during the day and when you're drunk.  Just wish they had a salsa bar.
author: Shane E.

description: Just come here and eat their burrito or super nachos...I mean, come on, over a thousand POSITIVE reviews? What more can I say to express how good this place is?
author: Tim P.

description:
For a place this festive inside---and I mean festive (this place looks like a pinata exploded all over this place!!!)---their food does not live up to the visual expectations this place provides....

We got the Mojado Super Burrito---otherwise known as the BIG ONE. And it is massive. Really massive. So they don't lie there. BUT it is just so huge and with so little flavor that it is just a huge huge waste of calories and a huge huge waste of time eating. The mojado sauce was just about the only positive thing in that big burrito, and really, for a place in the Mission district this place just is not anywhere near the standards of  places nearby....ahem...el farolito!!! this was just disappointing.....at least I had festive decor to stare at while we attempted to force this burrito into our mouths....

But Taqueria Cancun....you made me sad I made one of my last meals and last attempts at getting good, delicious mexican food before flying back to Boston here...it almost made me look forward to some of the wannabe mexican food boston has to offer!!
author: Sarah G.

description:
The Breakfast Burrito was a bit different than what I'm used to; the one's I have had before usually only have eggs, sausage, potatoes, avocado, salsa, maybe some other kind of vegetable. This one had rice (and maybe beans? I can't remember right now) too. It was delicious though! So if you're in the mood for one, I'd definitely recommend going here for one.

The Regular Carne Asada burrito was pretty amazing, the meat was well-seasoned, cooked really well, and they were generous with the amount added. And it was only 4.99. That's a pretty awesome price even by Mission standards. 
I've gone to other places in the Mission and this is definitely one of the cheapest places (while still being absolutely delicious). I also had the horchata which is also one of the better ones I've had.

Point being, it's a great place for cheap Mexican food.
author: Jen N.

description: Never been in this place, and am I so happy I did. Hubby was hungry and wanted a quick bite. Little did he know he know he stumbled upon a gem. Super Carne Asada Burrito all the way. Juicy delicious meat, no skimping of it at all! Will be back!
author: Karla L.

description: While the rating could easily be interpreted as bias because of the late night attendance element, there is an actual quality to the food and the establishment not surpassed by many of its type. Must stop any time of day!
author: Chris B.

description: I came here after a few beers with friends on a weekend.  It was open late and just looked like a delicious mexican burrito/taco restaurant from the outside.  It catered perfectly to what I was looking for.  Hot, seemingly fresh, and quick.  The bench style seating was also kind of neat, you feel like you are sharing this authentic mexican food experience with the people beside you.  The only thing holding me back from 5 stars are because I had to bus the trays and cups from the people eating there before me.  With a little more housekeeping and wiping tables down, this is would be a 5-star spot.
author: Joe L.

description:
What better way to start my Yelp quest than to write about my recent trip to the city that started it all, San Francisco.

How do you "stumble" across a restaurant with over 1,000 Yelp reviews? You're not familiar with the area, you've parked at the northern end of the Mission District, you're trying to walk to El Farolito, and you're hungry as a hippo.

This place was jammed packed on a Sunday evening. I didn't time how long it took from the second I walked in to the time I took my first bite, but I have that same feeling right now waiting for season 3 of Eastbound and Down to start. Yes, that long! 

I was set on ordering the quesadilla suiza at El Farolito to see what all the fuss is about, but since I didn't reach my destination I was delighted to see that Taqueria Cacun also offered this dish. I came with a friend and we decided to share a quesadilla suiza and a chicken super burrito. How can you resist ordering anything with the word "super" in the title? I dare you to try. Our order number was finally called and let me tell you, the quesadilla suiza was definitely worth the wait. This was made with a healthy serving of grilled beef surrounded by globs and globs of cheese melted in between two massive flour tortillas. The tortillas were grilled to perfection, just the right crispiness. The extremely tender beef combined with the cheese satisfied all my taste buds. 

Now on to the chicken "I got tricked by the name super" super burrito. It was a little bit of chicken and a ton of rice and beans. I think it also came with a dab of lettuce, tomatoes, and avocado. I couldn't tell because the amount of rice and beans completely covered up the deliciousness of the rest of the burrito. If only Super Man was called Man, I would have avoided this blunder.

Had we ordered two quesadilla suizas, there's no doubt in my mind this would have been a 5-star review.  I may never find out how delicious El Farolito is, but at least I can be the 886th person here on Yelp to give Taqueria Cancun at least 4 stars.
author: Eric K.

description:
The first time I came here, it was almost 2 in the morning, I'd had a ROUGH night and this was, seriously, the best food I've ever tasted. Like, how wide can I open my mouth to get this burrito in as quickly as possible, best food.

And while my subsequent (sober) visits to TC have served to somewhat disillusion me, it's good, cheap Mexican fare. I doubt I'll have a Cancun visit that was quite as magical as that first trip, but it's the kind of food that warms your tummy while you sit down on a Sunday night and catch up on emails. That sets you back $6 for a beer and a dinner you can't finish. That requires you to carry half a burrito in your purse for the rest of the day while you walk around the Mission after stopping here for lunch.

And, as far as I'm concerned, any place that allows me to positively feast with the cash I have in my coat pocket at the tail end of a brutal Saturday night, or that can half-live up to my drunken fantastical expectations is pretty darn good in my book.

(I have never been to actual Cancun)
author: Amanda F.

description: The very first restaurant I ever ate at in SF so it holds a special place in my heart!  I'm not a Mexican food fan, and I don't like burritos... EXCEPT for the burritos here.  Granted I get a vegetarian super burrito with black beans and NO rice... but it's incredible.  I tried a few burritos this way at other places and did not like them at all.  Also the salsa verde is the bomb.  So hot it makes the yupsters from the Marina cry.  Round it off with a Mexican coke or Grapefruit Jarritos and you're in heaven.
author: Sharon E.

description: I'm pretty sure the Carne Asada Super Burrito here can cure all sorts of illnesses with sheer flavor alone. Upon the first bite it was like a chorus of guacamole angles singing the song to which the carne asada and sour cream danced. It was ten full minutes before I gazed down and beheld: "I have only made it half way through this burrito".  Tl;dr - Cheap, great food.
author: Arman N.

description:
You're walking the streets of Mission, on a hunt for the best Mexican food. Look no further, Taqueria Cancun has the best Super Pollo tacos in town. Don't want pollo? Try another meat, you won't be disappointed. What's pollo? You're in the wrong place, just kidding, give it a try! Best "hole in the wall" taqueria! I go out of my way to come here.

I see a lot of reviews about how it's a great late night drunk food. It tastes just as good when you're sober and it's still daylight out! Bring cash!!
author: Jenna P.

description:
Donde esta la horchata y donde esta mas salsa??
They don't serve horchata here. There's no salsa bar either, you have to ask for more salsa at the counter if you're dining in and want more.  When you dine, the guys bring you water and your order, they don't really come around and cater to you, its a pretty informal atmosphere.  I don't mind getting up a few times for more 1-oz size of salsa but I do mind that there's no horchata. Bummer. I really was craving it.  

I think I've finally found the closest thing to a San Diego burrito in SF.  What I like about the carnitas and carne asada burritos here is how juicy and tender the meat is; the carne aside is cut up into tiny pieces- something I've never experience anywhere, not dry, very tasty. Although they skimp on the salsa and chips, they make it all up in their burritos. These burritos are BIG with the right amounts of each ingredient, loads of guacamole line the tortilla, lots of guac and salsa are mandatory in my Mexican food. I was only able to eat half. 

This place is in the mission and I would've had a more pleasant experience if it weren't for the bum coming in half a dozen times, yelling something, getting kicked out, coming back in, yelling something again, getting kicked out, he finally came back and changed it up- suddenly a liquor bottle appeared in his hand which he proceeded to guzzled down. It was like a creepy magic show desperate for applause or any kind of credit. Props to the guys in the kitchen for keeping their cool and pushing him out every single time he came in. Trying to eat with a screaming bum in front of your table is intense. He deserves THE most annoying bum award. Burritos are amazing here. Drunk bums are wackjobs.
author: Thuy M.

description: Visited this place in February while visiting SF and my taste buds were blown away.  Can't remember the name of the ginormous burrito that I had but it was incredible.  It was so huge I couldn't finish it so I had it for breakfast the next morning.  The horchata was pretty good.  If you're in the Mission district, this is the place to go.
author: Brenda L.

description:
I cannot find a better burrito than at taqueria cancun.  I've lived in SF, Denver, and now Dallas.  I've also visited Mexico several times, but I cannot find a burrito that compares to the amazingness of Taqueria Cancun!  Fresh avocados, housemade tortillas, and great hours. 

Please come to Dallas, then my life will be complete.  Until then, I will crave you and plan to visit on my return!
author: Pam S.

description: Good portion sizes, good prices, and a nice little place to sit with the front door open watching the Mission. Not the best carne asada I've ever had, but they're super liberal with the avocado and very very friendly.
author: Haley M.

description:
One of the best Taquerias in the mission, Cancun serves up some of the most reliably huge meals regardless of what you get, and I'm a big fan of getting lots of food for my dollar. On that note, be warned it's CASH ONLY.
I usually go for the carnitas burrito on instinct, and that hasn't let me down yet. The ala mexicana plate looks amazing as well, and I want to try that next time I find myself in the area.
author: Nik K.

description: Meh.  Not that flavorful. The tortilla was a little different at least.   Still haven't found many Mexican  places up here in the bay area similar to those in so cal. Guess the search contintinues.
author: Jonathan A.

description:
There is always something interesting going on at Cancun whether its 1pm or 2am. Been coming here for years and have always loved this taqueria. Every time I come here I get to speak spanish and everyone flips out. I'm always known as "La Chelita" when I come here, which means very white female, but somehow Latina. It reminds me of back home with all the mariachi music, flowers, religious decorations, christmas lights, random jukebox, sketch atm, and wooden tables. Heck in spirit of La Mission, I'll write this review in Spanish. 

Taqueria Cancun es uno de las taquerias que mas me gusta en la Mission. Siempre hay gente, la linea va super rapido y todo es muy bueno. Me gusta mucho mas el que esta en la Mission que el que esta en market. Los trabajadores son mucho mas simpatico y no hay gente loca afuera. Lo que mas me gusta ordenar son los nachos, super quesadilla de carne o el super burrito de pollo. Los super tacos son buenos, pero no es lo mejor aqui. Se te puede desbaratar tu comida y cuidado comes el papel, yo se que tienes hambre, puedo te puede pasar. Siempre siempre me pido una jarrita de mandarina cuando vengo aqui, me recuerda a la rojita de Nicaragua. Todo es super delicioso! Que haria sin esta taqueria?
author: Stephanie M.

description: The Al Pastor Burrito is freaking delicious, huge, and cheap.  Somehow it doesn't even put you to sleep after.  Great for lunch.
author: Alex H.

description: This has been one of my favorite Taco/Burrito spots in the Bay Area for years. The Burritos are Huge and made with fresh ingredients right before your eyes. Nice family owned restaurant with that SF Mission District feel. A Must for locals and Tourist.
author: Lenisha S.

description:
My Dad loves burritos and dealing with me his whole life he deserves the best F!#$!%^& burrito EVER.

I yelped this bad boy and KABLAMO the yelp community did not fail me.

The burritos warm buttery flour tortilla tickles your "situation". The hot delicious carne asada, mixed in with the fresh ingredients that were planted with a pinch of Dumbledor's Magic and a Chuck Norris's front kick, give this my friends the best burrito I HAVE EVER TASTED.

I may stand corrected but I have had my share of burritos.  Burritos that are messy and fall to pieces.  Burritos that are lop sided and just stupid. Rice that looks like a clump of soggy wet napkins.  Beans that are gross and made you feel better you that you pooped them out.

I love this burrito!
author: Chris L.

description:
My Favourite SF Taqueria!!

You need $6, buy an Al Pastor Super Burrito. It will sort you out no matter what ales you whether it is the flu, a hangover, a broken leg or a broken heart you will feel a million times better once this brick of delicious food has been consumed!
author: Chris M.

description: Their wet burrito is the bomb! Their super tacos are very good. Their quesadillas are not bad. The only criticism I have is they don't have a salsa bar. They are a bit stingy with the salsa and chips. I'd like it better if they had self-service salsa bar.
author: Nicholas B.

description:
The Burrito Majodo is MONSTROUS. I love the enchilada sauce. It makes every part of the burrito awesome to eat. Without it, I would have to say that there was a bit too much rice in it, and I wish the carne asada chunks were bigger. I like my burritos meatier. But then again, it's not possible for a mere human like me to finish a burrito like theirs. 

Dang, their guacamole hecka beat me. Spiiiiiccyyyyyy. Each time I took a bite of that, I had to drink four gulps of water. Haha, so eventually, I just took that off my burrito. 

Great price for a hecka interesting burrito. Never seen anything like it in LA, but I haven't been around my local taquerias. I know, for shame. But this is a pretty good find for a random stop in Mission.
author: Sally T.

description:
Dear Taqueria Cancun, 

Thank you for never disappointing me. Thank you for serving up delicious, sloppy and savory food on demand that is consistently crave-worthy and reasonably priced. There isn't anything really setting Cancun apart from some other really super Mexican burrito shops in the area, I just happen to go to Cancun the most often. 

Viva super burrito con carne asada. Mmmmm.
author: Kelly B.

description:
This was the place that changed my mind about mexincan food!
The burrito is great, the place is always packed.
Everything taste great, the service is good.
author: Danielle S.

description:
Has still got it.

Tip: this is the one with the "kill whitey" Salsa Verde. 

No charges for chips. Loads of salsa. Fast. Dirty. Cheap. Good.
author: Glen M.

description:
I remember it so well but I hardly remember it. We got one vegetarian super burrito to share. She let me have the first bite!!! Oh she was a good friend. An angel of a person. For giving me the good cheesey creamy bites.
Wrapped tidily in foil, hot, oozing, heaven in a tortilla.

This is the best burrito I've ever eaten. Yum yum yum.

This burrito. This super veggie taqueria cancun burrito that I walked to from bean bag on divis after a pint or two took my burrito virginity. So. This burrito and me have got something special. A sacred bond exists between me and what dwells wrapped in tortilla and foil.
author: Libra J.

description:
Oh taqueria cancun! It's funny that I'm writing this review the day after I booked an all-inclusive trip to CANCUN!! This is my go-to spot for mexican in SF better than El Farolito, Papalote etc. I haven't found better in SF. Everything here is delicious and even my vegetarian friends (I won't name names...) LOVE the veggie burritos. Veggie burritos with rave reviews?! they must be doing it right. 

I could eat this 5 days a week and die a happy man!
author: Mike K.

description: This place gets one star for being the only burrito joint open before 10. And one star for having a decently spicy green salsa. Other than that, my burrito was subpar. I had the carnitas, and the meat had no flavor. The beans had no flavor. The rice had no flavor. I'm at a loss as to the hype this spot gets. The applebees/chilis of mission burrito joints.
author: Chaz G.

description:
Hole-in-the-wall Mission awesomeness. Went in on a Monday night when there was a short line and a decent amount of seating at their picnic-style tables. A girlfriend and I split the grilled chicken mojada (read: a larger-than-life burrito smothered in red sauce and cheesy goodness). We each started at one end of the burrito and were left stuffed, with the middle portion to take home. While the flavors were not especially mind-blowing, the burrito and its component parts were fresh and tasty. Plus, the guy at the cash register was so, so nice; he was all smiles and gave us mucho free chips and salsa (it must have been my girlfriend's cute kiddos that did him in). I have no idea where TC's ingredients come from, how the animals were raised, or whether or not they use GMO corn, but I'm willing to let those things slide for this place. It should be noted that the salsa was a wee bit on the spicy for my gringo tastes, but Cancún wisely supplies ice cold water to alleviate the burn.

Cash only, but there's a non-bank affiliated ATM right in front of the register. 

(I hear from multiple sources that La Taqueria is even better, but I haven't had the opportunity yet to test that theory.)
author: Amanda V.

description:
I have twenty six years of history with this place and without it would have starved. Used to be you had to watch your back when you ventured to this section of town but it was my neighborhood and this was a staple of my survival diet. 

Sure the Mission is loaded with amazing burrito places but Cancun was always my favorite; perhaps it's how incredibly fresh the avocado's taste... sure but for me it's the way they lightly grill the tortilla + the jukebox rocks.

In your hunt for the perfect burrito be sure to give it a try as you will not be dissapointed.
author: Michael F.

description: There is a reason and only one reason why I keep coming back to this restaurant; that reason is called shrimp tostada ceviche. Not only it's a great dish, but also it's a steal, only $3 (same I would pay for a taco). I have tried other dishes here, most of them are barely average and the reason why people eat at to Taqueria Cancun is because it's located by the bars and they serve food until 1 am. They get 3 stars for the average tacos and burritos and an extra star for the tostada ceviche.
author: Jessica R.

description: Definitely deserves its high ratings.  Fast, efficient, cheap, and yummy Mexican food AND it's opened late makes for great drunchies.  I usually get al pastor and carne asada but I think I remember the lengua being delicious in my drunk filled haze.
author: Jane N.

description: I had the vegetarian burrito that everyone has been raving about, and it was disappointing.  I thought it could have used a lot more seasoning and flavor.  I probably will not get it again.
author: Lian L.

description:
Definitely my favorite taqueria in the Mission! I frequent this place once or twice a week. My go-to dish is the super burrito (chicken, no sour cream). 

They're fast, reliable, cheap, and tasty. I love that they melt the cheese on the tortilla before putting the other ingredients on. Call ahead if you're just getting pick up!
author: Max H.

description:
I like how this place cook/ grill the tortilla. 

I got a veggie burrito that was delicious.

I know my SIL and brother like coming here because this taqueria makes vegetarian/ vegan friendly food....and my that I mean, I guess their quaility of ingredients and flavoring is better than other places they have tried.

I have been here a couple times...one of these days I will try their carnitas and carne. The guy at the register recommended carne, so maybe carne it is...next time!
author: Anisha G.

description: Your typical standard super burrito in the Mission. They do toast/cook the tortillas before wrapping them up with the fun stuff, which I love since it gives them a crunchy, chewy texture. I do wish they'd put less salt in everything they cook there. I was throwing down bottle after bottle of water the hours after finishing half my super burrito.
author: Henry W.

description: Breakfast burritos were bomb. Really big for the price. Pro til, order your burrito "Super" to add avocado and sour cream.
author: Lazaro R.

description:
Omg deliciousness.  My boyfriend, and his mom (who was visiting from Mexico) thought it was good so who can argue with that?! 

I don't think I ever ate so much in one sitting before in my life.  I loved it and will def be back!
author: Sang L.

description: Taqueria Cancun is the best whether you're drunk or not.  HUGE burritos, cheap prices, and a fun crowd.
author: Stef S.

description: Seriously good hole in the wall mission style Mexican food. Those chorizo super tacos, UGH, SO GOOD.
author: Erika B.

description: This is not as great as everyone cracks it out to be. .. take it from someone who has eaten Mexican food their whole life, and grew up eating at taquerias on the Mission. First off, they are cash only and their atm machine was broken, so my friends treked to 16th street to get to the closest bank while I saved us a table (it was pretty crowded). After they returned with a 20 dollar bill for me I ordered the Super Nachos with Carne Asada. They arrived pretty quickly, but they were a gloppy, greasy mess. The meat was oily and not appealing at all. It honestly seemed as if the meat had been sitting in grease for a while. The chips are clearly from Costco- party size and cardboard flavor. Definitely not the most authentic option in the Mission. And not were the local latino people eat either.
author: Violeta G.

description:
JESUS CHRIST WHERE DO I BEGIN? 

Now that I live abroad,I have dreams about the vegetarian burrito with black beans. It is hands down, the best veggie burrito I have ever tasted. I really like the communal seating too. 

I miss living in the Mission just because I could roll out of bed and come here, or hit it up before or after a night of partying. I would eat here several times a week! 

Needless to say, whenever I come back for a visit, I go to Cancun religiously. The chips aren't that great, but the spicy salsa verde is to die for. The horchata is pretty tasty as well. 

Cheap, greasy, fast, delicious, and friendly service. What else could you ask for?
author: Tara M.

description:
if there's a better burrito in san francisco, i'll never find it. anytime i'm in the mission, i loyally head to cancun. likewise, if there's something better on the taqueria cancun menu, i'll never find it. the burritos are simply perfect and i've never wanted to stray.

i prefer chicken, but i've tried the carne asada and al pastor and even gone vegetarian. seriously, the vegetarian burrito at cancun is better than most meat burritos elsewhere. no joke! everyone raves about the meats and fillings, which are great, but i think there's something special about the tortilla, i can't figure it out.

i hear the burrito mojado is awesome but there's something about holding a burrito in two hands, peeling away the foil, and taking a giant bite.
author: Gary D.

description:
Let me start by saying I love spicy salsa. However, there is a point where "hot" overpowers flavor. Both of their salsas are too hot in the sense that they don't taste very good and interfere with the flavor of the food. 

The carne asada burrito I got tasted like it was getting old, was not very flavorful and made me (mind you, I have an iron-clad stomach) mildly ill.
author: Sarah D.

description:
Group of four of us went here a few days back.

Two of us were given the wrong burritos for our order.  So that's 50% wrong. Not great, as it goes. Anyway, as I'm a veggie and I'd been given a beef burrito, I took mine back. This was not looked on kindly and, after a bit of to-ing and fro-ing as to whose fault it was (really?), I got my money back.

For what it's worth, the others all said that their burritos were pretty damn good.  Just make sure you get the right one.
author: Max S.

description: Excellent and sizable vegetarian (and other) burritos made quickly. No complaints here other than that credit cards are not accepted; however, there's an ATM located in the restaurant.
author: Richard B.

description: One of the best Mexican restaurant in Mission district. As I stepped into the restaurant, I could feel the vibe of Cancun itself. One burrito can make you so full that you can't walk.
author: Ilhoon J.

description: this has to be my favorite resturaunt. i go here once a week and i have been for 2 years. i will never get tired of this place  hands down the best burritos!! friendly staff as well!
author: Ysabelle D.

description: Worst veggie burrito. Not understanding why anyone would consider this a great place to get a vegetarian burrito. Only rice cheese and beans. The Only vegetables are in the salsa. Gross.
author: Yana K.

description: To paraphrase Ron Burgundy:  I've been eating the same burrito for 18 years.  And in no way is that depressing.
author: Floyd B.

description: Nothing interesting  me to return to this place... I can't speak for all the dishes; either the beef burrito or chicken did for me.... I'll stick with other places around the mission....
author: Pedro D.

description: Second-best burrito in SF (after La Taquería).  This is the place to go for al pastor, although it's typically a little sweet for me and I prefer the pollo.  Cancún's burritos are enormous, and very satisfying.  You can skip the chips, however.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Super cheap, super tasty. 

You pay $5 or $6 and you get a gigantic burrito with chips and a few salsas. You have to handle this bad boy with two hands. 

Ironically, I ordered a Vegetarian Burrito with no cheese and no sour cream (because I'm one of those annoying vegan types), and then I ordered a Super Burrito with lengua for my omnivorous dining companion. 

FYI, lengua is beef tongue. She told me she'd always wanted to try it, so why not? 

The staff were all super friendly and even tried to teach me some basic Spanish at the register. I played dumb, even though I frequently speak Español at my restaurant job. ;)

One minor complaint: I could have used a few more containers of salsa, but I didn't want to bother them for more. That's just me. I'm picky, I like to drown my burritos in the stuff. 

The pico de gallo and salsa verde are both AMAZING. Definitely on the spicy side, so they're not for the faint of heart. 

If you don't mind walking past a few vagrants and prostitutes on your way back to the BART station, go for it.
author: Brandi W.

description: Service is slow. Had a wet burrito with chicken, it was pretty good. Had a regular burrito with carne asada and got this ground beef crap. Not so good.
author: Will D.

description:
I came here during a weekend visit to my friend in San Fran (S.F.). Being from New England, I told my friend I wanted the best burrito in San Fran (S.F.) or I was going to pound him. I'm glad he picked this place!

Got the Super Burrito with a mix of Carne Asada and Carnitas. My friend(let's just call him Dan) had no idea you could get two meats in one burrito. I told him he's an idiot and that he should be doing that from now on. 

YOU GET MORE MEAT IF YOU DO IT THAT WAY! not much more, but a little bit more......

anyways, this was awesome as I got the best of both worlds (beef and pork) in one burrito . It was Excellent. The best burrito I've ever had. 

The green sauce they give with the chips is awesome, I wish I got that in my burrito. 

I wanted to bring a burrito back on the plan with me, but I didn't think the FAA would let me because the bombs I dropped after eating one would endanger the welfare of the passengers.
author: Simpson S.

description:
Cheap and good Mexican, but not for vegetarians or for people with heart problems. The best dishes we had were the ceviche tostada and the carnitas tacos. The salads were fresh, but there was so much greasy meat on them it was more like a meat salad.

The atmosphere is very downmarket, with plasticky tables kind of like a McDonald's. I didn't think it was particularly clean, but this is no different from most other hole-in-the-wall taquerias in the Mission. Bus your own tray, there is no table service here!

I was annoyed that they use styrofoam cups here. I thought those had long since been outlawed. There is a great deal of waste, even for dine-in customers.
author: John S.

description:
This is what a taco place selling burittos and such in the Mission should be.

But no !!
Eater SF reports that Taqueria Cancun at 19th and Mission, the flagship shop for the local burrito chain, is at risk of closing. The burrito shop has been operating without a longterm lease for the better part of a year.

https://missionlocal.org/2014/09/could-taqueria-cancun-be-leaving-us-eater/
author: Gregory D.

description:
Let me articulate exactly what is right about Taqueria Cancun's super tacos. 

- The cheese is the base of the taco, going underneath the other ingredients, on the tortilla.
- They grill the tortilla, which makes it less prone to structure failure (and not gummy, like steaming will do) and melting the cheese into the other ingredients, thus enhancing deliciousness and cohesion. 
- They use slices of avocado instead of guac, thus no extra sour cream (i usually get it sans sour cream anyway) or other hidden ingredients. 
- the hot green salsa. if you know, you know.

Other "taquerias", take heed.
author: Tom H.

description:
I really love this place. I'd suggest coming with a friend or two and splitting dishes. I went with some friends and that is what we did. The ceviche tostada was really great. Perfect for a hot SF day. The fish was fresh and it was actually pretty cheap (under $4 if I recall correctly). We also had a wet burrito. It was pretty filling and tasty. The sauce had a great taste. It seems like they make it themselves.

The restaurant has picnic tables instead of usual chairs. I wish more places did this. It makes it much easier to cram all your friends and family around a table.

Some of my friends live closeby and after many trips to the taquerias in the area, we think this might be our winner.

Go here if you want no nonsense mexican food.
author: Arun V.

description: We stumbled across Taqueria Cancun while out celebrating Halloween, and I'm pretty sure it was the highlight of my night.  I got a carne asada super burrito, and it was AMAZING. Yes, even a burrito from Taco Bell tastes amazing to me after a night of drinking.  BUT the burrito was SO huge that I could only eat half of it, and when I ate the other half today, while completely sober, I was still completely in love with it.
author: Cici A.

description: pretty darn good!! kinda surprised by the prices, compared to Los Angeles. still delicious. will return
author: Arit B.

description: THE VEGETARIAN BURRITOS AREN'T VEGETARIAN! This is false advertising. Vegetarians don't want chicken broth or "Jugo de pollo" in their rice or Manteca in their beans. Call it a burrito without meat, but Vegetarian is misleading because most vegetarians won't think to ask!!! Shame on you Taqueria Cancun :(  Silent boycotting begins.
author: Onika C.

description: Boom! Best taqueria in sf, which makes it the best in the states.  As a vegetarian I always order the super vegi, black beans with mexican coke.  Makes me hungry thinking about it.
author: Kellen H.

description:
can't decide between tacos, tortas, burritos, and quesadillas? GET ALL OF THEM. except tacos. we'll get those next time.

torta: what i tried first, and it remained my favorite. nice and greasy carne; fresh and juicy tomatoes and avocado, melty cheese, and the kind of soft french roll you would expect with a torta. DELICIOUS. would devour again

burrito: second. pretty excellent for a burrito. not a huge burrito fan when good tortas are in order, but this one was pretty delicious. all the fixins' you would expect, with good chunks of pollo asado. 

quesadilla con carne: probably one of the best meaty/full quesadillas i've ever had. minimal sogginess from cheese goo. delicious avocado (again). needed to be eaten with fork and knife to avoid goodness-falling-out problems. 

all of that, PLUS horchata!!!: soooo gooood. the right amount of ricey-ness and the perfect amount of cinnamon. not too sweet; just perfectly thirst-quenching. 


won't have to eat for another few hours at least......
author: Samantha S.

description: Years ago I had a really nasty burrito from taqueria cancun on Market, and kind of blew this place off. Of course everyone raved about cancun but I wasn't convinced until tonight. I liked the efficient ordering system, although it was so fast that I was almost unprepared. Everything was very clear in placing the order, though. Everyone seemed pretty friendly at the communal seating. The assembled burrito (super carnitas w/out sour cream = rice, pinto beans, cheese, avocado, salsa) was delicious comfort food, although the salsa that they give you in the burrito and with complimentary chips, while delicious, has some seriously hot pepper chunks in it. How can other people even stand to serve burritos without toasting up the outside?? A cold tortilla is just not as good.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I've traveled the whole country and never had a burrito this damn good. In fact, for years I hated burritos (I'm from Boston) because they always seemed to taste off and make me sick.

This one is HUGE, cheap, wonderful ingredients and amazing. I think it's the way they cook the rice? I'm not sure. The meat is always delicious too. I like the carne asada but my friends have let me try their chicken and pork and both are yummy. 

Get the super burrito (with everything in it: guac, cheese, sour cream, salsa) for $6. It's probably 3 meals in one. Comes with homemade chips. 

Seriously, worth the trip to the Mission (or their other locations!)

Ca$$$h only!
author: christine c.

description:
This place has overtaken the once great, recently lously El Farolito as my favorite. The burritos, tortas, and tacos are all bursting with flavor, have their ingredients well distributed throughout, and are reasonably priced for the Mission. I've tried their chorizo, chicken, carne asada, al pastor, and vegetarian options--all delicious. The only dud I've had was the taco salad.

For anyone who doesn't get the appeal of the torta, this one's for you. They know the secret for grilling the bread shut, creating a seal that holds in all the oozy goodness. It ranks with the platonic version of my Northwest Side of Chicago upbringing.

Keep up the good works, compas.
author: Mike B.

description:
So it's Friday night. Date night! Yay! I was waiting for my boyfriend to pick me up so we could go grab a bite to eat and get in to some Friday night shenanigans. Unluckily for me, he found parking right outside of my place, which is very rare on a Friday night. So he parks the car and proceeds to tell me that he would rather just grab a bite to eat and make it a Netflix night. I can't say I blame him since he commutes 100 miles a day.

So we walk a few blocks to Taqueria Cancun to get some din-din. I order a super quesadilla de carnitas and he orders a super burrito de asada. We get our food quickly and proceed to start eating. The food is very ho-hum. I guess I'm spoiled from eating good food at El Farolito on 24th and Mission. As we're eating, a musician walks in and starts playing for tips. All of a sudden, loud music starts playing, drowning the musician out. The musician keeps playing despite being drowned out by the music. As the musician is playing over the blaring music, the guys behind the counter are laughing and mocking the poor musician. My boyfriend and I immediately lost our appetites for our sub-par food. The poor musician finishes the first song and proceeds to play another song, despite being drowned out by the loud music and merciless mocking from the guys behind the counter. He finishes playing his second song and goes around asking for tips. My boyfriend and I tip the poor guy trying to make an honest living. And wouldn't you know... as soon as the musician walks out of the taqueria, the music coincidentally stops playing!

The guys at Taqueria Cancun are certified jerks. My boyfriend's family and I will NEVER, EVER patronize this establishment again. Good-bye, Taqueria Cancun. Can't say I'll miss your sub-par food and your sh*tty antics.
author: Lorena D.

description:
Nothing special. Same burrito I could get at any Mexican hole-in-the-wall joint in the Mission District but without the long lines and 25 min wait.

The carne asada was chopped so fine that I had to really dig to find pieces big enough to pick up and feed Josie poodle.  Ton of rice filler.  The salsa was fresh but with lots of raw onion so be warned.

No credit cards. No outdoor seating. Hubby went in and ordered our food then we walked a few blocks down 18th St. and had a lovely picnic with our pup at Dolores Park.
author: Kim W.

description: This place is unsanitary. Something smelled off with my lunch yesterday and sure enough I've been sick since.  Never had a problem at the other location.  bleah! You've been warned.
author: Max B.

description:
about 90% of mexican places i've been to have had dry tortilla, dry rice, and dry/plain carne asada, but no, not Taqueria Cancun... they know how to make a burrito the right way

awesome Super Burrito - It had a good amount of moisture (not oozing, not dry)  and they actually have juicy tender carne asada.  and who doesn't like fresh avacado, soft tortilla, and fresh sour cream??   huge portions too ! 

impression: a great place for a quick lunch - could definitely feed 2 people for $7
author: Tina A.

description:
I have been here 5 times now, each because my friends claim it is the best burrito in the mission.

For me, a great burrito should be moist and well-distributed. Nothing makes me sad more than a bite full of rice, then a bite of only beans, and so on.

The grilled chicken burrito is incredibly dry and the distribution of their burritos have been inconsistent at best.
author: Evan W.

description: Best burrito of my life. So flavorful, so delicious. We split the big burrito and got pulled chicken. For under 9 dollars for an outstanding meal.. I don't know if I can ever go back to my hometown burrito joint. This burrito has changed my life!
author: Ryan G.

description:
Would NEVER eat. Went in after a night in he mission. Used their ATM to get cash and as I turned to the cash register to order my food a GIGANTIC roach or some kind of bug crawled under the yellow glass where they prepare food. Myself and few others seen this and walked out. I felt bad so I went back to inform them as the bug and they act as if I was crazy and looked at me as if I was speaking a foreign language. I would NEVER eat here EVER. I will also be calling the health department on them because that is out right disgusting and they need to be shut down for sure!! 

I'm rating this a ONE because I HAVE to.
author: Danielle D.

description: It is cheap and the food is good.  Four stars though because if you sit in, it's pretty messy because they don't clean the tables frequently.  But for takeout, it's awesome.
author: Daniel Y.

description: Such a great hole in the wall! The burritos were amazing. Would definitely recommend this place for Mexican in mission.
author: Stephanie C.
