Moral of the story: if getting a burrito, tell them to go easy on the rice.
author: Benjamin B.

description: Definitely one of the worse taqueria places i visited in SF. I really cannot agree with other positive comments. We have tried selection of tacos and it was simply not tasty and very greasy.
author: Jm J.

description:
I wish I could give this 5 stars... but after going to el farolitos I just can't do it. 

That being said, the burritos here are ginormous and delicious.  This might be the first place that actually beat me... no... no actually I finished the bad boy off.  I had the Carne Asada the first few times, but when i explored into the carnitas universe  I was equally happy.  Get the Wet burrito if you feel like a challenge, but i"ll admit the middle of it was a bit drier than I'd like (wet burrito--- dry??? wtf!!)

chips wise, I love the salsa, and hate that they give you a limited amount.  Sure you can go up and request more, but who wants to be the annoying gringo?

All in all a top notch burrito.  i'll definatley be back, but only when my true favorite isn't there.
author: Joseph F.

description:
This was only my second trip to San Francisco, but in a total of said two trips, I've managed to hit up this outstanding eatery not once, not twice, but a full FIVE times.

Why?

a) It's cheap. I can get two big burritos (with free chips and salsa), an a HUGE horchata for less than $15. That is ridiculous, especially in SF.
b) They have a vegetarian burrito -- many smaller, family run Mexican food places do not.  They'll also make veggie tacos.
c) Open late.
d) The amazing and slightly ridiculous atmosphere of fresh flowers, loud music, and an explosion of bright color.

Benches are a little meh, given my knee issues, but hey, how can you complain when everything else is just so freaking amazing?
author: Shanna K.

description:
Shrimp Taco was the best i've had in a long time!

Delicious :)
author: jane m.

description: Everything has already been said, but I'm just saying this is definitely my favorite vegetarian burrito so far in San Francisco - mid day or middle of the night.
author: Ramon S.

description:
Dear EF,

I've met someone, and I'm afraid we need to talk.  I am now a turncoat in the burrito wars.

For a long time I swore by your veggie super burritos (why yes, I do eat food that isn't fried or never had a face sometimes) - if I was anywhere in the Mission looking for a burrito, I'd come to you over others, even if it meant a walk or a BART ride.  I've had decent burritos and other assorted goodies elsewhere, but there was something about you that I just craved and adored.

However, I had a revelation encased within a grilled tortilla and a cylinder of aluminum foil this past Friday evening.  I expected good, but not One of The Best Damn Burritos Ever.  Granted, like many places, when you're eating the burrito you'll get a pocket of sour cream here, avocado there, maybe some cheese and rice, then some rice and bean, then a big glop of salsa, but I personally like the little surprises in every bite.  

Unlike *some* places (I don't mean you EF, but one that I have on the side when you're not available - since we're being honest and shit), sour cream and avocado is included in a veggie super burrito and you get a bunch of thick but well-made chips, along with two kinds of salsa.   I'm afraid the chips are better than yours, EF.

I'm sticking with 4.5 stars for now only because I haven't tried anything else yet, but I think this is a relationship I must explore and see where it takes me.  

Sorry EF - I wish I could say it's not you, it's me as personal taste is so subjective, but unfortunately that's the whole point.  We can still be friends though, and we'll totally hang out.  If I'm in the area.   KIT kthxbai. 

Sus.annah B.
author: Sus... B.

description: I really like this place bcuz u guys' burritos, nachos and everything is just so good. Also u guys close late so I can come late at night with my husband haha good!!!!
author: Kimberly K.

description:
I've lived around the corner from this place for about 9 years and the food is still as delicious as it was on day one.  The vegetarian burrito really IS the best in the city.  Don't ask for anything special like black beans, just order it the way they make it.  And enjoy the green salsa, which my roommates and I always buy for parties.

Prices have risen somewhat in the past few years, not nearly as cheap as it used to be, but you're still out of there for $5-$7 if you don't drink.  And the lines are still out the door if you hit it at the wrong time, (either an hour before the bars heat up, the hour when the bars close) so I don't blame them for raising prices a bit.

Awesome decor, awesome music... bring your tourist friends here and blow their minds.
author: Nathan F.

description:
Love this place. My favorite is the quesadilla suiza, which is a normal quesadilla but with a huge slab of carne asada. 
Cheap, great lively atmosphere, a good amount of seating, although it's bench style. A great taqueria. I don't know why, but it's April and there's still Christmas decorations. Makes the place even better.
author: Grace Y.

description: Cheap, fast mexican food and at just the right price! Portions are very large so beware when ordering. Burritos are enormous, tacos are just right, shrimp cocktail fresh. Carne asada the BEST I've ever had! Definately check this place out for cheap, fast, good food!
author: Casie P.

description: Massive burritos covered with salsa sour cream and quacamole. Make sure to try a fresh squeezed juice while you are here. Very cheap... cash only.
author: Matthew A.

description:
Really?  900 people in CA love this place?  I really hope most of these reviews were written after impaired visits since this place isn't serving anything close to what I would call a good burrito.  

After ordering a burrito with no onions, they gave me one with extra onions and took out the tomatoes.  I heard the guy at the counter say no onions to the cook too.  When I got the burrito home and unwrapped, it was almost like someone took a normal sized burrito and shrunk it about 40%.  I really could have eaten four of those things easily.  I was pleasantly surprised by the chips in the bag.  Well, that is until I realized that they were stale.
author: Jason P.

description:
Carne Asada Super Burrito....$5.99
Carnitas Nachos.....
yum.....
nice workers.....
Open super late....nicee.
author: Kelley N.

description:
Damn tasty burrito. So tasty that I waited to freak out about leaving my iphone in some cab until after I finished the entire giant thing. I don't recall much...but the burrito was heavy, full of rice that actually tasted good (hate bland mexican rice), beans (also good), and other stuff that I don't really remember. 

But hey, I woke up NOT hungover & I did not barf which I probably deserved to do so Taqueria Cancun is an excellent place to end the night. And they were still open after all other bars turned us out, which is another plus.
author: Jasmine A.

description: So, my SF newbie self and BFF visiting from Atlanta [literally] stumbled into this place last weekend after a night in the Castro and at the Lex.  We had no idea what a crazy good happenstance this would be.  I had the enormous veggie burrito, and my friend had the super nachos.  I think that the tortilla portion of my burrito may be the best thing I ate; it was so legit.  My friend was smart enough to order the horchata, which was so insane that I will never pass it up again.  Most of the crowd had clearly been partying and loved when the staff intermittently turned off the lights and shouted, "Viva Mexico!"
author: Jenna T.

description: Great burritols- and open late for after late nite adventures. Enjoy all the different items from burritos, tacos, quesadillas etc. Everything is good,  only thing to remember is this place is cash only.
author: Nicole S.

description:
You don't know Mexican until you've lived in southern Cali. 

I had a late night craving and searched Yelp for taco trucks in the mission, when I couldn't find a taco truck I decided to try this place out. I got the super quesadilla with carne asada, cheese, sour cream, avocado (not guacamole) and salsa. i was not impressed, it really made me want to jump in my car and drive down to San Diego to eat at Super Sergio's for some real Mexican food.
author: Nalipay M.

description: I discovered this place long before moving here and it's been one of my favorites ever since.  I used to live in San Diego and Los Angeles so i'm pretty picky about Mexican food.  Their chicken or carne asada torta is STELLAR. I usually get chicken though.   I've had burritos here but they are mediocre compared to the tortas.  Also, i love their chips and the green salsa is AMAZING.
author: Julie B.

description:
Maybe its the alcohol induced hunger but Al Pastor Torta is the bomb here! They grill the bread and whatever goodness they put into this sandwich perfectly. There is a sweet caramelized flavor that is balanced with the creaminess of the avocados and freshness of the tomatoes, and of course the al pastor was excellent. I've heard that the quality of the food here has dropped a little over time but the taste of that first Torta still lingers in my mind. 

Enjoy!
author: Byron C.

description:
I've eaten here before and its always been delicious! 

Except the other night i ate here at 1 am and woke up at 6 vomiting my guts out. Im convinced i got food poisoning from their tacos. 


:(
author: Amy M.

description:
I have to put a disclaimer on this and say that I was mildly drunk when I came here. I should actually be ashamed of myself. I spent the bulk of my life in the Bay Area and consider myself to be a Mexican food connoisseur, yet in spite of that, in my 26 years of life, I have only been to the Mission District once to sample its scrumptious burritos. For shame!!

I live in LA now but I have made it a point to go to at least one burrito place in the Mission every time I go back to the Bay. In my extensive reviews, I found that there is a pretty big consensus that the best two places in the Mission are La Taqueria and Taqueria Cancun. I wasn't sure where exactly on Mission each place was located, so my friend and I decided to drive down the street and stop at the first one we saw.

As is the problem with most places in San Francisco, parking is a beeyotch. Luckily, as soon as we saw Taqueria Cancun, a spot opened up directly across the street. We were there before the bars let out so the place wasn't too packed. It took about 10 min from the moment I first stood in line to when I received my burrito. The ordering system is simple. You pay for what you want at the register and he/she gives you a number. Then the guys preparing the food call our your number when ready. 

I ordered the Carne Asada burrito and it was delicious. The night was a bit hazy but some of the ingredients I remembered being in it were carne asada, rice, sour cream, guacamole, and beans. A pretty normal collection of ingredients but assembled better than pretty much any other place. The beans and meat were phenomenal. They were both so juicy and succulent that I thought I might have to order another one. 

The crowd was nice too. There was a group of Hispanic girls singing along with a guitar behind us making it feel a little more authentic. Every person I caught sight with smiled at me. Even some random girl sat down and told my friend and I how much she loved Filipino people. I definitely am not in LA anymore.
author: Jamie Q.

description:
After living in the Bay for two years and then moving to Portland I can tell you what I miss the most... the veggie burritos from this fine place. If I had to eat one thing every day it would that burrito. The avocados are always perfect and the price is just right. 

YOU MUST EAT THIS BURRITO WITH A COKE (the one in the glass bottle). It is the best way. Also with fresh squeezed lime on it. SO GOOD!!!
author: Gina H.

description: Great food for a great price, not only in quantity but also in quantity. Fast friendly service from the staff. Only reason not gonna give this a 5 star is the fact they dont take cash, but then again that's not uncommon for mission street. Definetly recommend to try it out
author: Yamil M.

description: Nom nom cheap delicious. Good flakey tortillas.
author: R. S.

description:
After eating at many various taquerias around the city (mostly around mission) I've settled on this as my favorite. It's the tastiest and is amongst the cheapest that I've seen. It's about $5 for a regular burrito, $6 for a super burrito or burrito mojado. 

Unless I'm on a lunch break I will always go for the mojado with whatever meat I feel like getting at the time. The al pastor and carne asada are my favorites, I found the shredded chicken to be slightly flavorless and it made the burrito too soggy. 

There is another location downtown at 7th and Market that I'll go to when I'm at work. It doesn't seem to be quite as good as the one on Mission, but that could be in my head. It also has a problem with homeless people standing at the door yelling at you.
author: Kyle K.

description:
This place makes me feel like I'm in Tiajuana! Or at least pretty damn close to the border. 

The carnitas here is amaaaaaaaaazing. You know how when you get cravings for certain things and a place comes to mind...? Well...when I get a craving for pork carnitas...it's Taqueria Cancun, all the way. (although there is a second runner up...see my review about Taqueria Vallarta on 24th Street)

BTW - get the burrito mojado (e.g. wet burrito). You will not regret it. It's heavenly. Do be prepared to take some of it home. HUGE portions.
author: Cat T.

description:
That was a DIRTY good "big burrito" for this Canuck!

I had no idea what to do with this massive plate. I thought it was a pick up and hoover type burrito, but I got a 10" long swimming in red and green goodness type. Uhhhh.
Fork and knife?
Spoon?

Oh F*ck it. Slurped that whole damn plate right in front of everyone.
Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm
author: Peter S.

description: best burritos in the mission. yes, i'm yelling. i'm in love!
author: Priscilla M.

description:
Having lived (alas, no more) in the Nission for years, I used to take Cancun for granted (as my review below might attest). This past weekend I stopped in for a quick late night snack and was reminded of why this place has the reputation it does as one of the better taquerias in town.

I ordered two carne asada tacos, which arrived with meat fit for three. Juicy and tender pieces, fresh and hot salsa, just the right amount of onions and a squirt of lime juice -- well it just doesn't get much better. Oh yes it does, when you wash it down with a bottle of Coke.

Am I still loyal to El Farolito? Yes. But Taqueria Cancun has won back my appreciation. Definitely worth a stop, at least after a night out in the area.
author: Nish N.

description: Awesome vegetarian burritos! Delicious agua frescas, yummy salsa with chips that come with the meal. Hearty, delicious, and cheap! And, let me just tell you that  Tacqueria Cancun is one of the big things I miss after moving away to Boston. No one does vegetarian burritos like Cancun or El Farolito! Plus, it's festive and fun! A great pick-me-up-I-need-to-eat-NOW after an afternoon at El Rio!
author: Heather S.

description:
I love this place.  Every time I've been to Taqueria Cancun, the line is at least 6 deep.  Don't let this discourage you from standing in line; the service is super fast and you have your food in no time.

Its perfect for your late night after club meal.  Prices are great after a night of spending too much on drinks.  

I usually get 2 Carne Asada tacos and I'm good to go.  Super Nachos are also excellent.
author: Bonnie L.

description:
I have a hard time straying from my Holy Trifecta in the 24th area (Papalote, La Taqueria, El Farolito) but will definitely be back to Taqueria Cancun to try their famed vegetarian burrito.  Maybe next time my stomach will not be a mess like it is right now.  But then again, I need to learn to breathe between bites after a pitcher of sangria to the face.

I am very hard to please in the salsa department.  Even the spiciest fuego is not hot enough for me. Taqueria Cancun has the SPICIEST salsa verde I have ever had in my life.  Mother of Mercy!  Their super nachos are bomb.com, topped with heaping slices of avocado and jalapenos.  Carne Asada Quesadilla Suiza?  Meh, not so much.  El Farolito still reigns as king of that dish as far as I'm considered.  

The yellow walls and red brick arches remind me of the inside of a McDonald's.
author: Kerry D.

description: I don't know if they were playing a prank on me or what but there were so many raw jalapenos in my burrito that I could hardly eat it. I was in so much pain I do not look forward to tomorrow.
author: Manny F.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE! Definitely my favorite burrito in the city. I have tried the carne asada, chicken, carnitas, and lengua and they are all really good... but their true brilliance, is Al Pastor. It is by far the best Al Pastor I have had. I suggest either the super burrito or the super quesadilla with a Mexican coke.
author: Alex S.

description:
Post-workout protein bliss. 

I've been here twice within two weeks. I love the chips with guac and salsa they give for each order.

I always get the chicken burrito. It's cheap, and it's filling. 

I'll be back.
author: Chris E.

description: Doesn't look like much from the outside but if you're a vegetarian who enjoys mexican food you have to try their burritos! $5 for a huge burrito that would be 2 meals for the average person.  My go-to place when im in the Mission!
author: D S.

description:
Finally tried this place after years of hearing about it. Wasn't disappointed.

$6 burritos is ALWAYS a good thing, especially when it's good. We got the super burrito with carnitas. The meat was smoky and the entire thing was flavorful and VERY FILLING. I was satisfied, but had to drink about 10 cups of water after dinner because I was so thirsty.

Food is definitely good, but I don't feel like I ate something really healthy afterwards. I prefer El Metate, but will come back to Taqueria Cancun to try their mojado (recommended by my foodie friend).
author: Angela H.

description: Wow. The tortas at Taqueria Cancún are, hands down, the best that I've ever tasted. I thought 6 bucks was a little pricey, but after the first bite I realized that I actually had gotten a bargain. That's a torta I'd be willing to go out of my way for.
author: Estevan D.

description: Tried three soft tacos made with corn tortillas, the veggie, the tongue and the pork; they were just ok.  May stop in and sample other entrees another time.  I wasn't impressed with the flavors, the beans or the cheese.  I liked the ambience inside, and the music was a plus.
author: Chris H.

description: Grilled chicken al pastor burrito is the bomb. Juicy and delicious. Chips that come with it are addictive and salsa is spicy - all for $6.50
author: Nora X.

description: Seriously yummy, but had some major language issues. They do not have guacamole, but they will put a ton of avocado on your tacos if you ask and have an avocado salsa.
author: Sarah F.

description: Authentic little joint hidden in the mission district with amazing food. Great prices - $2.65 for taco's let's you try every flavor!
author: Cathy C.

description:
That's a big frickin' burrito,  and tasty too. 

I liked it, but I have to admit I fit in way better with the dickheads that frequent Farolito. 

Everyone eating at Cancun was really nice and way better looking.
author: Jason R.

description: Had the beef lengua taco, wasn't all that impressed. Had to add a bunch of hot sauce to finish my one taco...
author: Nathan W.

description:
why the fuck aren't you open right now?!? 

i'm drunk and i'm pretty sure i'm literally going to die if i don't get a quesadilla.

this is the worst things that has ever happened to me.
author: Kelly Kate W.

description:
We came here after Dolores Park yesterday after I inisisted I try a taqueria I'd never been to before. Or, at least one I couldn't yet count. Turns out Taqueria Cancun was my FIRST taqueria in SF, but since I came here while visiting, I didn't have any comparisons at that point, and it was long ago in July 2006.

I ordered the carne asada super taco, and let me tell you, this may be my new favorite taqueria! I still love Papalote for its ambiance (& food), but I may love this taco a little more. Fresh, excellent carne asada meat, ample avocado slices draped on top, and delicious ingredients made for one heck of a taco! And I do like the salsa here best!

I highly recommend.
author: Sally M.

description: Nice staff, Nachos, beer, burritos, close to Dolores Park...what more do you need?
author: J F.

description: 5$ for a burrito bigger than your face, with lovely nachos and a pot of fresh and spicy salsa is a great deal! The guys behind the counter are friendly and funny. :)
author: sunita s.

description: Best authentic mexican food ever!! The burritos are amazing and super big. We go here whenever we are in the city. Never had a bad experience.
author: Pilar K.

description:
Thanks to my friend, JLab, I have found my guilty pleasure for soft tacos.

There are times when a busy gal/wifey just doesn't want to cook. (You know who you are!) And you just feel like some good Mexican tacos or burritos that will fill your tum-tum with goodness and leave you feeling comatose the rest of the day/night.

My fave thing to get here is their Super Taco.  And the meat of choice is Al Pastor (Marinated Pork). At $3.00 each, the price is right.

Super Taco = Super Good
author: Keika L.

description:
A friend took us to this restaurant yesterday. I would not have found this restaurant or even thought of trying it if it I didn't have someone to show me. But Im glad we ate here.

The location is kind of like a hole in the wall. The interior has got a cheesy selection of colors and the seating is a bit cramped but an efficient use of space.  They use benches to maximize seating capacity. The whole atmosphere is kind of cheap, but you are here for the food.

I had the burrito mojado, which packed a punch with all sorts of spicyness. If you can't take spicy, you probably shouldn't try this dish.  But man it was a a delicious burrito. Its also huge and heavy with sauces, so I didn't even try using my hands. I went straight to knife and fork.
I have a thing for avocados and I wish there was some in the burrito mojado. They put them in the super burrito, why not this one too?? Oh wells. It was a tasty experience.
author: Nathan K.

description:
If a restaurant is located in an area with a particularly high theft/crime rate, I prefer to be (somewhat) sober and (ideally) surrounded by tons of wasted people.

The way I see it, in this part of the Mission district, all I have to do is be able to escape predators faster than ONE other girl on the street.  Fortunately, during the weekends this place has an abundance of drunk girls teetering past me in uncomfortable footwear.  Sure, your heels might be uber-fashionable, but when some guy's chasing you with a knife and trying to steal your Kate Spade handbag, I bet my Steve Madden flats will be looking pretty good as they race away to safety in front of you.

Fortunately, I was with somebody who could protect me from purse-snatchers and cat-callers.  

We each ordered two tacos (one chicken and one chorizo) and they were the perfect late-night snack.  

Come here to order some authentic Mexican chow and get some feast on drunken eye candy for dessert.
author: Janney B.

description:
I became a Taco dude, NO More Burrito dude.
Except Breakfast Burrito. I still love Breakfast Burrito.

There was a website calls Burrito eater and the man says on the site out loud, " I don't do taco."
I was wondering why.
i was kind of disappointed to know that Burrito is American thing like JiveAssRoll.
I am not American things hater at all and I don't hate all JiveAssRolls but many of them, really sick to my stomach.
i love Japanese food but that doesn't mean I like all Japanese people.
I have met plenty JAJAH, JackAssJapaneseAssHoles.

So,....
Taco is better than Burrito for me lately.
I think because ....
I hate the smell of LEFT OVER BURRITO so much.
So why bother eating the shit.
That is something I CAN'T do.
Eat left over burrito is like... eating your own vomit.
I can't take the smell.
There was a person who was eating some one's left over in my office refrigerator and it was a half eaten burrito.
FXXX! She must be a FXXXin' pig eating someone else's left over burrito.
Yes, I know who did eat the shit and she is still here.

There is a BIG difference between Left Over Burrito and Natto.
Left Over Burrito smells like VOMIT.
Natto smells like SHIT.
Which one would you prefer? Smell like Vomit or smell like Shit?

I am a BIG Natto Eater so..... but that doesn't make me a SHITEATER for crying out loud. does it? 

The smell of left over burrito in my refrigerator turns me off badly.
But Taco is nice and small, there is no left over!

About the place.
Cheap, Good Tostada Ceviche for 2.50!
Super grilled chicken was 3 bucks!
Vege Burrito was 5 bucks.
Really-Great service. Nice manner to a drunk ass Japo dude like me.

I liked the place.
Taco Dude Here!
And I was drunk!
author: Nobu K.

description:
hmm.  I'm torn on this one.  Cancun is definitely one of my favorites, and I have been to this spot at least 50 times.

I ALWAYS get the super burrito with grilled chicken or the super vegetable burrito.  So, forgive the lack of variety in my review.

One thing I love about this place...they use straight avocado instead of guacamole, which is a must.  The meat is also generally pretty good, and the burritos are always well-mixed.

Most of the time the burritos are good, but not kicked-in-the-balls good.  But a few times, just a few unbelievably memorable times, I have had the holy grail of burritos here.  Satisfying, hot, crispy/flaky on the outside, soft and tender on the inside.  Cheese perfectly melted and complementing the beans and meat.  Salsa mild and subtle, but pairing perfectly.  I'm shuddering with pleasure just thinking of those times.

If only my girlfriend could please me like that.
author: Jay W.

description:
I experienced the unfathomable: Sober Euge.  Sober Euge is quite philosophical and serious.  I hope I see him around more.

After hoodwinking EuJen (sorry, I won't ever call you that again) into going to another event  where the drinks were flowing freely and deliciously, Jen needed a taco, or a bacon hotdog, no, taco so we ran across the street to Cancun.

Mimi and I sat across from Jen, Wakako and Euge, in that order, and it was like watching the most hilariously awesome show on TV.  We got there right before the after last call rush so we ordered and had our food quickly.  I had some chicken nachos that had fresh avocado.  The chicken was flavorful and kind of crispy so it tasted like pork.  Jen got her taco (I think) and Sober Euge had a quesadilla.  He does eat, ladies and gentlemen.  

I don't know how any of that food would taste if it weren't after 2 with 10 different alcohols coursing through my body but at that moment, everything was good.

Sober Euge thinks I look like I've had a nose job (because I'm Korean) and that my dimple is a further modifcation of my face.  Um, if this were true, why would I only get one?  Wouldn't it make more sense for me to get 2 and keep my face symmetrical?
author: Seong P.

description:
I have been eating here for years.

The burritos are huge, reasonably priced, and delicious. Two people with smaller appetites can easily share one.

I also recommend the Watermelon Agua Fresca.

Their salsa can be hot for some, so if you're not used to it, ask for it on the side.

This place is always playing crazy, fast paced, music really loudly, which detracts from the eating experience.
author: Sam W.

description:
I'm one of those white girls who thinks she can take the heat of spicy food. 

"Oh no, no, no, I don't want mild. Look at me. Do I look like a mild woman? Well I'm not! So step up fool! Give mama the real shit! I like it HOT."

As I eat the spicy food in question I smile through the pain, cracking my chapped, red lips as I proclaim my undying love of spicy food and frantically fan my mouth with my hand.

Ten minutes later I'm crying, snot is running down my lips, sweat has soaked through my clothes, my eyes are stinging from accidentally rubbing them with my chili-juice covered fingers, and my tongue is laying in my water glass like a dead pigeon.

My taste buds obviously haven't learned anything, because I continue to go back to spicy and beg for more. I'm a masochist. I'm a glutton for punishment. I'm the white gringa who all the food staff at Mexican, Thai and Indian joints laugh manically at when I order things spicy.

"Oh, this little hood rat wants her food spicy. Oh, I'll give her SPICY! I'll make her cry! I'll make her beg for mercy, I'll make her wish she were dead."

"Dude, you're scaring me, let's just make her sweat through her clothes so it makes it look like she's lactating."

"Ok, fine, we'll do it your way."

I'm pretty sure this was the conversation going on between the burrito guys at Taqueria Cancun on Saturday morning.

Why would they do this to me you ask?

Because I'm the jerk who asked for something that wasn't on the menu. Ya, I'm THAT guy.

I ordered a breakfast burrito, because it wasn't quite noon yet, and I felt a little iffy about having to admit I actually ate a burrito when most people are still in their jammies eating pop tarts and bacon.

The guy did a little eye roll when I asked for it without chorizo and I knew I was done for. Oh man! I'm making the guy scramble an egg instead of just scooping some shit onto a tortilla! 

"This guy totally wants to smash my head in the carrot juicer, doesn't he?"

"Ya he does!" Says boyfriend as he expertly ordered his carnitas burrito in Spanish, giving me the "they're-not-gonna-spit-in-my-food" eyes.

Ok, so they might have hated me, or I might be completely over exaggerating cause, well, that's my thing, I do that, but the burrito was still great. A little on the insanely spicy side, but who am I to complain? I ordered something off the menu! I deserve to lose feeling in my tongue. 

Boyfriend's burrito was exceptionally spicy too, so I think that all their burritos must be a little painfully delicious. And by painfully delicious, I mean they're a-fucking-mazing tasting but make my insides twist angrily after each bite of salsa-drenched burrito innards. 

+1 star for having party decorations year round. Who needs to take that shit down when we can nauseate ourselves with eyefuls of colorful of streamers? It's just like myspace!
author: Sammy S.

description: Long overdue! I first wandered in this fine establishment sometime in the late 90's. It's by far the most consistent taqueria I've been to in the city. Any of the burritos with extra avocado and your good day is complete! If you're looking for ambiance, beat it! If you like your salsa with some actual spice in it, you're golden!
author: R. C.

description: DELICIOUS!!!! The prawn burrito was filled with shrimp! and their salsa was fresh and flavorful. And I wasn't even drunk
author: Johnny C.

description:
taqueria cancun happens to be my local place (less than a block away).  I've always found the dudes that work here to be friendly, and you can usually find a seat.  The lines can be long, but the food is worth it.  I usually roll with the carne asada burrito, but the burrito mojado is their specialty, and you can tell why.  It's a very good place but there are better options.

Forgive me Taqueria Cancun for not giving you 5 stars.
author: Thomas K.

description: As good as it gets says it all.  The place for Mexican food in the Mission.  Take your pick - it's all good.  Fast - affordable - my husband is looking over my shoulder and he just said, "That place effin rocks".  Nuff said.
author: Marie M.

description:
This place is packed at night! Especially on the weekends. We came here after being at Bruno's really early and there was nothing going on so we decided to grab some food to munch on while the rest of our friends come. 

There were lot's of drunk people inside and out and a mariachi band outside too.

The menu has the basic Mexican joint items...burritos, quesadillas, tortas, nachos, Cow tongue? 

Us three girls decided to just get a super nacho with carne asada and split that since we had ourselves some San Tung for dinner like 2 hrs before here.

Nachos were $5.99 with $2 more for meat. It was good but definitely not the best nachos. Need way more chips and I think we counted that there were like 6 dices of tomatoes in there but plenty of meat. This one dude came and sat with us and he had a burrito which maybe I should of got one of those since it looked way better then our nachos.

We also got serenaded by the mariachi band with "La Cucaracha" .
author: Juliane N.

description:
Soy un ventilador de su Carne Asada Burrito Grande. Es sabroso. Es picante. Es tan grande en la boca. 

Más probable de regresar cuando vivo cerca. 

Liberte las pastillas, salsa, y el guacamol al cenar en. 

In English translation:

I'm a fan of their Carne Asada Big Burrito. It's tasty. It's spicy. It's so big in my mouth.

More likely to come back when I live nearby.

Free chips, salsa, and guacamole when dining in.
author: Stanley K.

description: There is no better place to go for a burrito in the Mission. Update 3/3/05: Dropped by last weekend and tried the ceviche, it was pretty nasty. Stick with the burritos!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
It kind of looks like a pinata threw up inside - all festive and shit, with streamers in every color adorning any feasible surface.  

I brought my parents here and my dad was like "I need to be facing the window so I can see EVERYTHING that's going on."  I think he was a little scared of the Mission.  All those tight jeans and Mexican families were a bit too much I guess?  And then Mexican families with tight jeans?  Heart attack central.  I don't know what i'm writing.

Anyways, the burritos here are pretty good.  Usually big enough to cut in half and share.  And totally reasonably priced.

Not the best burrito I've had in the city, but certainly very good.  For the best burrito check out "El Castillo" in the 'Loin.  They've mastered the art of making an awesome burrito and can scoop an avocado with some serious fierceness.  I hope to master that skill one day.  Also on the list of things to master:

1.  Archery
2.  Balancing a checkbook
3.  Basic English grammar
4.  My life

This review is useless.  DON'T CLICK THE USEFUL BUTTON.
author: Evan L.

description:
Seriously delicious tortas.  My favorite in the city.  Sometimes we go all the way from our digs in the Castro just to grab a carne asada torta, a quesadilla suiza and an horchata.  In our jammies (no one cares).  Good late night grubbin.

DON'T FORGET THE GRILLED ONIONS.  They give you like 12 of em.  Stick em in your torta.  Tada!
author: Diana Y.

description: bueno preparation of una grilled flour tortilla....uno red salsa y uno spicy green sauce pero muy spicy....chips por every order....!chip y sauce es free!..!hola, amigo!...me llamo enrique..yo necesito un burrito carne asada..andale, por favor... counter order y call of numero por pick-up...!cuarenta y cuatro!...take burrito to su table....unwrap foil y reveal muy guapo burrito....bueno size y weight engineering....bite y notice fillers...no bean order...results en extra rice filling...es malo....!aye caramba!....dry salty carne asada unevenly distributed.....never know what you're gonna get....verdict por $cinco burrito?....es decent y filling....
author: Hen A.

description:
The Negra Modelo I'd been drinking all evening needed some company, so I stopped here with a friend last night.  A quesadilla sounded like the most awesome thing on the planet.  Probably because it is!

The pechuga suiza (quesadilla with grilled chicken) caught my eye, and I knew that's what I needed to get me through the night.  Well, that and some Mexican Coke.  The cashier was very friendly and totally made me forget we were waiting a good ten mintues to place our order.  

I had hoped it would be bigger--I've definitely had bigger in my travels--but the pechuga suiza was damn good nonetheless.  The Mexican Coke was perfect to wash it down with, and I also helped my friend finish her horchata.  It wasn't as smooth as the horchata at La Borinquena in Old Oakland, but at 12:15am "any port in a storm" becomes an all-encompassing philosophy.
author: Eric E.

description: I'm of the opinion that there are only bad burritos and good burritos. There are lots of good burritos in this city and Taqueria Cancun is one of them. It doesn't really stand out above the others, but it definitely doesn't pale in comparison either. I've had the al pastor as well as the cabeza and both were very tasty. All in all, a good place to eat.
author: Jeremy J.

description:
My favorite SF taqueria, two and a half years running. I resisted Cancun based mostly on the fact that the totriila falls apart on their burritos while you're eating them, making the whole endeavor high-maintenance (some might rightly call ME high-maintenance for this).

But of the 761 factors that go into rating taquerias, location (I live a block away) and taste converged in 2006, and I've been drawn like a magnet ever since.

Simply the best forest despite only slightly above-average trees. And by that (for those lost to analogy), I mean that no single ingredient is incredible knock-your-socks-off, but they all come together to create the most enjoyable taqueria experience.

I tend to go for super grilled-chicken tacos, super grilled-chicken burritos, or super vegetarian burritos. Per the paragraph above, I think it's Cancun's salsa that really seals the deal. It's spicy, so hold onto your hat, but it enhances all the other flavors in whatever you're eating.

Also noteworthy is the huevos-and-chorizo breakfast. For those who eat lightly in the a.m., one order will easily feed two people.

Lastly, Cancun is still cheap. And by cheap, I mean affordable, not chintzy.

Post-lastly: My cohort and I LOVE the fact that sometimes there's a hyphen between "Can" and "cun," and have affectionately begun to refer to the place as "Can-hyphen-cun."
author: Jeff H.

description:
With 417 reviews already under its belt, this Taqueria doesn't seem to need one more, yet I cannot resist adding my 5 star vote as the best in SF.  I was not really familiar with the whole taqueria scene before arriving in SF and this was my first introduction to the genre.  How lucky for me.  I have since visited several others, many of which were good to great, but none had the hits on all levels as Cancun.  I believe it is the essential goodness of each individual ingredient that makes these burritos and tacos extraordinary.  The rice is wonderful, same with the beans, the tortillas, and all of the meats, of which the best is the carne asada.   This is a perfect place to take novices, if you want them to set their standards high thereafter.  

This patch of Mission is undoubtedly a bit spicy as well, making me want to advise caution and basic street smarts.  The interior is no frills but fun -- most patrons do take-out.
author: Joanie F.

description:
I'm shocked and disappointed... in myself for having never reviewed Cancun, since I've been happily gorging myself there for over 3 years.  

Great and inexplicably inexpensive burritos, a super-burrito that is bigger than your head, and actual avocado, rather than questionable guac make Cancun one of my top 3 burrito joints in the city.  Chips and fresh salsa with every order ease the pain of waiting, but really, they make that food so fast that I never finish, but then I have extras to scoop out the overflowing burrito filling.  The staff is always curt but nice and efficient.  It's a little dingy on the inside, but not dirty, and the occasional mariachi has livened up many of my visits.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Hype. But when you are starving after a night of drinking with friends and nothing else is open, this, I guess, is the place to go. 
The workers are super workers. I can't imagine been that fast in a kitchen.
The Chicken Burrito I had was great! Or I was so hungry I didn't noticed.
The mess of people coming in? Was there anyone there that was not drunk or high? Oh, yes, and he was returning his order because it was wrong...
I don't think I will go back on a Sat night after midnight.
The price is right, though....
author: Cristina R.

description:
Great, Mission-style Mexican "joint". If you're a Chipotle lover, this place will be your heaven.

For your first time, get the ginormous burrito, even if you don't plan on finishing it. It's an experience!
author: Mickey R.

description:
Solid taqueria my amigos. Solid. Their quesadillas are nicely pressed with gooey cheese. When filled with avocados and [fill in meat], they transport you to a place where fat and carbs are good and excercise is unnecessary for an ab to wash your undies on.

I like my carnitas stewed and then fried a bit to get a nice, carmelized crust and that's how they do things here. Al pastor tacos are piquant and delicious with just a hint of sweetness to make the flavors more than one dimensional. Love their lengua, it's soft and pillowy. Same with their cabeza although it was a bit high on the fat content. Very beefy flavor though so you win there. Last but not least, they overstuff their tacos. There is a LOT of meat in there. Take that for what it's worth.

I think they can improve on their salsas and their chips. It's relatively minor to the taqueria experience but every detail counts in a competitive market. I like that their salsas have a nice bite to them though. 

Prices are bit higher than most taquerias in the area but they're dependable so it's a worthy sacrifice. 

Recommendations: Al pastor, carnitas, lengua, orange-carrot juice.

Conclusion: You can hold your head up high telling people that you ate here. Hang your head in shame next time you're at Taco Bell.
author: Daniel K.

description: Small rival gangs have formed in SF based on your Taqueria colors.  I'm throwin Cancun signs.
author: Bernard W.

description:
Let me preface this by saying this is the worse 4 star review you'll ever read.

I was about 3/4's done with my taco when I saw a little white mouse walk out of the kitchen and head towards the exit.  I guess he was done eating too.  Shortly after that, one of the shiftier looking patrons approached our table.  She didn't say a word just began hovering over us and eating our chips.   Before we could say anything, she grabbed as many chips and she could with one hand and our Tapatio bottle with the other and walked out.

If these are the types of things that would ruin your meal, you might not want to eat at Cancun.  But if you can handle it, the tacos, nachos, and burritos are delicious!
author: eric f.

description:
Dudes,
its a burrito shop
in the mission
surrounded by what looks like someone threw up decorations.  flags. pinatas. "best of the bay" framed posters.
to top it off, they have a mariachi.
i had a veggie burrito.  beans rice cheese sour cream avocado....and of course no cilantro.  cilantro can die.
but its a burrito shop in the mission.
yah. its good.
isn't it supposed to be?
author: Lauren F.

description:
Upon entering this place, I was a bit tipsy from all the drinking, so all the colors and decorations hurt my eyes a little... But the smell of meat cooking on the grill just made everything a little better... 

I left the ordering up to Wakako... Al pastor burrito.... Oh my gawd... This thing was good... Really, really good... Stuffed to the max with delicious ingredients... I didn't want to let a single piece fall out, so it remained in my left hand, never letting putting it down and I held a fork in my right hand to quickly scoop up the pieces that looked like they were about to jump ship... 

They sell beer too... Lots of beer...
author: Jen D.

description: Just stopped for a snack while in the neighborhood checking out Murals.  Nice colorful, lots of lights, liked the atmosphere.........looked like a fun place to stop. Had a beer and chicken taco.  The salsa's and chips were great.
author: Jeanne F.

description:
Taqueria Cancun is one of my favorite late night spots in San Francisco. It is in the Mission (many of the best restaurants are!) and very convenient to nightlife haunts. 

The food is cheap for SF standards and absolutely delicious. Especially when you are drunk (which I admit is the only way I have ever gone... I am not even sure if it is open before midnight...?) and in need of greasy-good carbs. My favorite is the super quesadilla or nachos. The only thing that leaves something to be desired is the guac. It is basically just water with some avacado - but hey! What do you expect.

It can get crowded but the line moves quickly. Make sure you tip the hardworking staff who are giving up their weekend late nights to serve a drunk crowd.
author: Emmy L.

description:
Don't really get the hype about this place, but it's a far better alternative to El Farolito, or as I like to call it, "El Chodolito" (tm Jeff A.). The veggie burrito is alright, but just not nearly as tasty as some other places. I also wish they had more of the sauce-y salsas. I'm not as much a fan of just pico de gallo.

Pretty decent overall, and tends to be consistent. Be careful, the salsa iS HOT!
author: Jill M.

description: grabbed a burrito here at the tail end of a short weekend trip upon the recommendation of several people (on and off yelp) because we couldn't go back to NYC without first sampling at least one san franciscan burrito.  imagine the shame!  can't exactly say this was the best burrito i've ever had (a little too heavy handed with the rice and beans for my taste), but i liked the guys behind the counter and the fact that they seemed happy to be feeding you.  genuine smiles and impromptu mexican serenades that you can't help but love!
author: Tina E.

description: Got food poisoning from the shrimp burrito. I exploded from both ends from 3 am to 12 pm after eating here late night at around 11 yesterday. I used to be a huge fan but after this horrible ordeal I'm not ever going back.
author: Alicia P.

description:
My first experience with Taqueria Cancun back in 2003 was, from what I remember, pretty amazing. 1) I was jumping for joy when I found out that they put chorizo in burritos 2) I ran into someone (who I didn't know lived in SF) that I hadn't seen for a long time and he literally just rolled outta bed to get a burrito. The food was great and I just thought, YEAH. This is the spot.

Since then, I've gone back, multiple times...with various other people who also raves about Cancun. Unfortunately, the later visits only proved that this place is really kind of shitty.

1) Their mild salsa is painfully spicy. It's just hot, and that's it.
2) When you attempt to ask them for guacamole, they don't tell you that they don't have it. Instead, they hand you a cup of green shit that you think might be guac, but it really is #1 x1000billion in spiciness.
3) Their chips are stale as shit.
4) The place is filled with folks that look like they're all extras from Scooby Doo.
5) Their bathroom is pretty much exploding diarrhea. 
6) You need to pull about 2 feet to chew off a piece of beef on their quesadilla suiza. 
7) Chorizo is also spicy as hell.

I'm sorry, I just can't handle it anymore. The next time another out of towner drags me to this place, I'll have to run.

I know a taco truck down in South City that serves plain assed burritos many times better than this. Hell, I'd even rather go to Gordos. 

It's 1 star because, it's over, Cancun!
author: Faffy L.

description:
A line out the door at Farolito. . .incredible.  

Went to Cancun instead.  Fine, yes, the burritos are good but this place is a dump.  Disgusting.  I was in there slightly drunk too and still noticed how totally gross this place is.  Matter of fact, the repulsiveness of this place killed my buzz, I left totally sober!  Had to use the bathroom, mistake.  DO NOT USE THE BATHROOMS AT CANCUN!

I live in Lower Haight and I lived in the Mission for years.  I know what dirty is, I'm used to a little grime but this was over the top nasty.  I haven't even used the word "nasty" to describe something since maybe, 7th grade!  Cancun was nasty!  

Yuck yuck yuck.  Maybe I'm just too old for this scene anymore. . .no!  I love getting sauced up and noshing on burritos but honestly, this place needs a serious bleach down.  Gross.  One more time. . .gross. . .blech!
author: James M.

description:
This burrito was sadly underwhelming. I had tears. tears yo.
I ordered the chicken super burrito. The tortilla was sufficiently crispy and the cheese was almost melted completely. The beans were refried and they tasted bland and did not blend well.
 The main problem was the burrito was not tightly rolled. I had it in the foil and it still tried to get away from me. Two bites in I gave up and ate it with a fork, working around the beany parts.
The ingredients did not come together well for me, which was partly the beans fault. I will probably come back with some veggie friends for a famous vegetarian burrito but for now I will stick with El Castillo. They never fail in making the best burrito I have ever consumed. The ingredients there always meld nicely. But more on that at another time.
author: Mango D.

description: My opinion of Cancun has changed lately. I used to think it was one of those places that got good reviews due to its proximity to a bar (All burrito places by bars get 5 star reviews from drunks). Last few months Cancun has saved me from terrible hunger, especially when shying away from their burritos. Mmm salty goodness.
author: Zac H.

description:
There was a LONG BLACK HAIR in my little to go cup of GREEN SALSA!
Oh hells nah.
I can understand if it was in my burrito or something, but the cups of salsa are TINY.  No one noticed the long ass curly black hair floating around in that shit???
Foul for sure.
Disturbing but true:  I miiiiight still come here when I'm too lazy/shitfaced to walk to El Farolito.
author: Meh M.

description:
My favorite of the 3 Cancun's in SF  ( also one on Market and 6th as well as another on 29th and Mission ).

Fresh ingredients, huge portions, free chips and salsa, more space than lots of other taquerias, good prices and variety with continuous music usually playing from the juke box.

Order it spicy and get it SPICY  ...  YUM!!!
author: Mike J.

description:
Lived 23 years in The City and this is hands down the best burrito in town. Super carne asada with everything. The free chips and salsa(s) they give you are an added treat. You can't beat the price and speed of service. The only negative, and this is nit picky, is the size of their water cups. 

Can Cun rules forever!
author: Darius T.

description:
i dont really perfer Taqueria Cancun. but this a good alternative for a late night munchies especially after the clubs

dont ever order their quesadilla, its sooo OILY!

i rather eat at La Corneta on 24th st and Mission.
author: Carol Y.

description:
I'm a native Texan, and yet I never considered myself a burrito fan. In fact, I'm pretty adamant about hating Tex-Mex food. But that doesn't mean I'm racist, y'all. However, I actually had a might fine burrito here. I got the Al Pasto. It was juicy, it was tender, it completely fell apart and I looked like a total amateur trying to scoop it up with my fork. Don't waste your time on the pre-chips'n'salsa. You will need your brute strength for the Big Daddy Burrito. 

I like that there aren't a lot of options. I respect the fact that they don't take credit cards (gives them street cred.)  And I like the urine yellow walls and papel picado decor. And I was totally not drunk/hungover and it tasted great. Viva Burritos! (Still not eating them in Texas though.)
author: Lindsey K.

description:
We had the super burrito with carne asada and a taco salad with carne asada as well.  I honestly cannot say that there is anything special about the food here.  I'm wondering if others are enamored with this hole-in-the-wall more for the price and portion size.

The carne asada was cooked well and was moist but it was not fragrant or tasty.  The burrito's only pro were fresh slices of avocado. But the cons included the aforementioned tasteless carne asada and also how the scant amounts of avocado, meat and sour cream were drowned in excessive, heaping piles of rice and beans.  Not well balanced.  The taco salad was nearly unmemorable and if we did not perk it up with the free house salsa it would have been.  The taco salad bowl itself was stale.

If you are planning to eat there then just be aware that there are mostly picnic style tables and unless you have 4 or more people in your party you will likely be sharing a table with a buzzed, but friendly, stranger.  The jukebox sitting there is also kind of random, but I'm sure it is a lot fun for the post-bar crowd.
author: Rick T.

description:
My favorite vegetarian burrito in the Mission, not just because the avocado and sour cream are included in the basic cheap version. Staff is the fastest, so you won't have to wait long. Donwsides: Someone may come by your table panhandling, and don't ever go in the bathroom.
Update: I feel compelled to report that they got a perfect 100 score on their health department report card. I've been to much more expensive places that can't seem to manage that.
author: Amy E.

description: Love this place. Only issue is tight spaces in the building.
author: Matt B.

description: Get thee a grilled burrito!
author: Miriam W.

description: I've lived in the mission for quite a long time until recently... when I moved to the sunset, but all I can say is : i miss this place. I used to come here all the time , at least a few times during the week because it was walking distance from my house. Usually long lines but its worth my wait. The super shrimp burrito is so EFFING GOOD. I also recommend the super taco's with everything on it, with carne asada. They're open late, and they dont take card, so make sure you bring cash. The first bite is always the BEST. Most places have soggy burritos and such but not this place. And they have little packets of tapatio (great for on the go)!
author: Colette P.

description:
I love Taquería Cancun.
I'm not sure if it's the papel picado, the yellow walls, or that my burrito tastes just right every time, but this is and has always been my go-to taquería.
*Can't comment on the meat.
author: Emma A.

description:
Not as dry a burrito as El Farolito, and roughly Five Minutes more over-rated. Were this place not open late and roughly adjacent to bars that Whitey frequents, we'd not be talking about it.

I liked this place better when it was a heroin front.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
FRESH. Me, my hubby & cousin go here all the time. Like, at least twice a week for dinner, we get their veggie tacos. Ok, sometimes three times a week. And everytime, we realize when we get there that we don't have any cash, and have to make a run to the nearby convenient store to use their ATM.

Great Mexican food ... any time of the day, from day to late night. Salsas are so fresh and spicy ... fresh carrot juice too! Good usage of avocados ... mmm, now I'm craving a veggie taco.
author: Antara B.

description: i love cancun and i eat the whole burrito. it gives me a real good poop. and it's next door to the knockout. so perfect.
author: Kerry F.

description:
**** Updated: Can cun yall slipping, absolutely no consistency with the product at all. Demoted to 3 stars, and half of one of them stars is out of loyalty. I know yall can make a good burrito,. but how would any random person know that trying the product for the  first time and it not being good due to consistency issues. 
Cancun, you used to be my homie, used to be my ace, now i can't even recognize the taste...

**end update
_______________________________________
Cancun is probably my fav burrito, but that definitely comes with a price, get back to that in a sec.

I've been coming here for a while now and have had debates with friends over this place and Pancho Villa, when it comes down to it they both have their strengths and weaknesses. 
I've noticed that this Cancun in particular has had a kitchen lineup/ burrito maker change up where i hardly recognize any of these guys from like a year ago , so this means that the taste of the burrito has altered a bit because of things like amount and proper distribution of ingredients, but i think it is has become more consistent again- there is one older cook who is really tall, he knows what he is doing!!!

okay, so the location of this Cancun is pretty ..ah , not the most desired with all the outside activity that often spills in, not as bad as the Market St. one (by the way , dont go there unless you absolutely have to, it always smells like bleach in there, and you'll probably walk out after eating a burrito and see some crackwhore going down on a dog or some crazy shit like that to make you loose your appetite/ throw up) .
anyway, back to this one, if you have to use the bathroom, brace yourself for seeing some ill scheizza, if you can hold it, try to.

my friend said she once saw a roach in the kitchen, but im not tripping over that, neither am i over the occasional hair in the food or small piece of meat in my veggie burrito, when you come here you know its not a gourmet spot so you cant trip off those things, but i cant help but imagine how much better cancun would be if they had a security guard at the door like pancho villa does to monitor the randoms coming in ruining your experience.

so yeah, everything is good here, i highly recommend veggie burrito with a melon fresca (not diluted like all them other places, but is mad sugary!!! brush and floss after that fa sure!!!)- 

oh and chips are aight, but salsas are really good  so chip doesnt even really matter
author: James A.

description:
Whether you are drunk or sleepy, this place will surely bring you back to your senses. With their colorful festive flags and blasting (and extremely booming) jukebox, hot-as-hell salsa and guacamole there's no way you are going home not sober. 

First time I was here, I really didn't know what to order, but settled to some chicken torta which turned out to be awesomely good! It's bigger than my forearm and it's under 6 dollars. And the ingredients are real, no soy meat! 

The order comes with some tortilla chips with their house salsa and guacamole. Don't underestimate these babies in cups because if you gobbled down a chunk of their specialty dips, you could have wished that you ordered the large horchata. Well in my case, I ordered my second Mexican coke (which was surprisingly different than what we have).  

Parking is fine, since I usually go here late night, but if you are planning to go here early,  you can rely on good ol' Muni. Prices? Reasonable, since they are servings are huge. Ambiance? I can only give it two stars because of the ghetto area, the way too colorful interiors, and loud music (and I mean loud!), but who cares I'm here for the food! Wait time is okay, though they have a confusing numbering system. Service? Awesome, they will shout out your number in two languages (you don't have to press 1 for English) when your order is ready. Overall, I give it four stars!
author: Richelle Mae R.

description:
One of the best, open late, always happy.  Autentico enough que hay sesos (beef brain), but they do the nachos and burritos too.  Friendly generous and attentive staff (who sometimes sing spontaneously at night), mostly Latin crowd except for some other people dressed like complete FREAKS, like rhinestones and cowboy hats and spandex.   Plus a cab driver, and me.  Somehow, every avocado they serve is perfectly ripe.  Jukebox of mariachi music volume way up.  A place where you can dine alone and still have a good time.

Thet signature dish here is their tosdada de ceviche, chewy dark fish chopped small with onions and tomatoes, very acidic, with half an aguacate sliced on top.  it's been consistently delicious for the near decade I've been coming here.

In fact, the food is reliable, like coming home to an old lover.  Not high end even by taqueria standards, but well done, reliable, tasty.

Prices are way inexpensive, we're talking $3.80 regular burritos.  $6 cocktail de camarones and, though you can tell from the ingredients why it's so cheap, it's still a good value and enjoyable, served the right way with Tapatio sauce and fresh lime, avocados, onions, and saltine crackers.  A little heavy on the ketchup taste but aren't we all?

Festive decoration, looks a lot like Mexico -- fake brick arches (little tiles glued to wall), enough primary red and yellow thick latex paint to burn down a McDonald's from across the street in shame, cutout colored paper hanging from ceiling, sly mural on wall depicting natives gathered at oceanside to marvel at something in the sea, probably approaching Europeans, only there's notobody in the sea, just volcanoes on the peninsula.

I wouldn't go here on a first date, not even a first trip to the Mission.  But I would come back again and again when I need to feel better about life on a cold rainy night.
author: Gil S.

description:
Awww yeah, tacos are good.

Or burritos, as that's what I ended up having last night.

I was introduced to this local hole in the wall in the wee hours of last night and it didn't disappoint.  The burrito was massive and even with two of us eating it, we couldn't finish.  But it was so tasty and the price was right.  As others have commented, late at night it's a long wait, but well worth it.  

And no upset this stomach this morning...that must be a rarirty after eating Mexican food at 2:00 in the morning!!  I'll no doubt be going back at some drunken point in the future...
author: Melanie N.

description: I am definitely a fan. Came here really drunk after a party in the mission and fell in love. I ordered the vegetarian burrito and thought it was better than the vegetarian burrito at Chipotle. So fresh and authentic! The entire place is infested with drunk people and it's a party once you step inside. It's open late- thank god! I really, really, need to make a trip here again soon. I could really go for some right now.
author: Shannon G.

description:
David Rakoff once insisted that "...it's time to admit that the relentless questing for that next undetectable gradation of perfection has stopped being about the thing itself and crossed over into a realm of narcisism so overwhelming as to make the act of masturbation look selfless" 

You hear that, Cancun fanatics?
author: Marc M.

description:
Good lord, I swear to Jesus I've never believed in heaven but baby, this sways all my preconceptions. From this day on Taqueria Cancun is my favorite mexican taste joint.

There's no wonder they've been consistently rated from time to time since 1996 as the best taqueria in SF. As if that wouldn't look brilliant enough, they back up the title with their freshly made, starry presented, delicious, low-cost items.

I got a mojado (big) burrito for just $5.97 (with tax)! Is that a deal or WHAT!? Btw, they include complimentary chips. Here's a side note: AVOID the green and red cups... and tell them to skip the cilantro. If they don't understand, say "None of that green spicy stuff, please." This will work wonders unless you're a spicy-hoarding megalomaniac.

Cancuns's worst downfall is their abominably snail-speed service... which is understandable when crowds jam pack the small place so often, but even if there are just a few stragglers, they take 10 mins+. That's a vulgar no-no for me.

Now if only they'd extend these operations of theirs all the way to the east bay, they'd slam every other taqueria into the history books!
author: Carl Z.

description: I had a very good wet burrito made with nicely flavored enchilada sauce. Their chips have a nice crunch and they are served with a great avocado salsa. This is the kind of place that gives the mission it's reputation for great mexican food.
author: Andrew P.

description:
I've been to them all, and have the extra 20 or so pounds to prove it - but this is the king of the Mission taquerias for me.  It's not so much that it's all *perfect* but everything they do have is really good and in one place.  Yes, El Farolito is better drunk food and their tasty grease of doom is amazing, yes La Taqueria has that one taco that's better than anything else, but for consistency in being very good across the board we have Cancun.  

I take out-of-towners and friends there, but really I'm doing it so I can have a guilt-free excuse to get a carne asada super burrito or some chorizo tacos.  Two bonuses - it's next to El Rio, and during the day parking is quick and easy nearby.  Not so easy further into the mission.
author: Scott S.

description: The hype is true: this place kicks ass. On a many nights we have stumbled over to Cancun to get a burrito or nachos. One need not be intoxicated to appreciate its greatness. The burritos are very generous in size as are their nachos. The 14 and 49 MUNI will drop you off right in front and parking is bad but not impossible. Their horchata is awesome.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Pretty much my favorite burrito in the Mission, if not the city.

Wether its during the day or late at night, I love wandering over here for a grilled chicken burrito. Super cheap and filling! there's only so many places I like for Mexican and this place is at the top. It's awesome because the inside is fun and usually attracts other fellow post-bar late night munchers and not too many of the weirdos that linger in the mission.
author: Drew M.

description:
I had my first Torta here and I feel in LOVE.  If I'm ever near a Taqueria Cancun, I believe they have 3 sites in the city I will always stop.  I always get there tortas and if I go to another Mexican food place then I usually purchase the same item but Cancun does it right.  Especially after hitting the bars up this place will certainly sober you up.  

This place will not disappoint.
author: Ryan T.

description:
Time of Night:  12:45 AM
State we're in:  Quite intoxicated
Location we were at:  Portrero Hill
 
We're not hungry.  But you know that feeling that you've just GOTTA munch on something good, something you should not be eating at 1 AM if you actually truly did care about your waistline?
 
It was one of those nights. 
After a good time out, it was time to finish off the night with something yummy.  Head on over to the Mission.
 
We called in to the restaurant and verified that it was opened.
Asked them to prepare an order of Super Nachos with Carne Asada and "the works", we were on our way to pick it up.
 
Five minutes later, it was ready.
 
The plan was  to take it home and eat to our heart's content.
We devoured that stuff in the car like we'd starved for years.  (FYI, we'd had dinner some four hours ago.... huge dinner, actually, hahahaah....)
Messy.  Cheesy.  Spicy.  Juicy meat.  Tons of jalapenos.  Yummy salsa to go along with it all.  So much "stuff" that they needed to pack extra tortilla chips in a paper bag and even after all those ,we still had more "stuff" leftover.
 
Best damn nachos I've ever had.  HUGE serving.  Generous with every single ingredient.
 
I see many more 1 AM runs to Taqueria Cancun in my future....

NOTE:  I only had the nachos, so don't come after me if their burritos or tacos are no good, OK?  NACHOS.  BEST DAMN NACHOS.  Being a bit toasted prior to ordering them doesn't hurt either!!!!
author: Grace K.

description:
Meh.

Smack dab in the mecca of Mexican food, Taqueria Cancun is *alright.* I would put it in the very bottom of the top tier of taquerias in the 'hood. In terms of food, it's not bad, but nothing to write home about. I've eaten an al pastor burrito and a steak quesadilla... both underwhelming, but acceptable. 

What really turns me off about this spot though, is the atmosphere. The brick walls are a jarring bright yellow and the tables don't seem to get bussed often, which is kind of gross. The worst part, is that since this place is (in my opinion) a bit overrated, there is always a crazy line and you have to wait to order near the stinky bathrooms. Talk about unappetizing?

Sorry Taqueria Cancun, I want to like you. I'll most likely return since one of my friends is all about this place, so I'll update if it wins me over...
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Best for three reasons:

Best veggie burrito for the price, in that they actually make it with the right balance of ingredients, and that it's appropriately cheaper than it would be with meat.

They gently warm the tortilla in what I am pretty sure is continuously used lard.

It's open all the time. All the fucking time! And they also give you tasty fresh salsa with a decent amount of chips. Clean presentation.
author: Kai H.

description: Taqueria Cancun, it is so not fair that I should have to live so far away from you. Your burritos are heaven and if there was a way to keep them from getting soggy before reaching me, I'd have a dozen shipped to me weekly. Just thinking of them makes my mouth water...
author: Manda S.

description: Great burrito/taco spot.  They wrap the burritos really good so it doesn't get all messy when your eating it.  Tough to say whether or not it is better then chipotle, I might have to go back for further tastings.
author: James P.

description:
Pretty much the go-to taqueria of all SF taquerias after a night of drinking.  The place isn't designed to hold long lines.  It always ends up going into the bathroom pathway where you smell whatever spicy carne asada that came out of the dinner crowd.  And then it folds back into the dining area.  You cant be claustraphobic or germaphobic here.  Pretty much everyone is touching you and you are touching everyone else.  

Remember your first experience of wasabi?  Where someone told you it was the best guacamole paste ever and you took a large bite of it and your tongue started to burn off?  Well they do have a guacamole sauce here where it really is guacamole and it will still burn your tongue off.

Excellent super tacos here... get the lengua!  The enchilada dish is a pretty good deal.  You get 2 enchiladas, beans n rice, and some extra tortillas to make mini vegie tacos with the sides.  So I like to think I had like 2 enchiladas w/ 4 tacos all for $7.

I don't believe they have the "Wetback Burrito" found in their Market & 6th location.  That one is a must-try!  Their 3rd location is a lot less crowded and slightly cleaner with only 6 layers of sticky as opposed to this location's 8 layers.
author: Chris T.

description: Great burritos, tasty salsa, affordable prices , mariachi performers, and you can buy a watch or a pen from a homeless derelict wastoid while you dine.  Whats not to love?  Oh 1 thing, if you time it poorly your whole meal might  be eaten while they loudly chop meat.  I mean very loud, so if your looking for conversation go somewhere else.
author: Bryan M.

description:
Yes, there are many taquerias in the neighborhood, but it's hard to resist the Taqueria Cancun, which is painted a bright yellow, red, and green.

I got the small taco just because I wasn't too hungry ($2.50). It was very small and tasty! The server was awesome though and included nachos and salsa. The green salsa almost made me cry (spicy!)...The red salsa was very good though.
author: Laurie c.

description:
I heart Cancun!
god salsa. great food.
author: Kelle K.

description:
I love the Mission.

I came here with a friend and found a pretty limited but reasonably-priced menu.  Your basic burrito shop featuring: the basics.  A few tacos, some quesadillas, breakfast stuff.  Nothing fancy like tamales or chile rellenos.

But the food was pretty good - nothing to write home about, but I'd eat there again if I lived nearby.

My super burrito came with steak, rice, beans, sour cream, chips, salsa, and avo for about 5.50.  But I ordered fresh sqeezed (watered down) OJ which was $3.00.  I would skip that next time.

Over all, not bad.  Great colorful and festive interior.

Minus one for letting pan handlers heckle the customers.
author: Mari C.

description:
Eating vegetarian is sometimes just silly.  While I sat and munched on a veggie burrito, I had to watch my boyfriend swallow down a pulled and shredded chicken burrito that smelled like heaven.  Gawd, sometimes you just wanna do a little chicken cheer for how good that charred flesh tastes.  

Anyway, I would rate my veggie burrito at 3.5, and his chicken burrito at 4.5 . I am disspointed by the lack of fresh chips at this location and they don't have much in the way of salsa offerings...but their MEAT is really really good.  

Note to self...... why deny the carnivore inside?
author: Claire C.

description:
Pretty delicious burritos, and the salsa & guac are a bit spicy.  $3.50 for bottled Mexican beer is a bit more expensive than similar places in the area but would never ever stop me from getting a few Pacificos.  The guys working the line are furiously fast.

One note: there was some gang hanging just outside the door trying to start altercations, but they disappeared while we were inside.  

I was pretty surprised at what a mix of clientle there was as we approached the 10 o'clock hour... older chicks out on the town for a birthday, hipster douches, internet engineers, and hobos...

This is a good place.  Wish they had fish tacos.
author: Paul C.

description:
This place sucks.

The salsa sucks.  The rice sucks.  The chips suck.

Only vegetarians like this place because apparently they put a ton of veggies in the veggie burrito, but even if that did appeal to me (which it most definitely does not) then it wouldn't hide the fact that it's still a shitty burrito with funky-tasting rice and awful salsa.

I can't understand how this place wins so many "readers' choice" awards because it just flat out fucking sucks.
author: Doctor L.

description: Love their burrito mojado, They have a great burrito, so delicious and check out the flying fork, everybody knows whose :-)))))
author: Nebahat S.

description: Amazing. This was almost a perfect burrito. Great size and flavor. Good price. Comes with cilantro and onion on the super burrito, which i wish more taquerias included, and i also like that they use actual avocado inatead of a tub of guacamole. As a nice finished touch they slightly toast the outside of the tortilla giving the burrito a toasty-flaky property. Only drawback was that i didnt get my first bite with chicken until i was halfway through. Luckily, the chicken was bomb. Not bbq'd or saucy, but grilled and greasy, almost tasted like fried chicken. Next time i go back in going to order "sin arroz" and see if that evens out the proportions on this puppy.
author: Nicholas B.

description:
Some number of years ago, four friends and I tried ~10 different taquerias around the Mission, having a super burrito at each one over the course of about a month. Each of us independently picked Cancun as our favorite. They do a lovely job of grilling the outside and the salsa actually has a little kick, which really hits the spot.

I remain a loyal customer to this day, though I'm not in the neighborhood as often as I once was. Their ceviche tostada is also excellent.
author: Michael H.

description:
Not to say that I don't enjoy the smell of poop while I'm eating, but...

Oh wait. 

I DON'T.

Not too many homeless people inside and lots of places to sit, usually. Personally, I'm not sure whether that's good or bad. I mean, if there aren't a lot of bums...then why does it smell like doodie in there? Hmmm. And could all of the empty seats not be due to the fact that there are, in fact, ample seating options, but because it smells like an outhouse? IT MAKES YOU WONDER

If you can get past the overwhelming smell of old poo (because fresh poo doesn't usually reek as bad), this place is mighty okay. Their vegetarian burrito is so good and satisfying, that I'm nearly comatose after consuming it. I stumble down Mission Street, mumbling to myself and drooling. I fit right in, especially with the old poo scent of Taqueria Cancun clinging to me.
author: Pamela D.

description:
Wah Wah, it's too sketchy to walk here, boo hoo!  Hey, get over it.  Better yet, just walk down Valencia and feel safe and cozy floating down the little gentrified canal through the chaos of the Mission.  Then you only have to cut over one block and sneak around the scary Mission St. corner.  That's what I do!

Cancun is worth the sketch, in any case.  The wait can be awhile and seating can be...intimate...sometimes, but just grab a beer and make new friends!  A great, authentic taqueria.  Cheap eats, festive decor, tasty food, and the kicker: THEY. GRILL. YOUR. BURRITO!!  

Nom nom nom!
author: Kevin H.

description:
i love hole in the wall mexican joints. this place is freaking awesome and the crowd proves it. i got the shrimp burrito and every bite was amazing. full of flavor and i could taste every single layer. the burrito, plus chips and salsa plus mexican coke, all under $10. thats is freaking amazing.

the area is of course in the heart of mission so there are plenty of taquerias but this one is one of the best for sure. the place doesnt have too much seating so be ready to share.

also the locals are kind of rude and what i mean by that is while my friend and i were eating and enjoying each other's company. this lady who couldn't speak english came up to us asking for our glass bottles.. i had no idea what she talking about as she didnt even try to speak english and barely said a full sentence in spanish. she asks for my bottle and then gestures towards these other ones down the table left by previous patrons. instead of grabbing em herself.. she makes me get em. ok i understand times are rough and you're just trying to get by but have some manners for some crying out loud!
author: edward k.

description:
Large, filling burrittos--the carne asada is esp. tasty.  The chips are usually stale and the salsa is crazy-spicy but hey, chips and salsa are free, unlike some other places I could mention. (*cough* Orale *cough* Orale).  And they don't sit out all day while crackheads breathe over them (yeah, I'm talking about you, El Super Burrito). 

And the prices are right.  Where else can I get a meal that will get me through the entire day with a beer that comes under $8?  Where, I ask you?
author: MakeUp M.

description: My burrito here was pretty solid and yummy. One interesting fact: they put real avocado in it and not guacamole. I think I prefer guacamole, but the burrito was good nonetheless. The line was short, my burrito came up really quickly, there were plenty of places to sit, and they gave out free chips! My friends likes their burritos and quesadillas, and I didn't get a taco, but they looked delicious. Overall, a good experience, I'll totally be going back - it is one of the better small burrito joints in the mission.
author: Ashley H.

description: I dream of their burritos. I literally lay in bed at night and wish I was rolled up in a giant Taqueria Cancun super burrito that I could eat my way out of.
