And on top of that, my burrito recently had a bunch of burnt chicken (?) crust, it looked like bacon bits. It was the first time I saw it, and I found it strange never having seeing it before. Was there supposed to be chicken burnt crust in the burrito for flavor, or was this on accident? I plan on not going back any time soon because of it, so I guess I won't know.
author: S S.

description: Huge portion, great price! I was shocked at how big my quesadillas were! And freaking delicious!!
author: Dana S.

description: Best burritos hands down.  This is true Mission style that really satisfies!  There is almost always a line, and it's crowded and busy, but we were able to score a table to eat at!  The 2 burritos we got were al pastor and carnitas.  The way they wrap them and the tortillas are the best!  Slightly crispy on the outside!  Delicious!!!
author: Modern L.

description:
I'm a fan of some late night lovin'.

Possibly even more so when it refers to a Taqueria showing me some lovin by being open into the wee hours.

Definitely when said Taqueria cranks out some absolutely delicious food, when it could easily get away with cranking out sub-par food by virtue of being one of the few late night taquerias.  

Taqueria Cancun embraced me.  The Carnitas Super Quesadilla was absolutely delicious.  I told myself I wouldn't finish it, but 7 minutes later it was gone.  Add this to the fact that I was sitting here until about 2:25am nursing a Negra Modelo and no one kicked me out.  I felt loved.

Great food and that last beer before 2am.  Maybe I can ask Taqueria Cancun to be my valentine.
author: Steven R.

description:
I may in fact be executed for this review but...

I don't think Cancun is the best thing in the world. I will say though you get a lot of bang for your buck as their burritos are huge , almost like a hung mans "baby arm" big.I guess that counts for something
author: Lauren V.

description:
I completely agree with Pablo R's review (see below)

I went to Taqueria Cancun after my girlfriend raved about the nachos. However, I was duely disappoint and will never go back. 

reasons to not eat here (review for their nachos) -
#1 - the cashier who takes your order couldn't even understand waht you want. I didnt want guacamole and avacados on my nachos and with this simple request, he had to call another worker to translate. After all the discussion, I still found avacados on my nachos.

#2 chips weren't fresh. 

#3 carne asada (which cost #2 to add on) were dry and full of fat

#4 sketchy area of the Mission. It seems like even the workers at the restaurants were weary of some of the people who walked in.
author: Mindy C.

description: Good chorizo-and-eggs. Decent service. Easy seating. Reasonable prices.
author: Inigo M.

description: I think there's something to be said about a quesadilla that tastes better after an overnight stay in the fridge. The Al Pastor quesadilla was delightfully spicy, a kind of spice I've never had in any Al Pastor before. I'll definitely be back.
author: Maggie H.

description:
i used to totally love this place, but somehow we've grown apart. is it me? is it you? what happened to the relationship?

pros: (1) the ceviche. (2) the green sauce. (3) the carrot juice. (4) no migranes after eating there; some folks get migranes after eating at other latin/central/south american places, the guess is that it is due to use of lard or something, but dunno.

cons: (1) too many gringos. like, it is all gringos. including me. seems sad / lame. should eat some place that is frequented by people of that culture so you know the food is real? (2) the service. harried and thus brusque-to-rude. poor design of getting things out, for my order things didn't come out all at once, or even in the same place, so i had to keep asking where is it all, which only apparently pissed off the person i was asking. uh, not my fault you don't have your act together that way. (3) the burritos just aren't that special to me any more, really. not enough guacamole-or-avocado, or sour cream, that kind of stuff. (and i guess i have to be more proactive about saying i want frijoles negros.)

(man, i really miss the -- get this -- tofu burritos that they used to have at that place on 16th that was Maya. those were like the best things ever ever ever. so sad!)
author: Raoul D.

description:
Loud, dirty, and lots of people.

Why go?  Because the food is fresh and good.

Did I say loud... I ment very loud.
author: Amie C.

description:
After a night of drinking in the Mission, the burritos here complete my life.

There is so much grease in the food that you have virtually no chance of having a hangover if you drunk eat here.

Please note that I have never, ever eaten here even close to sober, so  kindly take the whole "complete my life" thing with a grain of salt.
author: Don H.

description:
Can-cun (as it is actually spelled on their sign, is a little hole in the wall with a lot of flavor at an even better price!  The kitschy plastic decor and sporadic Tejano or Banda music adds just the right amount of atmosphere.  You probably won't want to linger here forever but the food will keep you busy!  You can tell it is a more authentic Mexican joint by the big vats of agua fresca and horchata on the counter (traditional Mexican beverages (no alcohol).

Key to any experience here - NAPKINS!  The tacos are traditional "open-face" style on soft corn tortillas.  They are generously filled and piled high with all the fixin's.  If you think you can eat one with just 1 or 2 napkins think again but this is a good thing!

Enjoy!
author: Matthew T.

description: Quality Mexican food. Word. Bonus points for being open late. And I do mean late!
author: Ken L.

description:
I can't count how many times I've come here: drunk, sober, starving, etc. But every time I come here I ALWAYS get the same thing, that I love that they are very consistent with the quality of their food. 

(for all of those interested in what I get, it's a super burrito with steak) (sometimes I feel kinda fat because my husband just get the regular burrito, but then he eats 1/2 of mine because I can never finish it, so that makes me feel less fat) :) 

Just remember to bring CASH because they only take cash. They do have an ATM machine inside the place, but I hate all ATM machines, they are such a rip off. 

Also, do not pee here. I had to once and it was horrible. 

And after 12am until way after the clubs close the lines get ridiculous! The last time I went out and went to Cancun afterwards I was not in the mood to wait in line, so I just went to the cashier handed him some money and told him I didn't want to wait in line, probably saved 45 minutes of my life (now that I wrote that, I feel like I shouldn't have admitted that...) 

Anyways, go! You won't regret it.
author: Radha S.

description: As a doctor, I can't speak to the nutritional value of the food, but as an avid food-eater, I can say that I love their vegetarian burritos.
author: Andrew B.

description: Yet another place I dream about since moving from SF. Their veggie burrito is the best burrito I've ever had. I've tried all the other places in SF and none compared. Damn, now I want their burrito!
author: Tiffany P.

description:
One word: DAMNTHATSGOOD

ok ok...so i used more than one, chop my legs off and send em to the meatpackers why dont ya?  (whoa...where did that come from?) this place is soo good.  went here for lunch with my boss and man was it awesome.  didn't get the guac n' sour cream in my steak burrito though cuz it would've been messy.  i've gone back a few times since then and loved it everytime.  only thing is they play some noisy music but who cares?  the burritos are fantasticabulousisticulousousousous...lol.  if you can repeat that word twice fast i'll give you a burrito for free..scouts honor.  (puts two fingers in crossed position to those attempting to perform this ridiculouso tasko)

BOTTOM LINE:

i'm not a burrito guy..or rather, I wasn't a burrito guy at all..and now?  i love burritos...good ones that is.
author: Jack N.

description:
This place is the final stop of the Mission Bermuda Triangle composed of 3 of the 4 corners at 19th/Mission. First you go to Cha Cha Cha or Bissap Baobab for dinner and drinks. Depending on how Baobab-y you feel, you can then head over to Little Baobab to drink some Red Stripes and get your swerve on. The climax of the night is when you plow through the hipsters at Beauty Bar to dance and get a hideous nail job. 

And then, arguably the best part of the night is "sobering" up at Cancun with a quesadilla suiza and a Negra Modelo. Honestly, all the food here is good at 2 am, but the searing hot piece of meat surrounded by cheese and two pieces of crispy tortilla is heavenly. The super tacos and burritos are also good. But you should really give the ceviche a try. For around $3, you can get some pretty tasty marinated fish. Don't ask what the fish is, or how long it's been marinating in the bucket.

When you wake up the next morning with black nail polish on, a plantain in your coat pocket, and salsa verde all over your shirt, you'll remember "ah, that was a good night".
author: Lawrence L.

description:
A true five-star experience.  This is the finest burrito in the city.  A standard.

Why are you people complaining about Parking? Lack of parking is a PRO! It keeps the knucklheads away...
author: Nick A.

description:
I don't eat here anymore. But that's not because anything about Taqueria Can Cun has gone awry since my first burrito awakening in 1996; it seems more that my aging gut can no longer handle the utter richness of the food here. But look. They fry their tortillas on the grill that they also cook every bit of meat on and yet vegetarians flock to the place to get the vegetarian burrito knowing full well that it is tainted with cow or pig juice because the damned thing tastes like you've died and gone to a greasy, creamy, perfectly spiced bean filled heaven. With fresh avocado.

The green salsa that is so good it has gringos literally sobbing to eat as much as they can before they develop blisters on their tongues from whatever high-octane chilies drive the stuff--I can't eat it anymore either because my mouth has reverted to ordinary spice tolerance, and that alone makes me want to cry too.

Yes it has a neighborhood "ambience" that might put off the average visitor from suburbia, and you don't want to use their restroom, and you will have to share your table with someone dressed funny, but if you act like you don't care or notice, no one will hassle you. ok the guy asking for change will hassle you, but the crew behind the grill will throw him out if he gets too forward.
author: Erik S.

description: Whenever I have friends or family visit, I completely blow their mind with THE burrito.  I like the chorizo super burrito with no onions or cilantro and a bottle of Coke.  This is consistently my favorite meal in the city and I share it with those I love...because that's what you do.
author: Andy S.

description: Must order the veggie burrito! And even at 2 a.m. it's the best! What do I love about it? The big slices of fresh avocado and the rice is what makes the burrito so delicious. My mouth is watering right now... don't forget the horchata.
author: Lisa C.

description: I've had the super chicken several times, and their meat burritos aren't that good.  Cancun thrives off of positive feedback from their vegetarian patrons, and rightfully so, because their veggie burritos are some of the best.
author: Juan R.

description: Today for lunch i went here to get some food.  I was in the mood for a burrito so I got the burrito mojado.  There are a lot of different textures and tastes in that burrito.  I ordered it with the marinated pork.  The enchilada sauce was delicious too.  I think that made the burrito really good.  My buddy who had lunch with me said that the guacamole, sour cream, and salsa were placed on top of the burrito, much like the Mexican flag.  Pretty cool!
author: Brent T.

description:
Cheapest veggie burrito mojado in town!
My boyfriend and I can split one of these and be stuffed for hours.
Good salsa, too.
I like the employees - they are nice and they smile!
author: Melissa M.

description:
One can only hope that the vegetarian burritos they serve in "Heaven" are this good.  

Cancun's is quite probably my favorite in the city, if such a declaration is even legal.  We're luckier than we could possibly ever know.
author: Marie S.

description: This spot is indeed one of the famous gut bomb taquerias of the Mission district.  It is almost identical to a bunch of others scattered throughout the neighborhood and doesn't really do anything to separate from the pack.  The food is cheap, the ambiance abrasive, the free chips and salsa a nice perk, and the meat is most certainly suspect.  All in all a typical burrito experience, some might even call it authentic.
author: Kenneth H.

description: Good burritos and a great vibe, One the best taco joints in the mission.
author: Stephen R.

description: This place has the best burritos I've ever tried in my life. I ordered a super burrito with carne asada, with refried beans and no onions, and every bite I took was amazing. The cooks there know what there doing. There is no other place I would go to get a burrtio, because their super burrito has one over my heart.
author: Michael E.

description: This 'dive' Mexican place is a must try! Cheap as cheap can be and simply tasty. The horchata is very excellent and I am picky with horchata! Everything we had was excellent... Perfect choice to eat.
author: Luis M.

description:
Taqueria Cancun is one of the best places in San Francisco to get a vegetarian burrito. It was muy fantastico! BUT their super nachos are to die for! I haven't had any of their meat selections but I've heard the carne asada is good too.

The atmosphere is a bit obnoxious, but hey, it's the mission 

Anyway, I eat burritos like four times a week so I know what I'm talking about.

Just stay away from their bathrooms...
author: Jill E.

description:
If you eat here when you are drunk are you so sure its that great?  Seriously, think about that.  

This places is well below mediocre. It's sad. All that time waiting all that hard earned money done the drain for a flour tortilla stuffed mosttly with filler, which ends in an exceptionally unexciting starch finish. 

Hands down maybe one of the worst burritos i have ever had. And trust you me I have had A LOT of burritos.   My cholesterol, HBP, and BMI are testament to to this.
author: Spanky M.

description: Cheap, great burritos.  I love the carne asada super burrito - tons of avocado and cheese...and meat, of course!
author: Wendy L.

description: Over rated!  went here once, the pollo burrito was not good.  I should have known better. Everybody, like me read the review in the SF Weekly. Bleck :(
author: Bert K.

description: A solid place for giant and cheap grilled burritos. The meat is pretty good and there is plenty of space in this festive joint. I'm not crazy about their salsa but it is definitely one of the best burritos I've had in SF. Its also super cheap - under $5 and open after the bars close.
author: Lainy C.

description: Yo this place is like going to a Mexican festival.  All the decorations hanging off the ceiling.  My boyfriend showed me this place, because he love the tacos de ceviche w/ avocado.  Their food is very delicious!
author: Michelle M.

description: I love this place. I have yet to top their super steak burrito and I just LOVE their green sauce. It's so fiery and fabulous. And yes, I had a Pancho Villa burrito the other day. It was good, but not like Cancun. It  was technically great, but it was missing that something special, that extra zing.  The meat at Cancun is just perfect and juicy, they have good ceviche too! Yum. Love it.
author: Zvezdana O.

description: Think it has won Taqueria of the year a few times - i keep going back for their avocado salsa then hit the donut place down the street for a churro - oh yeah!
author: Matt T.

description: The al pastor burrito was spot on, gargantuan, maybe a wee low on the al pastor but the thing was still a bomb swimming in red sauce and it fed two of us lightweights. And the melon aqua fresca was yum too. Call me a sucker...
author: Henry Y.

description: Three days of diarrhea from this place. Granted, that was back in 2001 when the restrooms weren't working. Now, having drunk tap water in China many times, I know for sure that 3 days of diarrhea for me would put most anyone else in the hospital. So that's why you get 2 stars. I know the food is good, I've eaten it, but man, please please please keep the place cleaner and wash your hands after every cash register and poop stop. If I eat here again without the runs, then I will raise to 3 stars. Is that asking too much?
author: Brian J.

description: Had a Super Burrito from Taqueria Cancun today. It was amazing!! One of the best burritos I've ever had.  Really enjoyed the slices of avocado that were in the burrito. Highly recommended
author: Alex C.

description: I was literally starving when I came in here. I had failed to eat anything for several hours and I felt like my stomach lining was eating itself. I was in the area and this place was one of the few eateries still open, so I stopped in. Ordered a super burrito with carnitas and it was very satisfying, but slightly too mushy for my liking. Maybe it was the sour cream, or the fact that the tortilla wasn't toasted enough. Also, there was not enough guacamole. The salsa that came with the chips were spicy and delicious. I was also accosted with a homeless man asking for change, which wasn't cool, but I guess that's normal for this area. I was able to barely finish the entire burrito, but I was also super hungry. I would stop in again if I was in the area.
author: k h.

description:
Nothing better than 3 carne asada tacos with a tangerine Jarritos from Taqueria Cancun on Mission.  You want to be sure to go to this exact location because they differ in taste and quality.

The only thing I would suggest to them would be to clean the tables more frequently.  We ended up pushing the other used stuff to the other side of the table, via a newpaper.  Eventually they came to clear, but didn't clean.  Kinda gross, but what else would you expect.  The tacos still taste damn good!
author: Alison N.

description:
I can totally see why this place has such a good rep. I didn't expect as much flavor as their burritos and tortas had. The salsa that camp with the complimentary chips was even flavorful. I can't wait to go back. Cheap and delish

For an inside look at Taqueria Cancun check out this video review.
http://freakingdelicious.blogspot.com/2009/04/fd-taqueria-cancun.html
author: Patrick B.

description:
For years, the legendary Taqueria Cancun burrito was the king of the Mission burrito world. 

Since then, many challengers have come and gone, but the Cancun burrito still stands the test of time.
author: Steve L.

description:
I have to agree with Nalipay, bay area burritos have NOTHING on the  Mexican food in San Diego.

But, that's sort of moot... because I can't bike to San Diego for lunch. I got a pretty amazing vegetarian burrito at Cancun last night. I can say, hands down, best burrito I've had in the city so far.

So yea, if you're in San Diego, eat there... but if not, eat at Cancun.
author: jared c.

description:
I know that there are taquerias on every corner in the Mission, but I only have eyes for one.

Taquera Cancun has been my unwavering favorite for 8 years now.  I am willing to believe there is a better burrito out there, and I let people take me to their favorite taquerias, but the super veggie burrito at Cancun still holds the trophy.

There are a few important factors: 

1) the grilled, not steamed, tortilla
2) the chunks of whole avocado
3) the correct amount of cilantro
4) my favorite horchata ever
5) cheap!

Simple, straightforward, and just perfect, down to the last bite.
author: Anna W.

description:
food and value are top notch!

great mid day or late night burrito joint that has personality, authenticity & fast service.

sometimes seating can be tough and/or table busing gets a little behind..but it goes with the territory for a popular, cheap mexican restaurant.
author: alexander b.

description:
Okay.  I will admit.  I am lazy.  I live around 14th and Folsom, and after my sister suggested going to this place (me not knowing where it was) agreed.  We're walking, walking, and I'm getting annoyed because I have no idea where the hell we were going and when I was going to get some food into MY BELLY.  

Finally got there, ordered (I honestly don't even remember what I ordered, I was that hungry), while waiting for our food, my sister and I are asked by a crack chick if we have a quarter (no).  The guys working there were pretty funny, calling out numbers and not sure if they were calling out the right number.  We get our food, we sit down, we start wolfing and theeeeen...THE MUSIC.  Not much kills a hunger buzz than loud mariachi music, so we inhale our food and get the hell out of there.  Food's great, prices reasonable, atmosphere...not so much.
author: Asha H.

description:
Can't decide if it's the veggie burrito from here or the all-night drinking and bad dancing that causes sometimes violent stomach issues. Unfortunately, these two events are always linked together, so it's difficult to determine until either variable is analyzed on its own account. 

Nonetheless, having an entire half of a fresh avocado stuffed inside a burrito that costs $3 is worth the risk.
author: Kelly R.

description: Simply amazing. Their Super Burrito with carnitas is one of the best burritos I've ever eaten. The perfect ending to a night out in the Mission.
author: Garrett F.

description: the BEST (carnitas) TACO SALAD...ever!!   hands down, best ever, perfect.
author: Abigail W.

description: Living on the east coast for two years makes you appreciate a good burrito. This place, my friends, knows how to make a good burrito. I'm a vegetarian, but my meat devouring friends enjoy this spot just as much. The ingredients taste fresh, so the burrito is tasty. It's also gigantic. I have a big appetite, so I can finish it in one sitting. However, I have many friends who eat the burrito over two meals because of the size. If you want to have a great burrito come to this restaurant.
author: Aseem P.

description:
I really think I'm getting addicted to their veggie burrito.  I had one last night and another one two days before that, yet I'm thinking about getting another tonight.  Did they start putting meth in these things or something?  Well, it probably doesn't help that I just moved 1 block from this location.

This is the only burrito that I don't mind containing rice.  It actually adds to the flavor of the burrito, unlike most places that just use it as filler.
author: Paul W.

description:
I have an equal amount of friends who swear by Cancun as I do those who are Farolito junkies, so I thought I'd make up my own mind and try both as an unbiased observer.

The Cancun super burrito mojado is fantastic! The carne asada is perfectly spiced and the fresh avocado seals the deal.  The fact that it's the same price for a smothered burrito as a normal one is great!!  The super quesadillas are also really good, although a bit on the greasy side, put a lot of guacamole on them and you won't even notice the oiliness.

The only reason that Farolito wins out in this clash of the taqueria titans is that Cancun doesn't offer unlimited salsa, and the salsa that they do give you isn't nearly as good as that at Farolito.  Otherwise, Cancun is a great taqueria and is number 2 on my list of Mish taquerias.
author: Craig E.

description:
Super quesadilla suiza - this thing is huge - enough for two peeps. Got the chicken version. Must say I think I like the beef more since it makes it taste like a cheesy burger in tortilla wrap instead. 

The taco with carne asada was ok. I think this place is decent. At least the tables/benches look cleaner and is well lighted.
author: Cindy W.

description: I [barely] remember coming here with a group of friends after roaming around the city drinking.  The carnitas tacos hit the spot and helped soak up a bit of the alcohol.
author: Paige W.

description:
OH man, almost every night drinking in the Mission ends with Taqueria Cancun. That's a good thing!

Ok so the food here...actually isn't that great. I've been here sober and it's really not that good compared to like Papalote or El Castalito. But if you're drunk and hungry and it's 2 or 3 am...this is the place to go, it's close to a lot of bars and I think it's open the latest. I always go with a carne asada super burrito or quesadilla (I think the quesadilla is better). You can easily share one between two people since the portion here is gigantic. Be sure to smother everything in the green salsa which is a mixture of avocado and jalapeno. I think it's gotten less spicy over the last year or so cause I remember I used to almost die eating it, now it's not really that spicy. But it's stlll really tasty!

So I guess the verdict is...don't come here sober, but come drunk!
author: Mastiff B.

description:
Cheap, delicious food at a hole-in-the-wall with fabulous Mexican decor and an ultra-convenient location!!!

The veggie burrito is great!  Wash it down with a Negra Modelo and it is pretty much heaven.
author: Christie S.

description:
I'd almost give Taqueria Cancun 4 stars. I've been going here for eighty thousand years or so... I've lived near two of their locations.

But - their chips are just so-so. I mean, they are edible (although, at the Valencia & 29th location, sometimes, barely) ... i wish they had better  chips, because their green tomatillo salsa is to die for. It almost makes up for it, though. It's spicy as hell, which sometimes I can't do in other restaurants (I get hiccups - so embarrassing), but here I risk it. It's yummy.

I'm not a vegetarian, but I always order vegetarian at taquerias. I do *love* the veggie burritos, and the veggie tacos. Having eaten so many burritos in life, now I pretty much do the tacos. Love 'em.

This location used to have a lot of gang activity, but that seems to have calmed down, though obviously the neighborhood is kind of sketchy... but, I used to live practically on top of it as a single gal, and never had a problem.
author: Dusty R.

description: I just want to say...watching the guy in the back slice through all that glorious raw meat was a sight to behold. Oh and the burrito we got was great too. Carry on!
author: Penson L.

description:
The Big Majado has got to be one of the greatest creations ever.  For under $10 you can gorge yourself on what has to be easily over a pound of burrito goodness.  Cram that thing with some al pastor and enjoy the variance of flavors as you work your way from left to right across the plate.  They cover 1/3 of it with their red salsa, 1/3 with sour cream, and 1/3 with guac a la el Mexico el flaggo.

Its very clear that the guys behind the counter have perfected a system.  I'm always amazed at the efficiency by which they work.

I'd also recommend hitting up the agua frescas, cantaloupe edition, although the horchata is good as well.  The frescas here are always thick, pulpy, not too iced down, and probably carry about 50% sugar.  But its all good... you're eating out!
author: Jeff S.

description:
I have always had a good burrito here. 
I am not going with high expectations.
I go there for a simple burrito -- where they do the best fluffiest rice.

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
I don't know what the big deal is about this taqueria. El Gran Taco Loco is much better up the street. That being said I am not a vegetarian which might be the ONLY reason to eat here. 

I have enjoyed the carne asada burritos I've eaten here over the years, but they do NOT have a salsa bar. You have to ask to get a decent amount of extra salsa, which is not enough for this spicy salsa addict. This place is not bad, but is nothing special.
author: Yvette K.

description: All the reviews are on the mark...Really really good veggie burrito.  One doesn't even need to add salsa for any reason to eat this burrito. Great flavor all by itself which is a rare treat. I can see why they got soo many recognitions for this place. And btw.. This place is full of character. What more can you ask for...
author: Sue T.

description:
God, I love this place.  I went twice in one week while vacationing.  My cousin brought me here a few years ago and I had been dying to go back ever since.  

The carnitas are AMAZING.  They fry them up a bit before plating so they're a little crispy and loaded with greasy, porky delicious flavor.  I could eat this meat with nothing else.  

Free chips and salsa and the salsas are awesome.  Excellent agua frescas and good portions.
author: Lauren A.

description: The best veggie burrito in San Francisco. I have been eating here for over a dozen years, and am happy the burritos haven't changed at all. Fresh carrot juice is great, too.
author: Peridot G.

description: I've had burritos all over the West Coast. From the tip of Cabo all the way up to Oregon. Taqueria Cancun is one of the best bang for your buck taqueria's that I have been to. The carnitas, pollo, carne asada and cabeza are all excellent. Each is cooked and seasoned pretty well. The lenguas is only average and could use some more seasoning. I have not tried the sesos. I would stick to the super burrito. It's got everything you want including what looks like a whole avocado. You know you're in an above average taqueria when the salsa is great. Here you get Salsa Verde and some Pico de Gallo with your fresh chips. Each salsa is spicier than the average salsa you get at a taqueria, but in a "I-know-this-is-hot-but-I-want-more" kind of way. Whether you just left a bar and need some late night grub or you just want to grab a quick lunch, Cancun is a great place to go.
author: Thomas L.

description: I prefer the one in the tenderloin, but it's still a bloody good burrito! Love the shrimp super one here.
author: Ali B.

description: There's nothing like a grilled burrito from Cancun - one of the few places that does it as opposed to steaming the tortilla. Fast service, ultra-affordable prices makes this spot a perennial favorite. Along with the delicious burritos and tacos, the cocktail de camarones is must try. It's fun to see all hipster suburbanite expats mix in with the working class locals.
author: Be N.

description:
My favorite taqueria in the Bay Area.  It's cheap, open late, and delicious.  The salsas are smoking hot, and the service is fast and efficient.  The only issues would be that the bathroom could use some love from Martha Stewart and parking is nearly impossible in the Mission (at 19th).  Still, it's worth it to eat here.

PROS: The best/cheapest burrito you can find in the Bay Area
CONS: Parking
author: Drew P.

description:
The atmosphere and the cleanliness (or lack there of):
The clientele goes from funky to creepy; you will probably get hassled by a drug dealer, or an "eccentric" person trying to sell you a stolen muni pass at the very least. If you have to go to the bathroom don't do it here. I assure you that if you decide to check it out you will no longer feel such a strong urge...actually..you might loose your appetite as well. This is not the cleanest place, take your anti-bacterial disinfectant whatever you have if you are so inclined and be warned. 

Also - The Lexington Club is right up the street so lots of sexy lesbians pop in..rawr. 

The tasty food:
TASTY! Super spicy green salsa all avocado happy and such, thicker chips than I normally like but I view them as a vehicle for the salsa. Try the Super Burrito with chicken. Oh the chicken! I order this sexy beast without any rice (I'm just not a rice in the burrito kinda gal) and they make up for it a bit with their yummy soupy (but not too soupy) beans and their perfectly ripe avocado.

mmmm
author: Natalie G.

description:
My friend is obsessed with burritos. He has traveled to many a good burrito places and he has informed me that for: $5.50 for a Mojado (wet burrito) is a fancy find. 

The place is decorated with colorful indigenous flags, murals, paintings. This place is fast, has awesome burritos. I wish I lived in the Mission District. 

I would love to live in the Mission district just for this place.
author: Jack C.

description:
They seem to be known for their Veggie Burritos but I just can't, I just can't....  

Maybe in time but I still need to have my meat.  So I ordered a pastor burrito since that is one of my favorite meats for my burrito and it was pretty good.  All the ingredients were fresh and it was quite tasty.  

And their prices are right.  I'm still not into that Super Burrito thing costing $7-$8 plus.  

Here the super is $5.50

And if you are on a budget $4.50 for a regular
author: Mark W.

description:
My fave burrito place. First, because they grill the tortillas instead of just steaming them like a lot of places do. Second, because they really heap on the avocados. I once watched the guy scoop out an avocado, toss it in there, and then grab another avocado and toss in another half, just because the first avocado wasn't big enough. This is real avocadoness. Cancun is the place for burritos, as in the Super. Even the Super Veggie is good despite being veggie. For tacos I would go elsewhere as they have never heard of a fish taco here. There is usually horchata and a single agua fresca available, e.g. watermelon or cantaloupe, for a good price.

Ambiance? Well, this is the heart of the Mission, and you will get the regular denizens here. There is blaring mariachi or reggaeton from the jukebox, and you sit on these big picnic tables, and truth be told this is not the place to relax and hang out for an hour and chat over a burrito. But it has it's under- (or negatively-) stated charm and it works. You knew you weren't going here for a sit-down meal.
author: Art K.

description:
If this place only had decent chips, I'd have given it a 5 star review.  To succinctly describe what the chips here are like, think a poor man's (maybe even a homeless man's) version of Granny Goose or Tom's.  Yeah, THAT bad.

Aside from the chips issue, the burritos, tortas, and juevos rancheros are all delicious here.  They are definitely not stingy with the cheese and avocado here, which is a GREAT thing.  And true to their claim, they might very well have the best vegetarian burrito in SF.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
This place is BOMB if you're veg. The quesadillas are amazing, the burritos divine . . . yummy, yummy, yummy.
Also, these guys do right by some horchata.
Minus a star for the sketchy policy on letting random, non customers take over the bathroom and basically not caring what goes on in front of the counter, but the food's decent enough to keep me coming back. Just get it to go, is all.
author: Erin P.

description: Of the myriad taquerias in SF, not one holds a candle to Taqueria Cancun.  Cancun serves the freshest ingredients in largest burritos.  The horchata is a great way to tame the spicy flavors...
author: Daniel H.

description: I love love love this place!!!!! A friend who used to live in the mission introduced me to this fab hole in the wall joint. They're open till late to satisfy your drunken cravings of Mexican food. It's always packed especially late at night. The burritos are delicious and their salsa is the bomb!!
author: Ms B.

description:
Best burritos in all the land!!!!!!!

If you order a side of beans and rice, be prepared for the largest plate of beans and rice you've ever seen.

The #1 destination after the bar - lines get crazy but it's worth the wait.
author: Vivi W.

description: I echo what the other 1000 reviewers have said. Great pollo asado burrito. Salsas are good and spicy. Neighborhood is a little sketchy, but fine at lunch time.  Among the best of Mission taquerias IMHO.
author: Michael H.

description:
Awesome food!  Atmosphere leaves a lot to be desired, but for the price you can't beat this Mexican food.  

Please, order something more creative than the burrito.  The burrito is the least interesting item on the menu.  Try the torta, enchilada, quesadilla...anything but the burrito.  Ok, you can try the burrito, but please have your friend order something else so you can try some of the other tasty dishes.
author: Shawn H.

description: You can't go wrong by trying Cancun out. Smooth flavor and solid burrito architecture that withstands sharing. Try the pastor meat!
author: Mario C.

description: Best steak tacos ever! And if you're a girl sometimes the workers will sneak you in through the back so you don't have to wait in the line that wraps around the building at 2am!
author: J R.

description:
What a superb place. Easy to read menu. Fresh, quality meats and salsa. Mmmm. Great prices too! This taqueria will exceed your expectations. 

Parking Hint: if you can't find a street spot near by, kitty corner to the taqueria across the street is a burger king parking lot. Be discreet and they will never know. Plus u can watch your car from the taqueria for piece of mind. :)
author: ELiOT S.

description:
So it's the same mentality as Papalote - I just live in the Mission now.  Never fails to please, whether it be 9:00 am or 2:00 am they do it right.  With no exceptions.

Beware the drunken patron - you'll have to deal with massive crowds and long lines.  But once the burrito hits your mouth you sober right up.

Well done sir.
author: Girls Named Cherise C.

description: My favorite place to get full on my lunch break! amazing food plus the price is fair! yumm yumm yumm!
author: Everrett T.

description:
Great place, one of the best burritos in SF. 
Loved the fact that they are open very late!
author: Richard M.

description: My carnitas burrito had a significant amount of plastic mixed with the carnitas. No thank you. Not going back--I'm sticking with my old fav, La Corneta.
author: Jared B.

description:
The burritos here are a part of the canon.  Plain and simple, my favorite cheap eats, ever, by far.

I've had most items on the menu.  On an objective scale, almost everything was good, but I was inevitably disappointed that I could have been eating a super burrito instead of whatever else I had gotten (though I know people who would say the same about the quesadillas).

I'm pretty sure the seasoning used in the meat has some local ingredients (specifically, crack from 16th & Mission, I don't know how else it could be so addicting).  The super burritos are huge and heavy with beans, cheese, and rice, and balanced warm and cool with jalapenos, fresh avocado, and sour cream.  If you want a little more kick, the salsas that come with are hot (the green is especially recommended).

Only downsides:  the chips could be better, and the horchata is a little chalky.  They're supposedly famous for their tortas, but the one time I had it, I thought it had way too much bread.  This paragraph really doesn't matter, though - it's all about the burrito.
author: Jason F.

description: For the price this might be the best burrito you can find in the missions.  The meats are high quality, they grill the tortilla, and they use actual avocado in the super burritos.  This has become my go to spot in the mission for a burrito.
author: Lenza M.

description:
Excellent veggie burritos and shrimp cocktails.  Dirt cheap too.

For some reasons the chips are always stale but that adds to the charm of the place.  Only Cancun I have been to is the one at Mission and Valencia, so don't know how good (or bad) the others ones are.
author: Zk K.

description:
The best place to get a Burrito if you're in San Francisco.  

The price is cheap, the quality is great and the quantity is amazing.

Problem:  beware of the crips that may or may not be outside and inside and at any given time, the lines are HUGE, not because of slow cooks but because of how great the burritos are and how popular the place is in the Mission District.

I highly suggest trying it out, at least once, just don't wear a lot of red when doing so...=)
author: Mike V.

description:
I visited this place today for the first time and thought, "wow.  this place is festively dirtayyy."  But whatever, right?  I stood in line, looked at the menu, and ordered my carne asada super burrito with no rice.  yep, I said, SIN ARROZ!  I'm from San Diego where the burritos consist of one starch, not TWO!  

I looked over the counter and noticed that they heat the tortilla on the skillet... awesome!   I don't understand those steam-clean machines for tortillas.  Que gross.  Unfortunately, this is where the awesomeness ends. 

My carne asada burrtio arrived with no carne asada... and when I told the dude behind the counter, he served me a super-sized plate of attitude before finally caving in and making me a new burrito.
author: Erick A.

description:
Simply put: the best burritos in the city..

fresh avocado, homemade salsa.. there is a reason they've been voted Best of the Bay so many times...  and soo cheap! 

the nachos are great, as are the quesadillas, i make it a point to stop by pretty much every time i am in the city... i got spoiled living a few minutes drive away for 2+ years, and now that I am stuck in the east bay, I really miss my staple burrito joint..

EDIT (12/2006): the last few visits to my once favorite place have been disappointing. I don't know if I just happened in on bad days, but the tastiness factor has definitely declined recently.
author: tina p.

description:
So far in my short stint in San Francisco this place has the best burrito I have had throughout the city. Something about the way it all comes together makes me smile with each bite. I have also been to El Farolito and although there burritos are also pretty good, I would choose Taqueria Cancun over them. 

Its cheap, its fast, and it tastes damn good. Hard to beat that :)
author: Brent F.

description:
The super burrito is super good!  Filling and delicious. The salsa was hot!  A great buy for lunch or dinner.

Little anecdote:
Shortly after leaving my friend was like oh man, I have to poo.  Me, being a fan of pooing at home said, can't it wait.  He said no, its gotta be now, you know, to make room for that delicious and giant burrito he just ate.  So, looking for familiarity he went back into TC...shortly after coming right back out with a look of disgust.  "There is literally poop on the walls" is what he said.  I'm not sure if that's actually true, I didn't bother to check myself, didn't really feel the urge to.  
Moral of the story, make room for that burrito before you leave the comfort of your own john.
author: Levi B.

description:
A rare bright spot in the shockingly desolate SF late-night munchies scene.  The burritos here are the best I've had in San Francisco - go with the carnitas as we all know that pig is the tastiest animal on the 

BONUS TIP - Get here before 1:40am on Friday and Saturday nights.  Taqueria Cancun is right across the street from Bruno's so it becomes a madhouse once Bruno's gives last call.
author: Oscar M.

description:
How this place doesn't have six stars...?

Anyways- this is the best Cancun of the bunch.  It always feels a bit more alive than the others. And the majato is the BEST here!  In fact, I don't think I've ever ordered anything else but a majato!  

Viva la Taqueria Canun!
author: Dangerous T.

description:
Whenever someone comes to visit me who has never been to San Francisco before, our first stop for lunch is usually Cancun.  Their response is typically - "crap, I have to eat here again tomorrow." Revealed to me by my brother, who used to eat at Cancun all the time in the nineties, I discovered the bliss that is a Cancun burrito in 2003.  Though I know you either love it, or you don't, I fall squarely in the former camp.  The highlights are definitely:

1. Toasted tortillas.  It's so good.  Really.
2. Tons of avocado in each burrito.  No skimping.
3. The price tag.

There's nothing yuppie about the burrito, and you'll find Mexicans and Mission hipsters sitting side by side munching away.

I've also found that their ground beef super tacos are scrumptious as well.  

You have nothing to lose with this place.  My preferred location is on Mission at 19th, though the one down in Bernal Heights is also great, and I've never gone wrong on Mission at 6th either.
author: Jon A.

description:
(Preface: I don't eat meat so I can only relate that my SO says the meat is too dry here, but that was on a burrito with no sour cream, so maybe the balance was off.)

Dependable vegetarian burritos but nothing that knocks my socks off.  The decor is cheerfully garish and the long benches let you rub elbows with all sorts of folks.  A lot of people have told me this is the best Taqueria in San Francisco, but I feel like I could go to at least two better ones within walking distance, and I haven't tried anything like all the taquerias in the Mission
author: Tullia F.

description:
If you're craving a burrito or some tacos late at night, you definitely need to come here!  

The decor is colorful and the clientele is diverse.  Not exactly the cleanest place..but the food is just what one is looking for late at night or after a sweaty basketball game!
author: Christine C.

description:
My favorite burrito place in SF. I get the super veggie.

They could do better with the cleanliness of the bathroom, but I won't dock them for it.
author: Justin C.

description:
Went here with a few of my peeps (peeps = cute white girls 'cuz I'm a small (but fiesty!) white dude). We really enjoyed the salsa verde which one friend really appreciated, as she made it every day with her host family while living in Oaxaca. The burritos had the tortillas fried up a bit, which made them just the right kind of crispy. You know the type: the one that your mom never made. 

I've been here a few times and it's always crowded. With good reason: they are quick and the food tastes great. I love how the burritos are more goop-y on the inside. You know what makes it that way: guacamole and sour cream. Yes, fat is flavor, butter is love. And guac is romance in a bite. 

Get on the BART and check this place out. It's da bomb.
author: Benjamin T.

description: Born and raised on the peninsula, I am no stranger to many visits to taquerias over the years so there is a high standard. I was SHOCKED after reading the high ratings them eating here...so disappointed!! Husband said the carne asada wet burrito was metiocre and the rice needed more flavoring. I am vegetarian so it sucked!!! Veggie burrito was bland. I have had way better in sj and sm! Never returning...oh, and their chips and salsa were pathetic!
author: Maddy B.

description: Pretty good, not the best mexican place but it's not bad either. You get a pretty big portion ordering the quesadillas. . I would say that the carne asada is the best meat to get here. Not a bad place at all.
author: Greg D.

description: Delicious burritos. Quality ingredients. My favorite part is that they use fresh avocados instead of guacamole.
author: Maren A.

description:
drunken Mission nights+Taqueria Cancun prawn super burrito? 

damn....if u dont know, u better axe somebody....

This is one of the best burritos i've personally consumed and i've had burritos from a lot of places...

The great thing about this prawn burrito is its refinement...not only do they put about 10 big prawns in there, but the balance of flavor, overall construction and taste of this burrito is much more refined than the setting indicates...

Their green salsa also has chunks of avocado in it and is so good...

get drunk, go here and sleep in heavenly peace.
author: matt h.

description: For people who enjoy burrito, this place has one of the best-tasted burritos in Bay Area. Size decent and taste extremely good. I went to Chipotle the following week and could not even finish the burrito there, just because it tasted like crap comparing to Taqueria Cancun.
author: Jun W.

description:
i've gone back and forth on this spot but the last few times they have been very on point.  Sure I'd like more salsa options, but that said their green salsa is very good.  
good ingredients, good mix ration in the burritos and quesadillas, good products.  
with those reasons as well as location, this taqueria will hold steady in my top 5 go to spots.
author: Andrew r.

description: Inexpensive and VERY tasty food. I've brought nearly all my friends here when I used to live in the Bay Area. Also, whenever I come back to the Bay I ALWAYS hit up this place.
author: Hassan N.

description: Delicious vegetarian burrito. Great value, too!
author: Foodie V.

description: Plenty of good reviews...cuz the place is good!  Cash only sucks but the meat and beans are damn good.  I'm a stickler for good al pastor and they can work it.  The place is always crowded and the Mission location is great for people watching.  The ingredients were fresh and tasty the meat was sweet/spicy and not fatty.  My friend got a quesadilla and it was amazing also.  Cheese and tortilla were delicious!
author: Todd O.

description:
i love love love love love burritos! and i love love love love love getting them from taqueria cancun! the mission has the best mexican food in the whole dang city, but this place blows a whole buncha other places outta the water. 

get the super burrito for $6, and you can feed a third world country. i never seem to be able to finish one as hard i try to. mmm! mm! mm!

great place after the club if you got the munchies. the sucky thing is that everyone is in the same boat as you, so there are ridiculous lines to get your hands on a burrito, so keep that in mind!

and if you love colors, the ambiance in this place is color OVERLOAD. im just sayin...
author: Scott L.

description: I thought  I had the best burrito that was all changed after a try of cancun. I never had a guacamole thats a little spicy. The ingridents so fresh and the chicken its moist and tasty. The salsas are really clean, fresh and with some heat. This is the place to go in the mission I found a new place.
author: Nadia N.

description: burrito mojado is HUGE! definitely a good dish to share with a friend if you're not a huge eater. the chicken was pretty dry and crumbly, so i probably should have gone with carne asada or something. the sauce is delicious and is spicy enough that after eating for a while you realize your tongue is kind of starting to burn and you need to take a quick break to drink some water and eat some freshly-made chips smothered in guacamole.  house made salsa is also really delicious and fresh - love it when places don't skimp on the heat factor!
author: Stephanie C.

description: I think this is the best value burrito in the Mission.  The meat is a little lower quality than other places (e.g. Pancho Villa).  Apparently people get shot here on occasion.
author: Quags M.

description:
Its a legend for a reason.  Avoid the meats and go veggie unless you like Al Pastor, and keep an eye on the chefs.  My wife swears by the grill guy who's about six foot with dark hair and eyes.. maybe its because he always flirts with her?!?  She runs to Altena when the short light-skinned guy is twisting up the burritos.  Some people got it, some dont.

Gotta give a quick shout out to the ceviche tostadas... you might think that raw fish seems dicy from this time honored establishment, but I've eaten 100+ and never had any "issues".  Wish I could say the same about that al pastor super B with black beans, no crema por favor that the short anglo looking dude twisted for me a couple of weeks back.
author: evan J.

description:
So I realized a little while back that my friends are just as flawed as my enemies, only my friends had the type of flaws I could deal with. Taqueria Cancun is the same way. Its dirty, crowded and Im not a huge fan of their steak. Their burritos are good, but not out of this world good. 

The chicken enchiladas and quesadillas  are 5/5 for sure, and thats what I go for.
author: Tony D.

description:
God I love everything here.

But you only get 4 stars because I have, on more than one occasion, ordered one thing, and gotten another, quite different, thing and all you did was shrug your shoulders and pretended that you didn't speak English.

But all your food still rocks, even if it wasn't what I ordered.
author: Brandon B.

description:
Solid. This place is solid. You always know exactly what your getting.
I'm going to stand in line behind these hipsters. (Well, we are in the mission, aren't we?) Once they finish ordering something vegan, I'll order a veggie burrito, no onions. It will be stuffed with black beans and just the right amount of slightly runny sour cream and guacamole. Cilantro, yes. No lettuce, thank god. Then they'll fry it. That's when it gets really good.
I'll pay $4.80, or $5.30 since they raised the price. I'll get a basket of chips and two salsas. I'll feel weird about touching the chips because my hands feel dirty but I kind of have to just do it. 
They call my order, I retrieve my burrito and attempt to experience the joy that is cancun, while fending off panhandlers who probably won't leave in less than three minutes.
author: melody r.

description:
Best veggie burrito-- I am not kidding- who else put chunks of avocado instead of guac?  And the fact that they're grilled instead of steamed is major points from me.

I'm also all about the salsa verde.
author: SaraMitra P.

description:
Voted the best burrito in SF huh?

I tried the veggie burrito - and it was pretty darn good. The ingredients taste very fresh. Salsa is good. 

CHIPS SUCK though. What's up with that? I mean seriously, is it so hard to get decent chips?? And not just buy a bag of store-bought crap.

Except for the panhandlers coming in and disrupting a perfectly good burrito eating experience - this place is great!
author: Chili B.

description: I'm not a huge fan of burrito but La Taqueria makes me appreciate burritos! The burrito is cheap, huge, and most importantly delicious! I think what makes the burrio is the meat! I ordered the beef burrito and the meat definitely gave most of the flavor; I'm not a fan of beef so they might have done something right with the meat for me to enjoy. It's soft, juicy, and savory. The only thing I don't really like is the really spicy avocado. Do they make it less spicy? I love avocado but I just can't eat theirs. Other than that, the place is definitely well worth it! And I'm going to say this one more time, the burrito is relatively cheap in my opinion.
author: Anette N.

description: Does this place need another review?  After gorging on an Al Pastor Burrito, I vote 'yes'.  The burrito was the regular but there was nothing regular about the taste, it was spectacularly spicy; almost as colorful as the interior of this tiny taqueria.  Spicy meat, cilantro, beans and maybe a bit too much rice (one reason I like La Taqueria is the omission of rice...but I could have ordered it without rice, I guess).  Aye Carumba!  In the al pastor were very visible red pepper pieces from the marinade.  I had to partake in some of the free water at the counter.  I like that you get a little basket of chips as well.  The green sauce is spicy good as well.  Regular burrito costs $4.99 and a meal all in itself.
author: Kevin A.

description: Regular part of my sustenance.  I understand that everyone's favorite taqueria has, more than anything, to do with which one is closest to their daily travels, or whichever was the first they visited, and this is no different for me: I live around the corner from here, so take whatever I say with a grain of salt (which, some may say, has already been included liberally in their carne asada, but: whatever!).  I just adore the super quesadilla con lengua, and have been starting to develop a taste for cabeza, too.  And the salsa verde is, how you say, nucular, in the best sense.  And there's nary a fault to be found in their veggie burritos.  I can't understand why, if I was a vegetarian, I would bother eating anything but.
author: Damon S.

description:
FYI...I always order vegetarian burritos, I'm not a vegetarian, the meat just gets in the way of burritos. Therefore, me not ordering meat, is not the reason I didn't like the burrito. 

I ordered a burrito with black beans, cheese, guacamole & pico de gallo. I was not impressed. The tortilla was good, the burrito was made up of mostly beans, barely any cheese or guacamole and it was in random spots in the burrito (not consistent throughout). 

The green salsa is delicious & really spicy. 

I love how they are open until 3am (I also hate that b/c I really don't need a burrito at 2am)! (downside, cash only although most places in the mission are cash only)
author: Elaine S.

description: I had one day in San Fran and I ate at this place twice because it was so good the first time.  The food prep is quick and the neighborhood is extremely authentic.  The meat is spiced just right, and it won't leave your mouth burning.
author: Jake B.

description: Came out from NYC, looking for the best burrito. This was the first place I was directed to of many, and ended up being the best by far!!!  Ordered the pork shoulder, light on the rice, black beans. They don't just wrap it up and hand it to you- it goes back on the grill for a spell.  You SFers take this for granted, I'm sure...
author: Matt T.

description: If you're looking for LA style mexican food when you're in San Fran, look no further than this place. That said, it is in a dodgy area of town so keep your wits about you.
author: Dave P.

description: Their vegetarian burritos are the BOMB. Yes, the bomb. I routinely go out of my way to eat here because other burritos don't match up.
author: Kristin P.

description:
My love of Mexican food, especially burritos, is almost pornographic.  If I had to choose a cuisine to eat for the rest of my life, it would definitely be Mexican.  That said, Taqueria Can-Cun (Yelp forgot the hyphen), Mission location near 20th St.  is da shit.  My favorite burrito of all time, every time, even better than burritos eaten in Mexico.

"If it ain't broke don't fix it" applies to my order here.  I've tried other items but I ALWAYS go back to my usual: the super carne asada burrito.  The freshness and quality of the grilled beef can't be overstated.  But the key here, as any fellow burrito porn fan will attest, my friends, is the all-important  PERFECTLY PROPORTIONAL BLENDING OF THE INGREDIENTS.  For this reason, all prospective taqueria owners/cooks should be sent to Taqueria Can-Cun for a mandatory burrito making workshop slash class.  I can't even count the number of times that a perfectly fine burrito experience was nearly ruined by the last few bites being all one thing, usually rice.  Every bite of a Can-Cun burrito is the same due to the skill of the cooks: 100% off the freaking chain.

All the salsas are good, but the spicy avocado salsa is mind-blowing.  Through 18 years worth of visits, they never give me a hard time about giving me that extra one either, so remember kids, always put at least a buck in that tip jar.  If it's early, I'll have my huge brick o' food with a melon (cantaloupe) agua fresca rather than a beer.  Here in the Reno area, where there are some OK-to-good taquerias (but nothing on the level of the Mission joints), aguas frescas are an endangered species, with the melon agua fresca being extinct.

The other locations (Market St. and south Mission) are good too, but for some reason don't capture the quality of the one on Mission near 19th.  I'd still give them a solid 4 1/2.

Afterthought #1: people who knock a star off, or complain at all, about a taqueria having stale chips suffer from extreme suck-itis.  They're FREE, PEOPLE!!  With the low price of the food, quit bitching!!   The inexpensive burritos are so gigantic that I've easily made two full meals out of one. Besides, the avocado salsa is so godlike that I could probably manage to keep a dead rat down if I gave it a good dip in the ol' sauce.  Sorry to anybody that read this review on their phone right before/while eating, heh heh heh.  Which brings us to...

Afterthought #2: A good friend visited San Francisco recently and believes she ate at Can-Cun, and saw a roach on the wall.  I hate to even mention this, because I've never had a cleanliness-related issue there.  From her describing the sign, location, and the interior, it sounds like it was the place though.  I guess there have been a couple instances of having to napkin the table down a bit to be safe, but hey the place is always packed with people and there's often a revolving door of homeless hitting you up as you eat, so shit can happen. If this kind of thing revolts you, don't dine in a Mission taqueria and go eat overpriced food in an antiseptic environment instead.  I like the Mission "atmosphere" myself.  Once I remember going to get a burrito on Halloween of either 1996-97 @ Can-Cun and being insulted by a group of drunken or otherwise "lit"  gangstas on the way in.  As my burrito was being prepared, I watched them shove shopping carts out into the street as the traffic swerved to avoid them.  At that point, I changed my order to "para llevar" (to go).  Just a part of life in the city...
author: The D.

description: Mission street isn't the cleanest place in the world, but the burritos here are pretty much a religious experience and worth the effort.
author: Matthew B.

description: me amor mucho this tasty joint and their yumtown burritos.  I wish I could swim in a sea of their al pastor burritos for eternity to the moon.  I am taken on a rocketship success journey with every savory bite.
author: Darren H.

description: Best late night Taqueria in San Francisco.  I am usually over there after the Elbo room or Beauty Bar.
author: Steve M.

description: I ordered the Burrito Majado (the big one)... One word: "HUGE"........ wet burrito, this thing could feed 3-4 small hungry people! I swear it's pretty damn good, with the exception of the pinto beans which seem kind of hard and old but who cares that burrito was still good!.  The service was quick enough, 5 minutes I got my food even though there was a huge line.  Not bad I think they're pretty up there on my Taqureia runs.  :-)
author: Samson K.

description: The burritos are awesome. They are big, some served with just avocado instead of guacamole. The service is pretty fast. Their quesadilla suizas are also very good. I'm pretty sure I've had breakfast here too and liked it a lot. Only thing I don't like is that they are a cash only establishment. They also squeeze fresh oranges for orange juice and press fresh carrots for carrot juice. Definitely a good place for delicious mexican food in the mission.
author: Alex E.

description: "Vegetarian burrito" NOT vegetarian.  I just had a lovely visit at Taqueria Cancun, I loved my burrito, I'm just thankful that I asked if the rice was cooked in chicken broth.  The rice IS made with chicken broth for all y'all vegetarians. So... I ordered mine without rice, quite yummy.  I love the chips and salsa!
author: Laine W.

description:
'Haven't had a better veggie burrito! I hit the Cancun atleast
once a fortnight. The super burrito tends to be too large
for my enjoyment. Everyone Ive introduced to this place now swears by it.

The HOT guacomole is awesome.
author: viv k.

description:
It starts with melting the cheese right on the tortilla.  That slightly crispy, flaky shell is what always makes me salivate when getting ready to dig in.  Spicy pico style salsa fires it up.  Always go carne asada at Cancun and it pretty much never misses.  My mouth seriously waters when I think of a cancun burrito.

Only reason I can't go 5 stars is the fact they have messed up my burrito (i.e. wrong meat, extra sour cream, etc.) on more than a couple occasions. This blows because I always get it to go (more on that in a second) and often don't realize the mistake until I get home. This was particularly horrific when I got beef brains, which is on the menu.  Would love to eat there, they have a sizable setup of picnic style tables but the mexican music is always playing at jet engine decibel levels.  I'm all for rockin the scene, but c'mon.
author: J.D. P.

description:
Cancun (formerly known as La Parilla Suiza back in the day) is about the al pastor, the quesadilla suiza and the griddle toasted tortillas, and oh my, now it's safe...no more drive-by shootings and no more cops busting someone's head on a table while you eat....and the burritos are still only $3.80. (okay they went up) Best al pastor ever and cheap as hell...'nuff said.  

Oh yes, the bathroom is to be avoided at ALL COST. Despite this, it's still worthy of 5 stars.
author: milo a.

description:
How can something SOOO good feel so bad once it hits the tummy?
It really is the best and so worth the pain.
author: S M.

description:
The best burrito you will ever have ever.

Seriously, this place would be a bargain at thrice the price; the chips and salsa are fresh and delicious and the veggie/bean burrito is the best Mexican thing I have ever tasted.  

I used to live in Bernal Heights and there is a Taqueria Cancun at the bottom of this huge Exorcist-style staircase I'd have to climb every day coming home from work.  The thought of taking down that burrito really kept me going.

Every single person I have introduced this place to has said that it absolutely lives up to the hype.
author: Dave C.

description:
A quick eat taqueria. The normal grub you would get at any taqueria but for some reason it doesn't have quite the same pizazz as other places. And seriously, I can't get a side of gaucomole?
 I mean you don't have any? sad face...
Also, no salsa bar here! Sorry miss cancun you lose points for that one. I happen to be a salsa bar junkie. Retrieiving my little cups of goodness not once but sometimes 2-3 times.
The upside is; it's cheap, pretty clean and happens to be right across the street from the Dark Room when I am involved in a show there, I know I can walk across the street and eat for 5 bucks.
author: Eryn L.

description:
Worst decor... ever... some of the best damned late night mexican food... ever

Salsa is actually spicy... and two different kinds

I am slowly getting over my excitement when places have horchata... it just was not part of the menu back east... all part of becoming a Californian I guess... 

Eight different meats, each one is awesome. 

Ill admit it, I had just come from a magazine launch... and had enjoyed my fair share of libations... so my memory is just a little foggy. 

On the downside, the chips were stale, there was no salsa bar (though, not sure if that is such a bad thing... always leery of places where people can congregate and sneeze on things (read, Salad Bars)), and no guacamole... but all things that are easily overcome for Great Late Night Mexican.
author: Jordan Y.

description:
This is the only place I ever eat at when I am in the Mission. Why, you ask? Because it is amazing! Finally a place with some authentic mexican food and an authentic mexican atmosphere to boot. They also have Sangria Senorial and Jarritos, AND mexicoke...yay (coke made with real sugar and not corn syrup - trust me, you can taste difference!) 
The prices are pretty cheap and the servings are big and also come with chips and salsa. I like the picnic table style seating because you get to meet some interesting people. The bums dont really bother me much, I dont mind giving them my glass bottles so they can recycle them, or some chips or whatever. 
Another big bonus is that this place is open late, till like 2 or 3am.  So you can pretty much always get that delicious burrito or taco you are craving. I love the loud bustling atmosphere of the place, and the deliciousness of the food!
author: Jessica S.

description: There are not enough good things I can say about Cancun! Whether you are hungry around lunchtime or at 3am, you are guaranteed to get the best burrito every time. Be sure to add an agua fresca to your order if you're not in the mood for a beer. Consistently fast service, delicious and cheap: Viva Cancun!
author: Jeni K.

description: The best ever? No... let's be honest, it definitely isn't. But, it is really, really, really good.  I was expecting a little more but it's definitely worth a shot.  Word of warning for anyone that isn't a SF local...this isn't the nicest part of town so you'll be walking around a few homeless people here and there.  If this makes you uncomfortable, then skip this place.  I don't think it's that big of a deal but I can definitely see a fellow tourist giving this place a bad review just because of the location.  Also, if you want to get rid of your appetite then just go in one of the bathrooms and you won't feel like eating for a day.
author: Ryan F.

description: the owner doesnt speak or understand english and is rude. i took one bite and the food is boring and tasteless. i wouldn't even give it to my dog. the health rating is 73 ie; "needs improvement." it sure does! what an unfortunate waste of time and money.  "no stars" for this one.
author: K L.

description:
Vegetarians beware! My friend got sick (like she had meat products) after eating a dish here. 

If you are a meat eater, thought... YUMMY! I would have gone for four stars, as their chips and salsa are sort of lacking, but I love their burritos. Great beef.
author: Kat L.

description: Great chips and one of the best burritos I've had in a very long time.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Jane M.

description: I drive by this place all the time and never stopped by until I came across a review stating they have the best burritos.  On my first visit to any taqueria I usually try the carne asada super burrito, but I wan't too hungry so I opted for a super taco (carne asada).  It was very good.  I like the massive amounts of guacamole.  I didn't care for the chips as it seemed it was from a grocery store and was very salty.  I'll definitely try the super burrito on my next visit.
author: Ricky M.

description: I've never had anything but the veggie burrito, cause it's so damn good I can't break away. I've had hundreds, surely, in the 10+ years I've been going (to all 3 of the Cancuns, all great). The veggie burrito, with its hunks of avocado and flaky grilled tortilla, always makes me eat way more than intended and need to unbuckle my pants. I dream of it when away from home for more than a few weeks.
author: Mary T.

description: Maybe it's because I'm a Londoner, we tend to have somewhat limited Mexican options in comparison to our American compadres. Therefore i just love to sample the local quesadilla place in town, I was satisfied here with a low cost, highly munchable pulled pork snack drizzled with tangy guacamole, devoured in under 12 minutes.
author: inspirationjunkie

description: Great chicken quasadillas. The salsa is extremely hot for this gringo. Cash only. Quick service. There are community tables. Sometimes homeless people come in and beg while you are eating.
author: Ignatius D.

description: So Taqueria Cancun has been my favorite for the longest time. But recently it seem that their meet turns rancid. My brother got sick over eating one of their burritos. So I like the burritos, but on occasions their meat goes bad.
author: Liliana M.

description: Ok so I'm still trying to take in what just happened but I think I just went to a hole in the wall Mexican joint and just had my mind blown...yes it was that good. I went to the one on Market Street (there are a few of them). It was so good that I could have been eaten in a urinal and it still would have been a delightful experience. Hold on second...yup. It was the best Mexican food I've ever had. Now if you'll excuse me I have to somehow convince my wife to move to San Francisco.
author: John S.

description:
This place has always been a favorite of mine.
They make there food consistent and for the most it doesn't take them to long even when the line is out the door.
Al Pastor Super Burrito is my S*#& try it!!!
author: Rich P.

description: Yesterday I went out to the city to meet a friend and she suggested this joint because we both had a craving for Mexican food. She said that it was really good food at a cheap price so I thought why not? When I came into the Taqueria I had to use the restroom pretty bad so when I got in the restroom I noticed that the toilet paper was being held up by two locks, one a key lock and the other a combination lock. The fist thing that came to mind was "getto fab!" I thought it was the funniest thing I have seen all day. What I also noticed about this place is that it was really color full. The celling at ribbons all around, there were beautiful hand pained art work on the walls. There were fresh daisy's everywhere and there was even a real life sculpture of the Virgin Mary on the wall! Now lets talk about the food! I have only been here once and I got the veggie taco which was good and really spicy. When I was about half way done with it, I kind of noticed that it tasted a little bit on the soapy side, I was really hungry so I kept on eating it. I just thought that was a little strange. But It was good, I suppose and for one veggie taco, one diet coke and chips and salsa the price of $3.94 is not that bad at all!! I may go here again when I am in the Mission and I am craving Mexican food. I would give this place a shot if you haven't gone yet.
author: Kris O.

description:
kinda like el farolito, maybe 2.5
with the hoards of late night eaters, this place is packed.  feels like an assembly line factory.
had an al pastor burrito, but it had so much other stuff in it, couldn't really taste the meat.  why so many pinto beans?
chips?  too salty.
author: Rob C.

description: This place is a yummy steal!  You can get a super soft taco for $3 and it comes with tons of tortilla chips with two salsas.  They're fast and efficient and they still smile and seem to be having fun while the line shoots out the door!  Lots of tables, you just have to time it right.
author: Rachel S.

description:
probably my fav burrito/taco joint still. 

it is so cheap, and so good! you can get so full with a super burrito for less than 8 dollars. 

my fav is super chicken burrito. they make really good super tacos too. 

it is open until 2 or 3 in the morning i think, which is very convenient for a late night dinner or post clubbing snacks :)
author: Danielle A.

description:
I have been eating burritos in the Mission for years
their salsa tastes like sewage, like it was made 3 day ago
then they added water to thin it out
'cause business is slow and they decided to cut corners
their seating is cramped "HBO's Oz-like" long bench-tables
so if you sit facing the kitchen instead of the front window
then the homeless wander in, sneak up behind you and try to rob you
VIVA El Castillito !
VIVA Pancho Villa !
author: Richard D.

description: They say best vegetarian burrito in town but I don't think rice or beans are vegetables. El Metate has THE BEST vegetarian burrito in town. This place is cheap and good for a quick fix only imho.
author: jason h.

description: Came here late at night after a fabulous concert in south bay. We were starving, and in dire need of food. These guys were not only efficient, order to food in front of u in 2-3 minutes.... but they serve one mean burrito! Great for those late night hunger attacks...
author: Gurpreet S.

description:
This review is only for a super chorizo burrito since that is all I ever get here.  I'm all for spicy but their chopped type salsa is just hot without taste so I usually cut that out and add my own favorite hot sauce.

But most importantly they put full slices of avacado, not greenstuff!
**************************
11/14 UPDATE

Forget the burrito!  It is all about the chorizo torta. I'll take bread over rice any day, so that works out .

and it doesnt come with salsa so you dont' have to worry about the whole "if I ask them to change one thing everything else will get fucked up" situation

I also want to point out that it is $4.12 with tax!
author: b s.

description:
Let's face it: it's pretty hard to screw up a burrito.  Everything that goes inside one is good eating so it only makes sense that stuffing it all into a big flour tortilla is bound to breed taste success.  But, it is hard to make a GREAT burrito.  Yes, achieving superior burrito technology is no simple feat and unfortunately most taquerias either lack the skill and/or desire to get there.  

Thankfully, Taqueria Cancun has gone the extra mile.  It's all in the details.  We're talking freshly cut avocado slices instead of guacamole that might as well be sour cream with green food coloring.  We're talking tortillas that are steamed just right: not overdone so its slimy nor underdone so it has too much bite.  Oh, and of course the MBR (Meat:Bean:Rice) ratio.  Dead on.  

As many other reviewers have pointed out, Cancun's ambiance doesn't exactly scream luxury nor is the crowd perfectly serene.  But, let's be real, taquerias are about the food.  And by that measure, it's hard to top Taqueria Cancun.
author: Rishi K.

description:
this place is indeed dirty and there are homeless folks filtering in and out grabbing food that is left on the unbussed (is that a word??) tables. After you wipe down a spot to sit I would suggest enjoying a burrito mojado (either carnitas or carne asada) I can't vouch for the chicken or anything else. The burrito is served on a plate topped with enchilada sauce, cheese, sour cream and the super spicy salsas. The chips are forgettable.

i always get the burrito mojado - it is the same price as the super burrito -  you can't go wrong!
author: Ashley T.

description:
I was pleasantly pleased to eat here!

The tacos were really good...I had carne asada and pollo asado tacos.  And then I tried my friend's Carne Asada platter and that's when i decided that I had to come back and order that next time!  It's a plate of meat and rice and beans with sour cream (which i am not a fan of, but just letting you know what it comes with), onions, salsa, and fresh slices of avocado!  And a separate container of tortillas which are soft and good.

I also had horchata, which was good but comes with a ton of ice.

Overall the place didn't feel that clean, but the food was good and I would come back again.  I was a little scared of the dark, deep bathroom.
author: Sareen L.

description:
Taqueria Cancun is probably one of those places where its only really good when eaten drunk, lucky for me that's exactly the state I was in when I ate here. 

I was raised in LA, the land of taco trucks and best greasy Mexican outside of Tijuana, so I know a thing or two about Mexican food. Taqueria Cancun lives up to the standard of drunken fare and then some. 

The greasy taco and burrito sopped up all the alcohol in my stomach like those Bounty commercials. I love how Taqueria Cancun uses slices of avocado instead of low grade guacamole. The salsa verde is really spicy which makes it nice and authentic and the tortillas have a little crunch to them (not wet like most places).

How do I know Taqueria Cancun did its job - I woke up without a hangover.
author: Arin N.

description:
Alright for all of you that have a hollow leg like me, get your culos over to Cancun and order a burrito mojado, it's the business.
